div.p:
THat Eminencie that is in a mo≈øt excellent Maecenas, to ≈øupply the defects and meanne≈ø≈øe of an ob≈øcure Author; and that Relation and obligation that a poore Clerk may have to a mo≈øt

The di≈øcour≈øe is of a mixt and various nature; and the theame of ≈øelf-killing is the ≈øubject both of Divinity, and of humanity; of Religion, and of Law: the full handling whereof may be ≈øerviceable to the Kings Maje≈øtie, for pre≈øervation of the lives of his people, again≈øt the blowes and mortall wounds of a ≈øelf-killing hand: and may be u≈øefull for the publick good of the Church and of the Common wealth; both for the ≈øafety of the ≈øoules and bodies of their members; and al≈øo, in point of Honour; that the government of ≈øo gracious a King, and the glory of ≈øo famous a Nation may not be ignominiou≈øly ≈øtayned, by ≈øelf-murdring practi≈øes.

In which re≈øpects, it was mo≈øt requi≈øite that I ≈øhould dedicate the treati≈øe of that nature to ≈øuch a noble Guardian, as hath a mo≈øt ≈øpeciall care to uphold and advance both Religion and Iu≈øtice; the honour of the King and kingdome; and the welfare both of Church and Commonwealth, in all the members of the ≈øame, as your Honourable Lord≈øhip alwaies hath, in the places of your imployment and re≈øidence: which, in cognizance of us in the Mini≈øtery, is ≈øpecially apparent, by your noble and pious care of providing able, painefull, and godly Mini≈øters to the Churches under your ≈øpeciall Patronage, be≈øtowing your Church-livings, both freely, and to the fitte≈øt and be≈øt de≈øerving that you can finde for tho≈øe places; and countenancing and furthering the Clergie, what you can, in all godly and legall cour≈øes; whereby multitudes of ≈øoules being ≈øaved, and the Church of England (under our Soveraigne the King) advanced and ≈øupported in the Honour of her Mini≈øtery, all have cau≈øe to prai≈øe God, and to pray to God for your Lord≈øhip, and for your noble Family, the honourable
in≈øtruments of ≈øo much divine and publick good; whereof many ble≈ø≈øed ≈øoules in heaven (≈øaved by that meanes) are witne≈ø≈øes before God, to your eternall prai≈øe, honour and comfort, with your renowned progenitors, of that practi≈øe.

And I confe≈ø≈øe, it is the dutie ≈øpecially of us of the Mini≈øtery to write your mo≈øt Illu≈øtrious name, and highe≈øt Commendations with the poynt of a Dyamond, in letters of Gold, upon the mo≈øt durable pillars of perpetuity; and ever to celebrate your due prai≈øe, both, for honour of your noble de≈øervings, and al≈øo for vertuous and pious example and incouragement to all po≈øterity, and noble Peeres, in that poynt ≈øpecially of upholding and advancing true Religion and piety, both in and by that carefull and con≈øcionable cour≈øe of be≈øtowing your Church-livings, and regarding of your Mini≈øters; and al≈øo, by your con≈øtant profe≈øsion of the truth; and, according to the ≈øame, profe≈ø≈øedly wor≈øhipping the true God; thereby publickly obliging your ≈øelfe to ≈øuch holines of heart and conver≈øation in walking with
God, according to the rules of true Religion; as may give your Lord≈øhip ≈øound and grounded hope of eternall life, and may verifie in you the realitie of that mo≈øt Chri≈øtian and heroick motto, Garde ta foy.

In a word, Divine Providence, and Heavens favour hath made your Lord≈øhip Rich; not onely by nature and name, but al≈øo in honor and manifold ble≈øsings upon you, and in much good done by your meanes, whereby you ≈øtand bound to be accordingly thankfull to God; and to be ever mindfull that your Eminency objects your Lord≈øhip to the worlds prying ob≈øervation, and to mens rigid cen≈øure, which requires your more carefull circum≈øpection in your whole conver≈øation, that you may be as farre di≈øtant from all ignoble vices, and ≈øinfull cour≈øes, (which ≈øtaines and aba≈øes Honour and greatne≈ø≈øe) and as Illu≈øtrious in all vertues, and commendable actions, as your noble condition is elevated above the common ranck of men; which conciliates and
procures Honour and comfort of a higher nature; and of more la≈øting continuance, than that which can be had from, or by Titles, and humane dignities, or from ≈øycophantizing humoring and flattering, that ≈øo you may attaine to eternall glory and happines after this ≈øhort life ended.

Mo≈øt noble Lord, I commed this treati≈øe to you, not onely that you may put credit and re≈øpect upon it, for publick favour and entertainment, and to give encouragement to the Author: but al≈øo, with all ob≈øervancie, to ≈øubject it to your judicious cen≈øure; and my ≈øelfe to the ≈øervice of your Honour and noble Family, for the furtherance of the good and ≈øalvation of you and yours, by the dayly prayers, and faithfull labours of him that ever remaines

div.head: THE PREFACE TO THE READERS OF THIS TREATISE: AND To my Auditors in my Mini≈øtery; ≈øpecially my ever much re≈øpected loving Friends, and re≈øpective Pari≈øhioners, the Inhabitants of Leigh in E≈ø≈øex: Grace and Peace be multiplyed.
div.p:
THis Treati≈øe I can neither commend to you, from the plea≈øantne≈ø≈øe of the nature of the ≈øubject of it, which is about Selfmurder; that is a wickedne≈ø≈øe not to be named among Chri≈øtians, in regard of likeing, or practice thereof: nor yet can I magnifie it to you for any thing that is ≈øimply mine in it; although there is much more mine in it, than might have beene, if there had been full and compleat Tractates made by other men of that ≈øubject; whence I might have borrowed more, and have had more
help, than now I could, to have made this a more perfect and better poli≈øhed peece.

I doubt not but it ≈øhall be found, in the advi≈øed and candide peru≈øall thereof, to carry in all the pa≈ø≈øages thereof the impre≈ø≈øe and ≈øtamp of truth; for which it may be worthy of your acceptation, both for information of judgment; and al≈øo for direction of practice, in many important points and ca≈øes.

Although I did not obtrude it to the pre≈ø≈øe for publique u≈øe, upon mine owne meere motion, or pre≈øumptuous ≈øelf-conceit; yet I need not make Apologie for my publication thereof, from the incouragements and furtherance of ≈øuch per≈øons, who≈øe worth of Judgement and power of godline≈ø≈øe is ≈øuch, as might be ≈øufficient to put mee forward to it; ≈øeeing that, in the≈øe dayes, wherein ≈øo many doe mo≈øt wretchedly, and unnaturally kill them≈øelves, it is a Tractate too nece≈ø≈øarie and u≈øefull: which ≈øufficiently warrants mee, upon and with the approbation of the Church, to divulge the ≈øame to the worlds view and ≈øervice.

Although many men of learning and worth, Ca≈øui≈øts, Schoolemen, and other Divines: Prote≈øtants, and Papi≈øts, Ancient and moderne, tran≈ømarine, and Dome≈øtick have occa≈øionally, or but brifely couched and condemned Self murder; yet I have met with no ≈øingle, nor compleat Treati≈øe of it. And therefore, ≈øeeing how requi≈øite and needfull it is that there were in the≈øe dayes, ≈øuch an entire Tractate of that ≈øubject, when as of mo≈øt other ≈øubjects, and of many le≈ø≈øe nece≈ø≈øary there is a ≈øurcharge of bookes and pamphlets; and finding my ≈øelfe, in this particular
unprevented by others of a Birth and opportunity free for me to adventure to the Sea of publickne≈ø≈øe, I have imbarqued my ≈øelfe in this bottome of di≈ømall denomination from Self-killing; which notwith≈øtanding ≈øpreads and carryes in the fore-top, and in the En≈øigne upon the Poup, the white and comfortable Colours of Lifes pre≈øervation, having all her force and ordnance bent again≈øt Self-murder; to overcome and ≈øink the ≈øame; for which purpo≈øe it di≈øplaies the Flagge of bloody colours again≈øt it in the maine Top of every page. And thus I have, for the good both of Church and Common-weale, and of the ≈øoules and bodies of men, (all which this ≈øubject doth neerly concerne,) adventured to commit my ≈øelf to the ≈øtormie and uncon≈øtant Ship-wrecking Ocean of this tumultuous and tempe≈øtuous world, under the ≈øailes of the pre≈ø≈øe, with flowen ≈øheets, qu√≤ fata ferunt, whither divine providence will carry me. I pray for heavens favour; for the worlds faire weather; and for a pro≈øperous voyage: de≈øiring that my au≈øpicable attempt may occa≈øion and provoke others of better abilities to perfect my good meaning and weake A≈ø≈øay, by their more exqui≈øite performances; and that my ≈øelfe may not be di≈øcouraged, by counterbla≈øts, or ill ≈øucce≈ø≈øe, in my fir≈øt ≈øetting ≈øaile out into the worlds view.

The Contents and worth of the Treati≈øe will bee apparent to the judicious Readers, upon the advi≈øed peru≈øall thereof: and the fruit of the ≈øame will ≈øhew it ≈øelfe, in the Effects of it: and according to your e≈øteeme in both, I doubt not but you will entertaine and regard it. I pray you read con≈øideratly every pa≈ø≈øage
thereof, and the whole to the end, before you ra≈øhly cen≈øure, condemne, or reject any thing therein, upon the fir≈øt mi≈øtake; either of the matter, or of the Authors meaning. What ≈øhall be, upon good rea≈øons, manife≈øted to me to be therein ami≈ø≈øe, I will willingly endeavour to amend and correct; with re≈øpective thankfulne≈ø≈øe to the Informer.

I affect not to ≈øtand upon the pinacle of publickne≈ø≈øe; objected to the contrary bla≈øts of every bodies impetuous cen≈øure, neither agreeing within them≈øelves, nor many times with the truth; where pa≈ø≈øion, prejudices, or their owne private un≈øound principles, and by-re≈øpects yeeld them the premi≈øes of their conclu≈øions.

Although I am, in ≈øome ≈øort, under an obligation of ancient intention to have made ≈øome thing publick, about the body of Practicall and Ca≈øe-divinity; yet I may be excu≈øed for not performing; becau≈øe the precipitating zeale and bold undertakings of le≈ø≈øe con≈øiderate youth are often commendably moderated, or recalled, by more mature and beter advi≈øed age.

I find ≈øo much, and ≈øo wel, ≈øcatteredly done by others (of great worth for judgment, piety, and experience,) touching that ≈øubject; which collected into one body, out of their writings publick and private, may ≈øuffice. And al≈øo I doe perceive that it may be hurtfull, be≈øides the difficultie of it, to de≈øcend particularly and punctually to the ≈øpeciall definite and publick determination in Print, of all incident ca≈øes, as the ≈øame may be diver≈øified, by their ≈øeverall circum≈øtances and accidents: whereupon I have beene hitherto deterred

For the pre≈øent, this Tractate I commend to your u≈øe. And above all, as I ≈øtand mo≈øt bound, I commend it to you my much re≈øpected Auditors and friends of my peculiar charge; whereupon I have faithfully, although in weake manner, attended and be≈øtowed my labours in my mini≈øtery the≈øe ≈øeaven and twenty yeares, and upward; (in ≈øucce≈øsion to a mo≈øt Reverend, Iudicious and godly Divine, a Father both to you and me,) endeavoring to doe you all the be≈øt ≈øervice and good that I could: and (I thank God) not without comfort of ≈øome fruit of my paines among you; although it be not ≈øo much as I would, for the ≈øalvation and welfare of you all; from whom neither any inte≈øtine di≈øcontents, nor externall invitations could ever hitherto prevaile to draw mee, to whom I found my ≈øelfe ≈øo ≈øtrongly obliged and tied, both by my comfortable calling, and the Churches order, to bee yours; and al≈øo by our mutuall entire affection and re≈øpects each of us to other; begun with your Ance≈øtors, and continued with your ≈øelves as the ≈øame ought to be betweene a Mini≈øter and his pari≈øhioners or people.

In which regard I leave and commend unto you this Treati≈øe, for a monument and witne≈ø≈øe, in times to come, of remembrance of your true and deare Friend; who≈øe la≈øt farewell, he would be loath ≈øhould be concluded with this le≈ø≈øe-plea≈øant ≈øubject. div.head: LIFES PRESERVATIVE AGAINST SELF-KILLING.
CHAP. 1. The generall de≈øcription of Self-murder.
¬ß. 1. Concerning life and death.
div.p:
Life and death things of great importance, and much to be regarded, are not rightly cared for.
LIfe and Death are two things of the greate≈øt importance in this world; both in re≈øpect of what they are; and whereto they tend: that is, their E≈ø≈øence; and the great con≈øequences that depend upon them: and yet there is nothing wherof many men are more regardle≈ø≈øe, than of their lives; how wretchedly they ≈øpend, and end them; and of their Deaths, how de≈øperately they incurre and contract them; ca≈øting them≈øelves into the danger of it, by the hands of others, or of
them≈øelves; although the ≈øinnes in which they die, can never afterwards be recovered, or eternall de≈øtruction be avoided.

And therefore, con≈øidering the dangerous and damnable practi≈øe of divers per≈øons de≈øperately de≈øtroying their owne lives, and murdering them≈øelves; with ≈øo great prejudice to the Honour of God and his truth imbraced among≈øt us; and with ≈øo much hurt to them≈øelves and others: I have adventured to treat more largely of the point of ≈øelf-murder, than yet I have ≈øeene the ≈øame done by others.
Touching which I will fir≈øt de≈øcribe in generall what it is.

div.head: ¬ß. 2. Self-murder de≈øcribed.

p.hi: Self-murder is the voluntary de≈øtroying of a mans owne life, by him≈øelfe, or his owne meanes and procurement.

div.p: 1. In which de≈øcription we are for the better under≈øtanding of it, to con≈øider, Fir≈øt, the object of ≈øelf-murder, and that is the life of man.
2. Secondly, the act it ≈øelfe; which is the voluntary taking away of life, or unju≈øtly de≈øtroying of it; which makes it to be murder.

3. Thirdly, the efficient cau≈øe, or meanes of the de≈øtruction of mans life, and that (in this ca≈øe) is a mans owne ≈øelfe by his owne procurement; which ≈øpecifies the act, and makes it to be properly ≈øelf-murder.

div.head: ¬ß. 3. Self-murder is knowne by life.
div.p:
Life. In explicating the≈øe in order, I will begin at life; as fir≈øt in nature, and more au≈øpicable; which is the object of ≈øelf-murder. For, ≈øelf-murder being death, and death being onely a privation, it cannot be knowne what it is but by the knowledge of life, which is its contrarie: for, no
privation can be defined (in regard of its want of entitie in it ≈øelfe,) but by its oppo≈øite habit: as no man, that knows not in ≈øome mea≈øure what light is, can know what darkne≈ø≈øe is.

Evill cleaves to good. And ≈øelf-murder being in it ≈øelfe evill, it cannot be but in and about that thing which of it ≈øelfe is good. 1. For evill cleaves and adheres to good for two rea≈øons; fir≈øt, that it may ≈øub≈øi≈øt, which extra ≈øubjectum bonum, without the ≈øubject of good cannot be: for, evill is like to the di≈øea≈øe called the woolfe, which maintains it ≈øelf by eating & feeding upon the body wherein it is. For, as non datur ≈øummum malum, nec datur merum malum per ≈øe exi≈øtens: There is nothing ab≈øolutely evill, neither is there a meere evill ≈øub≈øi≈øting by it ≈øelfe, but in that which is good.

2. Secondly, evill adheres to that which is good, that it may convert and turne the good ≈øubject wherein it is, into the quality of it ≈øelfe, ≈øo making it nought, and de≈øtroying it; as loaven that ≈øowreth the whole lump wherein it is: the nature of all evill is ever active and de≈øtructive of that good that entertaines it, or that it is exerci≈øed about, it being as the worm that de≈øtroyes the tree wherein it breeds and harbours.

Ob≈øerve. All things are ≈øubject in this world to contraric pa≈ø≈øions. From whence we may ob≈øerve that, as all created ≈øub≈øtances are mutable, ≈øo are they capable of, and ≈øubject unto contrary pa≈ø≈øions and qualities in this world; and by how much the more excellent any good thing in this world is, ≈øo much the wor≈øe is the contrary evill that attends upon and corrupts it; and therefore the better that any created thing is on earth, the more danger it is in, and needs the greater care and indeavour to be had about it, to pre≈øerve it again≈øt its oppo≈øite evill: ≈øo, life being of the nature and number of the be≈øt things, it is in danger of the wor≈øt evils, and therefore is with the greater care and circum≈øpection to be watched over, for its pre≈øervation.

div.head: CHAP. 2. Of the kindes of the life of man.
div.p: THat we may know what life is, & (becau≈øe there be divers kinds of it) wch it is that in ≈øelf murder is de≈øtroyed by death; we are to con≈øider there are two kinds of the life of man; Kinds of life, naturall and ≈øpirituall. the fir≈øt is naturall, the ≈øecond is ≈øpirituall; according as he con≈øi≈øts of two natures, and is an inhabitant of two worlds; being made of heaven and earth, to inhabit both: there is no creature in the world that con≈øi≈øts of ≈øuch various & different compo≈øition as man; nor is indowed with ≈øuch multiplicity of vitall operations, or ≈øuch variety of properties and qualities, fitted for diver≈øity of actions of ≈øo many kindes; and thereupon is ≈øubject to ≈øo many and oppo≈øite motions and temptations.

Ob≈øerv. Mans care mu≈øt be of two lives. From the divers kindes of mans life, we may ob≈øerve, that mans care mu≈øt not bee (as the brute bea≈øts) to live according to the in≈øtinct of nature, but that he may live by a ≈øupernaturall principle, and divine direction, a ≈øpirituall life, even here in this naturall life, as he expects to arrive, and attaine to a more excellent and heavenly end of advancement, than other earthly creatures do, or ≈øhall: and there is a taske of more and greater porformances required to be done by him, than from any other creature on earth.

div.head: CHAP. 3. Of naturall life in generall.
¬ß. 1. of divers ≈øorts of life.
div.p:
Kindes of naturall life. FOr our better under≈øtanding of naturall life, wee are generally to con≈øider that, according to the di≈øtinction
of earthly living creatures, there be three kindes of naturall lives.

1. Of vegetation. Fir≈øt, that which is called the life of vegetation; which is the life of trees, plants, corne, and the like; whereby they grow and encrea≈øe, both in their ≈øeverall kindes, and in their individuals.
2. Life of ≈øen≈øe. Secondly, the life of ≈øen≈øe, whereby irrationall and ≈øen≈øitive creatures do, be≈øides their life of vegetation common with plants, live inlived with ≈øen≈øe and motion.

Now the≈øe two kindes of lives, con≈øidered ≈øpecifically in the afore≈øaid ≈øeverall kindes of creatures, fall not under the con≈øideration of, nor are ≈øubject to ≈øelf-murder; becau≈øe the law again≈øt murder is not given to them, who are not properly capable of the ≈øame, by meanes of their want of rea≈øon: neither are they ≈øubject to this fact and ≈øin of ≈øelf-murder, which by in≈øtinct of nature they abhorre, and doe alwaies naturally indeavour their owne pre≈øervation.

3. Rationall life. The third kinde of naturall life is that which is called rationall, or of rea≈øonable creatures; which is proper to men; whereby they live, (be≈øides the life of vegetation and ≈øen≈øe, common with other earthly living creatures,) according to rea≈øon, or in a rationall manner; both for the e≈ø≈øentiall forme of their natures, whereby they are called rationall creatures; and al≈øo for their thoughts and actions; which for their originall principle, whence they flow, and for the rule whereby they are ordered, are rea≈øonable, morall, and more divine in all their motions, than are other earthly creatures; if the ≈øame be not perverted by ≈øome other exorbitant principles, or accidents.

In and under this rationall life of man, both the other lives are comprehended; as things inferior and ≈øubordinate are contained in their ≈øuperiour and ≈øummary head. Note. Mans perfection. The perfections of all other earthly creatures are in man, together with, or comprehended in that which is proper to him≈øelfe, whereby he tran≈øcends them all.

div.head: ¬ß. 2. Man only is ≈øubject to ≈øelf-murder.
div.p: Notwith≈øtanding that man indowed with under≈øtanding hath the greate≈øt helps again≈øt ≈øelf-murder, and hath the greate≈øt rea≈øon of all worldly creatures to pre≈øerve his life, it being ≈øo excellent above theirs, yet he onely of them all is ≈øubject to this fault and mi≈øchiefe of ≈øelf-murder.

div.head: ¬ß. 3. How naturall life is knowne by man in whom it is.
div.p: Touching the knowledge of the naturall life of man, a rea≈øonable living creature apprehends the ≈øame, both by ≈øen≈øe and under≈øtanding: This life is knowne 1. by ≈øen≈øe. by ≈øen≈øe, a rea≈øonable creature not onely de≈øcernes that it lives; but al≈øo feeles this life by the effects of it, to be a quickning power of inlivening the body inwardly, and di≈øpo≈øing and inabling it to action outwardly.

2. By under≈øtanding. By under≈øtanding, a man knowes that this life is an act of the ≈øpirit, or ≈øoule in the body of man; or a quickning vertue of it, in a continued fluxe, by the per≈øonall union of the ≈øoule and body together.

div.head: ¬ß. 4. The ≈øoules double act of life in man.
div.p:
The ≈øoules act of life in man. This act of the ≈øoule in its union with the body, is twofold. 1. Making the ≈øubiect to live. Fir≈øt, that which re≈øpects the bodie it ≈øelf; or rather mans per≈øon, in that worke, or lively energie, which we may, in ≈øome re≈øpect, call opus ad intra, or a reflexe worke of man upon him≈øelfe; upon the per≈øonall union of the ≈øoule and bodie, whereby he becomes a living ≈øoule, Gen. 2.7. for exten≈øion, in all his parts; and for inten≈øiox, in fulne≈ø≈øe of lively power; for his ≈øub≈øi≈øting and growth to his appointed period; and for u≈øe of all his organs and faculties, for their proper function; being thereby al≈øo able to di≈øcerne, take notice and judge of him≈øelfe, his ≈øtate and actions: For, not the ≈øoule only, nor the body onely is to be properly ≈øaid to live, after their union together; but the per≈øon, con≈øi≈øting both of ≈øoule and body, doth live this life; which is not the life of either of the natures, or parts of man by them≈øelves con≈øidered;Man lives or dies per≈øonally con≈øidered. but the life of the per≈øon of man con≈øi≈øting of both natures per≈øonally united. And therefore, when one kills a man, we ≈øay not properly that he hath onely killed an earthly body; but we ≈øay properly that he hath killed ≈øuch a per≈øon, as con≈øi≈øts of a ≈øoule and a body: and therefore, it is ≈øaid in Scripture, that there were ≈øo many ≈øoules ≈ølaine
Jo≈øhua 10.28.; not that the immortall ≈øpirit is in it ≈øelfe ≈øubject to ≈øuch a death, or can be ≈ølaine; but in regard of its Acting and working in its per≈øonall union with the bodie; whereby both of them live per≈øonally together, that life which is the life of the per≈øon; which is de≈øtroyed, and cea≈øes upon death, which is further apparent by this, Rea≈øon. becau≈øe, the murder of a man is ≈øo hainous a crime, in regard of the de≈øtruction of the Image of God in man; which is not onely in the body, or onely in the ≈øoule, but is in the whole per≈øon of man, ≈øo long as the ≈øame lives.

2 Making the ≈øubject to worke. The ≈øecond lively act of the ≈øoule in this union with
the body per≈øonally con≈øidered; is that whereby it makes the body organically fitly di≈øpo≈øed and active to tho≈øe duties, which we call opera ad extra, works about objects, not it ≈øelfe: which works are the common outward workes of the per≈øon con≈øi≈øting of tho≈øe two natures, and not of either of them apart.

Ob≈øerve. Upon life depends the ≈øub≈øi≈øting and working of the per≈øon. Whereupon wee may ob≈øerve, that upon this life depends, both the ≈øub≈øi≈øting of the per≈øon of man in its being; and al≈øo all its actions naturall, civill and morall: ≈øo that, he that kills a man de≈øtroyes his per≈øon, and aboli≈øhes all his per≈øonall actions and activity, whereby he might be ≈øerviceable and u≈øefull to God, to him≈øelfe, to the Church, or Commonwealth. And yet we ≈øee no thing more pa≈ø≈øionately and ra≈øhly enterpri≈øed than killing of men, than the which nothing ≈øhould be more deliberately and upon weightier cau≈øes done, it being no le≈ø≈øer matter than to di≈ø≈øolve heaven and earth, by de≈øtruction of a per≈øon con≈øi≈øting of an heavenly ≈øpirit, and of an earthly body, to de≈øtroy the noble≈øt naturall life; and to deprive God, and the world of the mo≈øt glorious and profitable workes. Such a thing is this naturall life of man generally con≈øidered.

div.head: CHAP. 4. Of mans naturall life more ≈øpecially.
¬ß. 1. Wherein the naturall life of man con≈øi≈øts.
div.p:
Mans naturall life is fraile. Phil. 1.22. expounded. MAns naturall life con≈øi≈øts (as in part wee have heard) in the Act of the ≈øoule united per≈øonally with the body, by meanes of the animall, naturall, and vitall ≈øpirits: which the Apo≈øtle calls living in the fle≈øh, Philip. 1.22. which is to live neither to the fle≈øh to fulfill the lu≈øts thereof, nor yet is it to live according to the
fle≈øh, directing our waies by our owne carnall wi≈ødome and will: but, thereby is intimated living in a fraile and ≈øinfull body, ≈øubject to manifold troubles and infirmities: in which regard, it is a fading and temporary life, as Saint Iames tels us, Iam. 4.14. comparing it to a vapour that vani≈øheth away.

With the which life all men that come into this world are indowed, as Saint Iohn affirmes, Ioh. 1.9. and this naturall life is onely for this ≈øublunary world, and not for the world to come; for, our lives do differ according to our e≈øtates, and places wherein we are to live.

div.head: ¬ß. 2. The ≈øweetne≈ø≈øe of naturall life.
div.p: In what re≈øpect naturall life is ≈øweet. Even this naturall life is ≈øweet, in regard of the union of the ≈øoule and body together; and in re≈øpect of the pre≈øervation of our per≈øons by it; and for the workes that we may doe in it, for Gods glory and our owne ≈øalvation.

1. So that the le≈ø≈øe certainty that a man hath of a better life, the more deare this ≈øhould be unto him, that therein he may enjoy the pre≈øent, and may provide for a better; 2. and al≈øo the more zeale and de≈øire that a man hath to doe good, in glorifying of God, and in benefiting of others; (and the more care he hath of advancement of his owne eternall happine≈ø≈øe,) the more is hee to re≈øpect his life wherein the ≈øame is to be done.

div.head: ¬ß. 3. The lo≈ø≈øe of naturall life is horrible and painefull.
div.p:
How death is naturally horrible. God hath ≈øo ordained that, the departure of the ≈øoule from the body ≈øhould ordinarily be horrible to mans apprehen≈øion, and with paine and grie≈øe; not onely in re≈øpect of parting two ≈øuch ≈øweet Companions, which ≈øeparated are imperfect the one without the other; but al≈øo in re≈øpect of the utter de≈øtruction of their common,
naturall, per≈øonall life; and the cutting off of all the≈øe comfortable actions and affections, that depend upon, and do tend to the perfection of the ≈øame: Which is to the end that man may naturally endeavour the pre≈øervation of his life, again≈øt all dangers; and may abhorre ≈øelf-murder, that deprives him of ≈øo much good.

div.head: ¬ß. 4. How life is deare and precious.
div.p:
Life deare. There is nothing in the world more deare to a man than his life; in which regard it was that Satan ≈øaid to the Lord touching Iob, all that a man hath will he give for his life, Iob. 2.4. and, for the excellency and u≈øe of it, Salomon calls it the precious life, Prov. 6.26. and therefore, he ≈øhould not part from it, or ca≈øt it away for a trifle, or in a humour; ≈øpecially ≈øeeing he can never redeeme, or recover it againe from death
P≈øal. 49.7..

Rea≈øons. 1 It pre≈øerves the per≈øon in being. For three rea≈øons e≈øpecially is the life of man precious: Fir≈øt, becau≈øe by it the per≈øon of man is pre≈øerved in its e≈ø≈øe or being, by per≈øonall union of ≈øoule and body; which otherwi≈øe would be di≈ø≈øolved and undone. Now, betweene being and not being there is ≈øo va≈øt a di≈øtance and oppo≈øition, that a creature doth naturally de≈øire rather to live mi≈øeraebly, than not to live; as is apparent by that naturall in≈øtinct, whereby the creature, to ≈øave its life or vitall parts, objects and offers its le≈ø≈øe principall members to undergoe the danger: choo≈øing rather to live mutilate and wretched, than, for prevention thereof, to die. For, the lo≈ø≈øe of life is not onely irrevocable, and unmatchable in worth, compared with that worldly thing for which it is exchanged; but al≈øo, it includes all other worldly lo≈ø≈øes in it; and therefore, it is farre the greate≈øt lo≈ø≈øe that man can ≈øuffer.

2 It makes capable of comfort. Secondly, it is by life that the creature is capable of any comfort, or of the u≈øe and benefit of the ble≈ø≈øings of good
things, that God gives us to rejoyce in, in this world: for, to a dead man all this world and plea≈øure of it is gone; and to him that wants ≈øen≈øe, the u≈øe and delight of all ≈øen≈øible things is lo≈øt: in which re≈øpect Solomon ≈øaith, to him that is joyned to all the living there is hope: for, a living Dog is better than a dead Lyon, Eccle≈ø. 9.4. ≈øo it is, under God, by the ble≈ø≈øing of life, that other good things are ble≈ø≈øings to us; and that the mi≈øeries and calamities, that betide us here, are le≈ø≈øe evills than death: for that, partiall and initiall evills are ever le≈ø≈øe than tho≈øe that are compleate and full; tho≈øe that afflict, than tho≈øe that extingui≈øh.

3. For the u≈øe of it. Thirdly, life is precious for the u≈øe and improvement of it: 1 To Gods glory.Fir≈øt, to Gods glory, in ≈øpending of it in manner according to his holy word; with re≈øpect to God, for the end that we aime at: in which regard, godly Hezekiah ≈øaid, that not the dead, but the living prai≈øe God
E≈øay 38.18, 19. .

2 To others. Secondly, the preciou≈øne≈ø≈øe of mans life is ≈øeene in the u≈øe of it, for the good that thereby is done to others; both in civill and divine good offices, in Church and Commonwealth: as the Apo≈øtle Paul confe≈ø≈øeth of him≈øelfe, that he did live for the ≈øpirituall benefit of the Philippians, Phil. 1.24, 25.

As for the dead, they are unprofitable to the living, as appeares by E≈øay 63.16. ≈øaying, that Abraham is ignorant of us: and the P≈øalmi≈øt tels us, that we ≈øhould not put our tru≈øt in Princes, nor in the ≈øonne of man, in whom there is no help: and then gives the rea≈øon of it; His breath goeth forth, he returneth to his earth, in that very day his thoughts peri≈øh
P≈øal. 46.304. .

3 To a mans ≈øelfe. Thirdly, the excellencie and nece≈ø≈øity of life is ≈øeene, in the u≈øe and benefit of it to a mans ≈øelfe; in fitting him for heaven, by working up of his ≈øalvation here in this life, and in advancing him≈øelfe in glory, both by adorning his per≈øon with divine and ≈øaving graces of Gods ≈øpirit; and al≈øo, by holy actuall obedience, and dutifull performances
to God, in tract of living. For, if a man doe not at all live this naturall life, he cannot be capable of eternall life: and although he do live this naturall life, yet if he do not endeavour to extend and employ it to the attainment of ≈øalvation, but that it be cut off, before ≈øalvation be wrought, he cannot but of nece≈ø≈øity peri≈øh for ever. For, as the tree falls, ≈øo it ≈øhall lye, there is no amendment of our e≈øtate and errors after death: as appeares by the parable of the rich man, Luke 16.25, 26. if God doe give a man life and time, he puts a price into his hand, and gives him a great ble≈ø≈øing, for his advancement to a better life.

And therefore, in all the afore≈øaid re≈øpects, it is apparent that life is the mo≈øt precious thing, that God be≈øtowes upon man, whereby all other ble≈ø≈øings to us are expre≈ø≈øed: as appeares by Abrahams ≈øpeech to the Lord, ≈øaying, Oh that I≈øhmael might live before thee
Gen.17.18.
V≈øe. To pre≈øerve life..

The chiefe u≈øe of the former doctrine is, to provoke and move us to u≈øe all lawfull meanes to pre≈øerve, and prolong our lives: for hee that wills the end, ≈øhould al≈øo will the meanes, whereby he may attaine to that end.

div.head: ¬ß. 5. Of the meanes of lifes pre≈øervation.
div.p: The meanes. 1. Prayer. Tho≈øe meanes are, fir≈øt, prayer to God for to ≈øu≈øtaine and pre≈øerve our lives, e≈øpecially in apparent dangers: as David did, P≈øal. 102.24. ≈øaying, Oh my God take me not away in the mid≈øt of my dayes. For, as our lives depend upon him, that is the fountaine of life, Ioh. 1.4. ≈øo our eyes mu≈øt be to him for a continuall influxe of continuing the ≈øame: in regard of outward dangers, and inward mortality dayly putting our lives in jeopardy, which of our ≈øelves we are not able to re≈øi≈øt.

2. Foode, cheerefulne≈ø≈øe, &c. The ≈øecond meanes of the pre≈øervation of mans life, is the moderate and cheerefull u≈øe of nece≈ø≈øary foode and raiment, with other convenient comforts and delights,
needfull to cheri≈øh and pre≈øerve our lives: according to Solomons direction, that there is nothing better for a man, than that he ≈øhould eate and drinke, and that he ≈øhould make his ≈øoule enjoy good in his labour, Eccle≈ø. 2.24. according to Iacobs de≈øire, Gen. 28.20. intreating God, that he might have bread to eate, and cloathes to put on: not to hoard and lay up, but for his u≈øe.

For a man to have plenty, and yet to be in want, is a mi≈øerable condition; for, ≈øo he defrauds and wrongs him≈øelfe; he is injurious to the creatures, in not imploying them to the u≈øe for which God made and gave them; and is ingratefull to God, in not rightly u≈øing his ble≈ø≈øings, ≈øo as he may thereby doe God the greate≈øt honor and ≈øervice.

Of cheerefulne≈ø≈øe. Cheerefulne≈ø≈øe is an excellent meanes of life; for, as Solomon ≈øaies, by ≈øorrow of heart the ≈øpirit is broken; and all the dayes of the afflicted are evill; but a merry heart maketh a cheerefull countenance; and he that is of a merry heart hath a continuall fea≈øt
Prov. 15.13, 15.: and therefore, Eccle≈ø. 8.15. he commendeth mirth; becau≈øe a man hath no better thing under the ≈øun, than to eate, and to drinke, and to be merry; for, that ≈øhall abide with him of his labour, the daies of his life, which God giveth him under the ≈øunne: and for this purpo≈øe, God gives us ≈øome things that are onely for delight, and of other things he often be≈øtowes ≈øuch plenty, upon us, as ≈øhewes it to be his plea≈øure that we ≈øhould u≈øe them, not onely for nece≈ø≈øity, but al≈øo for cheering of us; that we may both ta≈øte thereby how good he is to us; and al≈øo, that we may the more joyfully ≈øerve him, with gladne≈ø≈øe of heart, in health and in plenty of all things.

Grounds of cheerefulne≈ø≈øe. 1 A good con≈øcience, grace and hope. The grounds of this Cheerefulne≈ø≈øe are two; Fir≈øt, inward peace of con≈øcience, in the apprehen≈øion of Gods favour and love to us in Chri≈øt Ie≈øus; in the comfortable evidence of the pardon of our ≈øins; in the undeceivable enjoying of the ≈øaving graces of Gods ≈øpirit; in the truth
of our conformity and obedience to God; and in a≈ø≈øured hope of everla≈øting life and happine≈ø≈øe, all which will make us to rejoyce, yea even in tribulation, Rom. 5.3. with joy un≈øpeakeable and glorious.

2. Outward ble≈ø≈øings. The ≈øecond ground of our cheerefulne≈ø≈øe is, the outward favours and benefits that God in mercy be≈øtowes upon us; whereof wee are to take the pre≈øent u≈øe and ≈øweetne≈ø≈øe; not depriving our ≈øelves thereof, nor deading our ≈øpirits with feares of uncertaine, or remote future evils: according to the direction of our Saviour, Mat. 6.34. Take no thought for the morrow: forbidding anxious tormenting care for feare of en≈øuing cro≈ø≈øes, and according to the practi≈øe of Hezekiah, to whom the Lord had denounced fearefull judgements upon his po≈øterity, who ≈øaid, Good is the word of the Lord: for there ≈øhall be peace and truth in my dayes, I≈øai. 39.8.

3. Phy≈øick. Thirdly, to pre≈øerve our lives it is requi≈øite that we u≈øe the ≈øea≈øonable, fit and moderate help of Phy≈øick, to prevent or remove di≈øea≈øes; which are not onely the enemies of life, but are al≈øo an inchoate, or begun death; as Hezekiah did take a lump of figgs, and laid it on his boile, for his recovery, 2 King. 20.7. according to Gods direction by E≈øay the Prophet: in this re≈øpect did Saint Paul direct Timothie to drinke no longer water, but to u≈øe a little wine, for his ≈øtomacks ≈øake, and his often infirmities, 1 Tim. 5.23. that ≈øo a man may not be a deficient cau≈øe of the pre≈øervation of his owne life, when God gives meanes to ≈øave, or prolong it.

div.head: ¬ß. 6. How to u≈øe Phy≈øick.
div.p:
Cautions about Phy≈øick. 1. That wee tru≈øt not to it. In taking of Phy≈øick wee are alwaies to ob≈øerve the≈øe ≈øub≈øequent cautions: Fir≈øt, that wee dote not upon, nor tru≈øt, or a≈øcribe too much to phy≈øicall meanes; but that we carefully looke and pray to God for a ble≈ø≈øing by the warrantable u≈øe of them. For, it is God that both directs
the Phy≈øitians judgement, and con≈øcionable practi≈øe about a patient; and al≈øo puts vertue into, and gives healthfull operation to the medicines.

2. U≈øe it moderately. Secondly, that we u≈øe Phy≈øick moderately; not out of wantonne≈ø≈øe, but for nece≈ø≈øity: nor as our daily diet, bringing our ≈øelves under a nece≈ø≈øity of ever u≈øing it; and ≈øo by repairing of the hou≈øe of our body, wee may wa≈øte and overthrow it: neither are we then to u≈øe Phy≈øick, when there is no needfull cau≈øe, nor yet in ≈øuch de≈øperate ca≈øes, where there is no hope of life, but apparent ≈øignes of approching death; le≈øt under an intent of prolonging life wee doe ≈øhorten it, or of curing wee doe kill; where there is not ≈øtrength of nature to help phy≈øick to work its due effect.

3. U≈øe it not ra≈øhly. Thirdly, our care about Phy≈øick mu≈øt be, that wee doe not unadvi≈øedly and ra≈øhly u≈øe it; either by practi≈øing upon our ≈øelves, or others beyond our skill, or calling: or el≈øe by taking Phy≈øick from others, that be either pre≈øumptuous-ignorant Empericks, or prophane and de≈øperate di≈øpen≈øers and undertakers, neither con≈øcionable in their owne lives, nor tender of the lives of others: but, are more de≈øirous of their patients monies, than of their healths: and therefore, our endeavour ≈øhould be to take phy≈øick both ≈øea≈øonably for time, and al≈øo by the coun≈øell and direction of ≈øuch, as be both skilfull per≈øons in that facultie, and al≈øo con≈øcionable, for religion and piety; that God may ble≈ø≈øe their labours the better; who will be tender and carefull of mens lives, working by ≈øafe cour≈øes, and in manner fit for their patients good: and herein, what ever the effect be, men may have comfort, when they ≈øhall have in≈øi≈øted in a warrantable way.

4. Not to be perplexed about the event. Fourthly, wee are to take heed that we be not anxiou≈øly perplexed and troubled, when upon the u≈øing or forbearing of Phy≈øick, upon warrantable grounds, the effect an≈øwers not our de≈øire or expectation: But, ≈øuppo≈øe the patient dies, or labours under any griefe unrecovered,
without hope of cure: it is folly to vexe our ≈øelves, becau≈øe we have not u≈øed this body, or that body, this medicine or that medicine, thinking, or ≈øaying, if we had done this, or that, our ≈øelves, or ≈øome other patient belonging to us, had beene recovered: ju≈øt as Mary ≈øaid to Chri≈øt, Lord, if thou had≈øt beene here my Brother had not died
Ioh. 11.32..

When a thing contrarie to our de≈øire is done, wherein we are not faultie, when wee worke according to our pre≈øent knowledge and meanes, we ≈øhould re≈øt content with the will of God, how adver≈øe, or cro≈ø≈øe ≈øoever it ≈øeemes to us: con≈øidering that, as God appoints the end and thing that doe come to pa≈ø≈øe, ≈øo doth he likewi≈øe direct and order the meanes to accompli≈øh the ≈øame. For, God oftentimes over-rules our purpo≈øe, mens skill, and the nature and effects of Phy≈øick, to the bringing to pa≈ø≈øe of his owne purpo≈øes, contrary to our expectation: which mu≈øt bee attributed to God the ≈øoveraigne Lord, and is not to bee imputed to unblameable men and meanes, that are but the in≈øtruments under God, and ≈øubject to his controle and di≈øpo≈øition: and therefore, touching the events thereupon following, wee mu≈øt bee content to be cro≈ø≈øed of our wils ≈øometime, that God at all times may have his.

div.head: ¬ß. 7. Of deadly things to be re≈øi≈øted.
div.p: 4. Oppo≈øition of deadly things. Fourthly and la≈øtly, to pre≈øerve his life, every man is bound to decline, and oppo≈øe all things that tend to the unlawfull taking of it away: for, that which other creatures do, by Antipathie, and in≈øtinct of nature, for ≈øhunning that which is contrary or pernicious to them; man is, by the meanes of his rea≈øon and will, to do the like for his pre≈øervation: who, by his intellectuall parts, can better fore≈øee and di≈øcerne what is hurtfull and dangerous to him or his life.

1 Inva≈øion. The things that e≈øpecially he is to decline and beware of are: Fir≈øt, Forcible inva≈øion, whereby his life is a≈ø≈øaulted or indangered, and his death attempted by others: For, be≈øides the perill that a mans life is in, by that inbred poy≈øon of di≈øea≈øes and mortality in him≈øelfe, it is lyable to death, by meanes from without him≈øelfe, whereof a man is to be carefull, both to fore≈øee the ≈øame, and to prevent it, or to extricate and free him≈øelfe out of it: as we ≈øee how Paul, (under≈øtanding of a con≈øpiracy of above 40. men lying in waite to take away his life,) u≈øed his be≈øt indeavours to decline and prevent the ≈øame, by di≈øcovery thereof to the chiefe Captaine, Act. 23.17. and ≈øo our Saviour him≈øelfe gave commandement to his Di≈øciples, that when their enemies did per≈øecute them in one citie they ≈øhould flee to another, Mat 10.23. according to his own practi≈øe, who to avoid and e≈øcape the bloody hands of Herod, was carried into Egypt Mat. 2. : which cour≈øe is abundantly warranted by manifold arguments and examples in Scripture, and upon ju≈øt rea≈øon, is ≈øo good, that nece≈ø≈øity of ≈øaving a mans life, again≈øt unju≈øt and violent inva≈øion, warrants him, both in the Courts of Heaven and Earth, in his owne lawfull defence, to kill, rather than to ≈øuffer him≈øelfe to be unju≈øtly killed: becau≈øe, that love, which is the fulfilling of the Law
Rom. 13.10., begins at a mans ≈øelfe, it being the rule, that we ≈øhould love our neighbours as our ≈øelves. How can it bee expected that he will pre≈øerve other mens lives, that is carele≈ø≈øe of his owne? Qui ≈øibi nequam cui bonus?

2. Dangerous undertakings. Secondly, for pre≈øervation of mans life, he mu≈øt not onely not ≈øubmit him≈øelfe pa≈ø≈øively to private deadly cruelties of others: but al≈øo he mu≈øt not actively expo≈øe him≈øelfe to hazard the lo≈ø≈øe of his life, upon ≈øelf-will'd dangerous undertakings, without a lawfull calling, and ≈øufficiency of ≈øtrength to undertake, or go ≈øafely through the enterpri≈øe: as our Saviour intimates, Luk. 14.31. in the parable of the King going to warre, that would
not undertake above his power.

3. Motions of ≈øelf-murder. Thirdly, the thing that a man is to decline, for pre≈øervation of his life is, that he do abhorre and reject all unnaturall motions, or re≈øolutions of ≈øelf-murder. That the heart of man may neither be ≈øuffered to breed, nor to entertaine the thoughts of his owne de≈øtruction; like a viper conceiving and ≈øomenting ≈øuch an i≈ø≈øue, as in the birth thereof de≈øtroyes the parent that gave it being. The thoughts of evill, that a man doth at fir≈øt but dally withall, and fearele≈øly beholds in his mind, (pre≈øuming of his power over them;) at length po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe him, and ma≈øter him: and therefore, above all things, wee are to keep our heart, for, out of it proceeds all evill. Prov. 4.23. Mat. 15.19. if the ≈øeed and ≈øpawne of ≈øin in the motions of it in the heart be extingui≈øhed and de≈øtroyed, then there is no feare of the breaking of it out in act: for, as Saint Iames ≈øaith, Lu≈øt fir≈øt conceives before it brings forth ≈øin
Jam. 1.15..

div.head: ¬ß. 8. Of ≈øpending our lives well.
div.p:
To ≈øpend our lives well. Another generall u≈øe of the former doctrine of the pretiou≈øne≈ø≈øe of mans life is, that wee be the more carefull to hu≈øband and ≈øpend it well; to the glory of God; our owne good and comfort; and for the good of others, among whom we live: con≈øidering that our life is too good to be ≈øpent away in idlene≈ø≈øe, to bee wa≈øted prodigally; or to bee mi≈ø-imployed in the ≈øervice of ≈øinne and Sathan; and is irrevocable, when it is pa≈øt, that it cannot be had backe againe; that it might be better ≈øpent, and former errors be undone: and therefore, we doe ever need, with the P≈øalmi≈øt, to intreat that God would ≈øo teach us to number our dayes, that wee may apply our hearts unto wi≈ødome
P≈øal. 90.12.: being ever mindfull of the Apo≈øtles admonition; redeeme the time, becau≈øe the dayes are evill, Eph. 5.16.

Motives. The motives that may move us to ≈øpend our time,
and life well, are ≈øpecially the≈øe three following. Fir≈øt, 1. Badne≈ø≈øe of the times. the wickedne≈ø≈øe of the world, which ≈øhould make us more watchfull, to catch at all opportunities to do good; that our life, that will wa≈øte away with the ru≈øt of doing nothing, may bee comfortably ≈øpent, in well doing: Happy ≈øhall that ≈øervant be, whom his Lord, when he comes, ≈øhall find doing ≈øo. Mat. 24.46.

2. Shortne≈ø≈øe of our lives. Secondly, the ≈øhortne≈ø≈øe and uncertainty of our lives, (which pa≈ø≈øes as a ≈øhadow, or a vapour, that appeares no more,) puts us in mind, not to deferre; but, while it is called to day, requires us, with ≈øobriety and watchfulne≈ø≈øe, to be couragious and ince≈ø≈øant in well doing. Po≈øt e≈øt occa≈øio calva, the morrow is not ours; and if we be cut off before it comes, our worke being undone; how then will it grieve us that we were ≈øo ≈ølothfull?

3. The benefit of well-≈øpending them. Thirdly, the weightine≈ø≈øe of that which depends upon well-≈øpending of our lives here; as, the comfort of our ≈øoules, and everla≈øting ≈øalvation hereafter, calls upon us to con≈øider, that no e≈øtate or ≈øtock need be ≈øo frugally ≈øpent, as the ≈øhort life and few dayes of man; than which, nothing is more wa≈øtefully, worthle≈øly, vainely, nor wor≈øe mi≈ø-≈øpent; ≈øpecially three wayes: to which we may adde a fourth.

How men mi≈ø-pend their lives. 1. By doing evill. Fir≈øt, in doing of naughtine≈ø≈øe and evill; which wee ought not to doe, it being forbidden by God: whereby many men take great paines in vile cour≈øes of prophanene≈ø≈øe, filthine≈ø≈øe, drunkenne≈ø≈øe, fighting again≈øt the truth, and the like, mi≈ø-≈øpending their meanes, and lives, to oppo≈øe God, and to get, and goe to hell; by rightly imploying whereof, they might, with farre le≈ø≈øe trouble and adoe, happily do much good, and attaine to heaven and everla≈øting glory.

2. By doing things impertinent. Secondly, by doing that, which is little, or nothing to the purpo≈øe; for a mans true happine≈ø≈øe and comfort; as impertinent ≈øtudies, pur≈øuite of curio≈øity and vanity, hunting immoderately, and pro≈øecuting eagerly after the profits
and plea≈øures of this world; that before God will availe a man nothing for his ≈øalvation, and eternall, or ≈øpirituall comfort; when the things whereupon the ≈øame depends have beene neglected: for as the Apo≈øtle ≈øayes, bodily exerci≈øe profiteth little; but godline≈ø≈øe is profitable to all things 1 Tim. 4.8..

3. By idlene≈ø≈øe. Thirdly, men do often mi≈ø-≈øpend their lives, by wa≈øting it in ≈øluggi≈øh idlene≈ø≈øe; when they minde and indeavour nothing ≈øo much as how they may ≈øleepe at ea≈øe, or pa≈ø≈øe away their time in ≈øloath, or ≈øotti≈øhne≈ø≈øe; ≈øo driving their dayes and lives to an end in doing nothing, although none have more to do than they: while others complaine of want of time in their imployments, about their commendable affaires; the≈øe object, that they have more time than they know what to doe with. Such are, iners & inutile pondus, an unprofitable burthen, and the excrements of the Church and Commonwealth; dead while they live, and, as hoggs, more profitable by their deaths than by their lives: like ciphers, they keepe a place, but are of no value or worth: they go out of the world, before they regard why they came into the world; when they are pre≈øent, they are unprofitable, and when they are gone, they are not mi≈ø≈øed, for any good they ever did.

Cau≈øes of idlene≈ø≈øe. The cau≈øes of which idle cour≈øe of life, are, affectation of their owne bodily and worldly ea≈øe, contenting the fle≈øh with doing of nothing; and care onely to avoid trouble, which attends upon active and indu≈øtrious godly imployment: but wee finde the ≈øentence of condemnation pa≈ø≈øed no le≈ø≈øe again≈øt tho≈øe that omitted to doe their duties Mat. 25.43.; than again≈øt them who committed that evill which was forbidden. Wilfull defects and omi≈ø≈øions of doing good bring damnation. He that wanted his wedding garment was thru≈øt out of doores, and ca≈øt into utter darkene≈ø≈øe Mat. 22.13.

Why was Meroz cur≈øed? becau≈øe they came not out to the helpe of the Lord again≈øt the mighty, Iudg. 5.23. An
idle and ≈ølothfull ≈øpending of a manlife, is every where in Scripture condemned; and by nature the Bees expell the Droanes.

4. By over-charging ones ≈øelfe in doing good. There is another way of mi≈ø-≈øpending a mans life, proceeding from good affection, in a pious manner; by his over-tasking, or overcharging him≈øelfe, in religious performances, or good duties, above his ≈øtrength: as in fa≈øting and prayer, in ≈øtudies and labours in the Word, Neque immoderata imperamus jejunia. Hieron. ad Demetriadem. and the like: whereby a mans life is ≈øoone ≈øpent; like a ≈øudden blaze con≈øumed in a pre≈øent flame; which, by more frugall ordering of it, according to his ability, might la≈øt much longer, to the greater benefit both of Church and Commonwealth: and thus I have done with the di≈øcour≈øe of mans naturall life.

div.head: CHAP. 5. Of mans ≈øpirituall life.
¬ß. 1. What ≈øpirituall life is.
div.p: Spirituall life what. WEe are now to con≈øider of mans ≈øpirituall life; which is not properly the life of his ≈øpirit, whereby the ≈øpirits of all men doe live: but, it is the life of a man, whereby he, per≈øonally con≈øidered, lives a ≈øpirituall, and ≈øupernaturall life.

Which con≈øi≈øts in the gratious union of man with God in Chri≈øt; who is our life
Ioh 14.6.: whom God ≈øent into the world, that we might live through him, 1 Ioh. 4.9. by whom we are delivered from death by his ≈øpirit; becau≈øe of the ≈øpiritualne≈ø≈øe of this our life, it is ≈øaid to be hid with God in Chri≈øt, Col. 3.3.

div.head: ¬ß. 2. The acts of ≈øpirituall life.Acts of it.
div.p:
1. Of this ≈øpirituall life there are two acts: Fir≈øt, that
whereby we, that were dead in tre≈øpa≈ø≈øes and ≈øinnes, are quickned. Ephe≈ø. 2.1. being tran≈ølated into a ≈øtate of ≈øpirituall and eternall life; and indowed with a new lively principle of grace; inabling us to ≈øpirituall motion.

2. The ≈øecond act of this life is, that, whereby we walke, and worke, according to the direction of Gods word; and the good motions of the good ≈øpirit: ≈øo being made conformable to God, and walking with God, as new creatures, in the e≈øtate of regeneration.

div.head: ¬ß. 3. The degrees of ≈øpirituall life.
div.p:
Degrees of it. Of this life there are two degrees: 1. Fir≈øt, that which is by faith, in the ≈øtate of grace in this world, as our Saviour tells us, that hee that beleeveth on him hath eternall life, Ioh. 6.47. by this life we are to live according to God in the ≈øpirit, 1 Pet. 4.6. and al≈øo, if wee live in the ≈øpirit, wee are al≈øo to walke in the ≈øpirit
Gal 5.25.. Faith and good workes, as the cau≈øe and effects, are alwaies together, Iam. 2.20.

The ≈øecond degree of our ≈øpirituall life, is that which is by vi≈øion or ≈øight, in glorie: whereof Saint Iohn tells us, that we ≈øhall be like to Chri≈øt, for we ≈øhall ≈øee him as he is, 1 Ioh. 3.2. and touching tho≈øe things wherein it con≈øi≈øts, Saint Paul ≈øaies, that eye hath not ≈øeene, nor eare heard, neither have entred into the heart of man, the things which God hath prepared for them that love him 1 Cor. 2.9.. And he him≈øelfe, having beene rapt up into the third heaven, confe≈ø≈øeth that there he heard un≈øpeakable words
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ
; which was not lawfull for him to utter2 Cor. 12.4., in regard of impo≈ø≈øibility; there being want of words to expre≈ø≈øe ≈øuch ≈øupernaturall matter, and his conceiving being le≈ø≈øe than could comprehend what was repre≈øented to him. This ≈øpirituall life, in the e≈øtate of grace in this world, is apprehended, fir≈øt, in the under≈øtanding, Heb. 11.1. but in the ≈øtate of glory in heaven, it is vi≈øibly injoyed, by way of a ≈øpirituall ≈øen≈øiblene≈ø≈øe. Note. In the former ≈øtate, life is put into
us; but in this latter ≈øtate, wee ≈øhall be put into life; filled with it, within us; and fully compa≈ø≈øed about with it, without us; as ve≈ø≈øels ca≈øt into the ≈øea are filled with water within and without: ≈øo being comprehended by it, as well as it is comprehended by us according to our modell and capacity.
This life is one. Although the≈øe degrees of ≈øpirituall life bee ≈øeverall; yet the life it ≈øelfe is but one, whereupon the≈øe ≈øub≈øi≈øt.

This life is begunne here in the ≈øtate of grace by faith in Chri≈øt, and is con≈øummate, and fully accompli≈øhed by vi≈øion, or ≈øen≈øible fruition, in the ≈øtate of glory in heaven, according to our hope, & Gods promi≈øes to us; although at death faith doth cea≈øe, yet the ≈øpirituall life, thereby wrought in us, is not extingui≈øhed; for, or by the introduction of the life of glory; but the manner onely is altered, and degree of ≈øpirituall living intended to perfection.

The degrees ≈øubordinate. A mans ≈øeverall and graduall kinds of lives do ≈øtand in ≈øubordination one to another thus, to the life of glory in heaven with the Lord, none can attaine, but tho≈øe that fir≈øt live by faith in Chri≈øt, in the ≈øtate of grace; in manner conformable to Gods word and will: neither can any attaine to the life of grace, but tho≈øe that fir≈øt live the naturall life; which is the materiall, or pa≈ø≈øive foundation of the other twaine: for this naturall life gives beeing to a man; the other two doe adde perfection and happine≈ø≈øe to him: ≈øo that if the fir≈øt be a ble≈ø≈øing, much more are the other lives ble≈ø≈øings, and highly to be e≈øteemed.

The≈øe three degrees, or kinds of life are like to the three roomes of the Temple, where all entrance into the mo≈øt Holy place was made by the Holy place; and into this by the outward Court; ≈øo, none could come into the third, but by the ≈øecond, and none could come into the ≈øecond, but by the fir≈øt: whereby it appeares, that naturall life brings man under a po≈ø≈øibility and capacitie of the life of grace and glory; and the life of grace brings us, that
certainely have it, into faire a≈ø≈øurance of attaining the life of glory; for that they are ≈øpecifically the ≈øame, but gradually different: as the twilight, and perfect light at noone.

div.head: ¬ß. 4. Who may have ≈øpirituall life, and by who≈øe fault doe any mi≈ø≈øe of it.
div.p: Denyed to none. Although all men, that doe live the naturall life, attaine not to the ≈øpirituall; yet ≈øpirituall life is denyed expre≈øly to no man, if they will carefully u≈øe the meanes, and truly indeavour to have it: for, who≈øoever mi≈øcarries and mi≈ø≈øeth of this ≈øpiritual life, he him≈øelfe is guilty, and cau≈øe thereof:Lo≈øt by our owne fault. for, God hath given ≈øufficient meanes of ≈øalvation, and made a generall offer thereof to all men: as Io≈øhua did call Heaven and earth to record that day, that he had ≈øet before the people life and death, and ≈øo did put them to their choi≈øe, Io≈øhua 24.14. if with Mary wee choo≈øe the better part, wee are happy: it were better for us that wee had never lived at all, than that wee ≈øhould not live this ≈øpirituall life; without which we are dead while we live1 Tim. 5.6..

None can be excu≈øed, by preten≈øe of want of particular in≈øinuation of the Go≈øpell; (that is) the power of God to ≈øalvation, to every individuall man; or, becau≈øe it is not naturally ingrafted in every mans heart, as is the morall Law, in the generall principles, and matter unformed thereof; though not as it is perfectly formed, in every particular precept. For the Go≈øpell is not contrary to the Law; but the Law, both morall and ceremoniall, is our Schoolema≈øter to drive and direct us to Chri≈øt for ≈øalvation Gal. 3.21.24. ; and that for the ≈øame we ≈øhould neither re≈øt upon our ≈øelves, nor upon the Law.The Go≈øpell to al publi≈øhed.

1. To Adam.
Againe, when God him≈øelfe, at the beginning, fir≈øt after the fall, preached and delivered the go≈øpell to Adam and Eve
Gen. 3.15., he did publi≈øh and give the ≈øame to every particular
man and woman, then in them, that ever ≈øhould be borne into the world; to whom their parents were bound ≈øucce≈ø≈øively to preach and deliver the Go≈øpell, by a continued tradition. Note. If any of their children ≈øhould have died before they were capable of ≈øalvation by that mean; then (as it is mo≈øt probable) they were to be ≈øaved, as dying infants of beleeving parents now are.

2. To his po≈øterity. Furthermore, ever ≈øince the fir≈øt promulgation of the go≈øpell to Adam, it hath plea≈øed God to repeat, and more and more fully to explicate the ≈øame by his ≈øervants, with invitation of all men to entertaine the ≈øame, from age to age, in ≈øuch places and companies, where all men might take notice thereof, if they were not wanting to them≈øelves, in adjoyning them≈øelves to, and keeping union with the Church; where they might be within the hearing of the Go≈øpell; which is ≈øufficient to leave men inexcu≈øable, in their ignorance of it: Although God by his providence and prerogative Royall, directs, di≈øpen≈øes, and applyes the Go≈øpell, in the mini≈øtrie of it, to ≈øome people, and not to others; according to the good plea≈øure of his will, after the fir≈øt promulgation: as wee ≈øee how the publication of Lawes and proclamations of Princes, (which are as little written in their ≈øubjects hearts as the go≈øpell is in mankind)Compari≈øon. being publi≈øhed in manner, and in places, as Princes plea≈øe, whereby, and whence their ≈øubjects are to take notice of them; ignorance of the ≈øame excu≈øes not, but that the di≈øobedient and tran≈øgre≈ø≈øors of them may ju≈øtly be puni≈øhed; notwith≈øtanding that they never knew them: ≈øeeing every man is at his owne perill to looke after, and take notice of tho≈øe Lawes, or ordinances, whereby he is to live; whether they proceed from inbred naturall notions, or outwardly from the will of his Superiours.

div.head: ¬ß. 5. Of the excellency of ≈øpirituall life.
div.p: Spirituall lifes excellencie Mans ≈øpirituall life far excells his naturall life; in three re≈øpects e≈øpecially.

1. For nature. Fir≈øt, in regard of the things where in it con≈øi≈øts: the naturall life con≈øi≈øts but in the union of ≈øoule and body which are but naturall things; and holds by a tie of naturall ≈øpirits in the blood; upheld by earthly naturall meanes, ≈øuch as man is made and compounded of.

Spirituall life, which is now ≈øupernaturall, con≈øi≈øts in a ≈øpirituall union with God, by his eternall Sonne and Spirit; and is upheld by ≈øupernaturall meanes, and divine influence, whereby we live the life of God; and al≈øo by God, and to God
Rom. 14.8. and ≈øo, as the life of naturall or rea≈øo≈øonable men, 2 Cor. 5.15.1 Pet. 4.2. farre excells the lives of brutes; ≈øo doth this ≈øpirituall life of Gods regenerated people, farre ≈øurpa≈ø≈øe the lives of meere naturall and unregenerated men: and therefore it is, that men are farre more beholding to the meanes and in≈øtruments of their ≈øpirituall life, than to the meanes of their naturall; for, naturall life without ≈øpirituall, makes a man but ≈øubject to mi≈øery; whereas the ≈øpirituall life, upon the naturall, makes a man everla≈øtingly happy: which ≈øhould quicken in us a de≈øire, and endeavour to be borne againe, according to our Saviours ≈øpeech, Ioh. 3.3.

2 For continuance. Secondly, the ≈øpirituall life farre tran≈øcends the naturall, in re≈øpect of its continuance: the naturall life, depending upon mutable and mortall ties and bonds, and ≈øubject to many externall harmfull accidents; is fraile, and, at la≈øt is ≈øwallowed up of mortality; it being appointed for all men once to die, Heb. 9.27. and few and evill are our dayes in this world; wherein wee have no abiding city, the ≈øpirituall life is eternall, without ≈øubjection to death; becau≈øe, it is in it ≈øelfe ≈øupernaturall, and advanced above the reach and power of all things that can de≈øtroy life,
and is pre≈øerved and upheld by ≈øuch a fountaine of indeficient and omnipotent life, and undecaying lively vigour, and meanes of divine living, that never ≈øuffers the man, that hath and keeps communion with the ≈øame, to be ≈øubject to death: but makes him pa≈ø≈øe from death to life, Iohn 5.24. the faith whereof doth free a man from the feare of lo≈øing that happy e≈øtate, (while he continues to love it,) whereas others, in a lo≈øeable and mutable e≈øtate of life, are, (by feare of being deprived thereof, and being without hope of a better,) hindered in injoying the full comfort of the pre≈øent good, that here is afforded.

3. For effects. Thirdly, ≈øpirituall life ≈øurpa≈ø≈øes the naturall, in its effects: the naturall life enables a man to the doing onely of naturall actions, ≈øpecially concerning mans naturall good; agreeable unto, and flowing from naturall principles in man; being, in the meane time, dead to any divine, or ≈øupernaturall good: neither actively doing that of goodne≈ø≈øe, which is truely morall or divine; nor pa≈ø≈øively receiving and enjoying that thereof which is beatificall, or which makes man ble≈ø≈øed: and ≈øo he may, for all that life, the powers and actions thereof, be mi≈øerable and peri≈øh; for, fle≈øh and blood cannot inherit the Kingdome of God, 1 Cor. 15.50.

The ≈øpirituall life, by ≈øo neere conjunction of a man with the fountaine of life E≈ø≈øentiall, the well-≈øpring of infinite goodne≈ø≈øe, not onely, by that touch and union, doth it make him ≈øo live, but al≈øo it cau≈øeth him to be mo≈øt happy, both by making him able Actively to live the life of God
Gal. 2.19., and to live to the will of God, 1 Pet. 4.2. and al≈øo by endowing him with pa≈ø≈øive capacity, and with reall po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of all ≈øuch beatificall perfections as are nece≈ø≈øary for his advancement to, and in a glorious e≈øtate; farre above all other earthly creatures, in this world and in the world to come: whereby he becomes ≈øo happy, that nothing can make him mi≈øerable, but even
in tribulation he hath cau≈øe of rejoycing, Rom. 5.3. and when he dyes, yet ≈øtill he lives, in more excellent manner, as Paul ≈øaid touching his afflictions, as dying, and behold we live, 2 Cor. 6.9.

In regard of the afore≈øaid excellency of this ≈øpirituall life above the naturall, it was that our Saviour did command his Di≈øciples, not to feare them that kill the body, but are not able to kill the ≈øoule: but rather to feare him, which is able to de≈øtroy both ≈øoule and body in hell. Mat. 10.28.

div.head: ¬ß. 6. How to obtaine ≈øpirituall life.
div.p: V≈øe 1. To get ≈øpirituall life. From the former doctrine, touching the excellency of this ≈øpirituall life of man, diver≈øe very nece≈ø≈øary u≈øes are ob≈øervable. Fir≈øt, it may provoke and ≈øtirre us up to get this life, above all things in this world: whereof we are borne de≈øtitute, yea dead in ≈øin; to which life, by our manifold actuall tran≈øgre≈ø≈øions wee doe indi≈øpo≈øe and unfit our ≈øelves: but yet the Lord of his mercy hath appointed us a way, whereby we may get this ≈øpirituall life: ≈øo that, by our con≈øcionable u≈øe of the meanes appointed by God, By meanes. wee may attaine thereunto, in regard of his promi≈øe, and faithfulne≈ø≈øe, that tho≈øe that ≈øeeke ≈øhall finde. Amos 5.6.

And why to be u≈øed. The≈øe meanes are wee to u≈øe, in regard both of Gods commandement, who thereby tries our obedience and faith: and al≈øo in re≈øpect of the di≈øpen≈øation of God; who gives his graces onely by, and in his owne way, which otherwi≈øe cannot be had. Al≈øo the worth and nece≈ø≈øity of this ≈øpirituall life is ≈øuch, as de≈øerves our be≈øt endeavours to get it: our e≈øteeme whereof is ≈øeene by our labours for it, in Gods appointed way, without which, God will not give it; becau≈øe, hee will have us active, about our owne ≈øalvation; that the ≈øame may co≈øt us the price of our labours, to come by it; that thereby we may
the more comfortably know that we have it; when we know how we came by it: that wee may be the more carefull to keepe, what wee have ≈øo laboriou≈øly purcha≈øed; and may a≈ø≈øuredly looke for the reward of our labours; which God, that cannot lie, hath promi≈øed to tho≈øe that ≈øeeke life by his appointed meanes.

To u≈øe no meanes to get this ≈øpirituall life, is to contemne both it, and God: and to indeavour to get it, by u≈øing other meanes than God hath appointed for that end, is to tempt God, or to pre≈øcribe him his waies of di≈øpen≈øing his grace, and to preferre our owne wits and wills above Gods; whereby ≈øuch men lo≈øe both their labour and expectation.

Which they be. 1. The word of God. The meanes in particular, to get this ≈øpirituall life, are; Fir≈øt, the word of God, ≈øpecially the Go≈øpell; which is as the materiall and ≈øeminall cau≈øe of it, 1 Pet. 1.23.
2. Application. Secondly, the meanes vegetating and applying the Go≈øpell to quicken us: which is fourefold.

1. By the mini≈øtry. Fir≈øt, the mini≈øtrie of the word; by reading, and preaching of it, to the enlightning of the under≈øtanding, and to the moving of the affections and hearts of the hearers, to embrace it; for, Faith comes by hearing, Rom 10.17.

2. Chri≈øtian conference. Secondly, the Company and conferences of tho≈øe Chri≈øtians, that in this kind of life, are (by their motion, and example) lively, and vigorous; able, by their warmth and liveline≈ø≈øe, to heat and quicken tho≈øe whom they touch: as Eli≈øha, by his application of him≈øelfe to the dead child, made it warme and alive, 2 King. 4.34. and as leaven leavens the lump; and every thing affects to procreate its like.

3. Prayer. The third meanes of the Go≈øpells application to quicken us, is ≈øervent and effectuall prayer to God, from whom is all the vertue and efficacy of it, that he would make it effectuall to us: for although Paul do plant, and Apollo water, it is God that gives the increa≈øe, 1 Cor. 3.6.

4. Sacraments, & the ≈øpirits operation in them. Fourthly, the Sacraments, and in them the powerfull
operation of the ≈øpirit of Chri≈øt, is that which quickens us when wee are ca≈øt into the frame and mould of the Go≈øpell; untill Chri≈øt be formed in us Gal. 4.19.: ≈øo that in this worke the ≈øpirit is the principall efficient cau≈øe: as our Saviour tells us, Iohn 6.63. it is the ≈øpirit that quickneth.

div.head: ¬ß. 7. How the Go≈øpell workes life.
div.p: 1. Hovv the Go≈øpell workes not. So then, the Go≈øpell works not this life in us, in a Phy≈øicall or naturall manner; as having vertue naturally inherent in the words, to produce ≈øuch an effect in tho≈øe that heare it.1.Not phy≈øically For then, men ≈øhould be converted and regenerated in a naturall, and not in a divine manner: and al≈øo, then the Go≈øpell would worke alike upon all men that heare it, that were alike di≈øpo≈øed, and did not ponere obicem, or lay a barre of their owne to hinder it; except God ≈øhould re≈øtraine the naturall power of it in working: but ≈øo, the conver≈øion of man mu≈øt be within the power of his owne act; and God could not be ju≈øtified in his withholding grace.

The word is a ≈øupernturall in≈øtrument of ≈øalvation. But, the conver≈øion of a ≈øinner is wrought by a greater vertue, than can naturally and ≈øubjectively be in the words and ≈øentences of the Go≈øpell: for, the word of God is not in≈øtrumentum phy≈øicum, a naturall in≈øtrument, but a morall, or rather metaphy≈øicall in≈øtrument of effecting ≈øuch a ≈øupernaturall worke; according to the will of the fir≈øt agent.

2. Not Ethically. Neither in an Ethicall manner, doth the Go≈øpell worke this ≈øpirituall life in us; onely by morall per≈øwa≈øion; as morall Philo≈øophers, and Rhetoricians doe affect and draw their hearers; by rea≈øons, and exhortations ≈øtirring up a latent power inherent in us, and inclining our wills, by rationall motives and objects, to be made alive: then mu≈øt it depend upon us, that wee are ≈øaved; and be from a power of our owne, exu≈øcitated by the word.2. How God works by the Go≈øpell according to his own will. But God works by his word, as a more pui≈ø≈øant
and independent agent; that inintends and remits his power in working, according to his owne will, by the meanes; and u≈øes meanes not as nece≈ø≈øary for him; but that he can doe as much without them: in regard that the effect is his owne, and man the pa≈ø≈øive ≈øubject of it.

Mans will is the ≈øubject of conver≈øion. It is the will of a naturall man that is mo≈øt dead to God-ward, and mo≈øt aver≈øe from him; and therefore, it is the will that is chiefly to be wrought upon and made alive in conver≈øion, whereupon all depends; but, wee know that nothing can make it ≈øelfe alive, when it is dead, but he that is the fountaine of life; the Son of God, Rom 1.4.

Note. Of the heart. The illumination of the under≈øtanding, which is common to the wicked and the godly, is pre≈øuppo≈øed as requi≈øite to fit a man for conver≈øion: and therefore, in the worke of regeneration, the ≈øcripture takes notice ≈øpecially of the heart, in≈øomuch that the old Te≈øtament u≈øes no other word to expre≈ø≈øe the under≈øtanding; becau≈øe, in Divinity no knowledge without intertainement in the heart, and without conformity of the will and practi≈øe to the truth, is ≈øaving; action being the end of Theological knowledge in this life; words of knowledge in Scripture commonly comprehend affections in them.

div.head: ¬ß. 8. Why God u≈øes meanes.
div.p:
Although that God could, if he plea≈øed, convey grace into a ≈øinfull man, by immediate influxe, or in≈øpiration; from which wee cannot utterly exclude all; ≈øeeing, the worke of grace depends ab≈øolutely neither upon the nature of the meanes, nor upon the abilities and will of the converted and elected, whereof many are not, by that method of meanes, capable; but upon God, who workes according to the good plea≈øure of his will: yet he u≈øes meanes; not to help him≈øelfe, as if otherwi≈øe he could not doe the worke; but in re≈øpect of us, that are naturall men,
indowed with ≈øen≈øes as well as rea≈øon, hee appoints meanes, Rea≈øons of u≈øing of means. 1. that by our u≈øing thereof, we may be active about the worke of our owne ≈øalvation; and may attaine the ≈øame by a way and cour≈øe within the compa≈ø≈øe of our owne power and indeavours, as the reward and ble≈ø≈øing of God upon our labours, to our commendation before God and men. 2. Againe, meanes are appointed by God for our obtaining of ≈øalvation, that by u≈øing of them, our ≈øaith in Gods promi≈øes and power may be tried, in expecting thereby ≈øo glorious effects, farre above their nature: and al≈øo, our obedience may be proved, by doing what God commands us to doe, within the reach of our power, to get life, albeit it doe tran≈øcend rea≈øon, how by this way it can be had: as appeares by Naaman the Syrian, 2 King. 5.13, 14. 3. And finally, God appoints the u≈øe of meanes for our comfort, that by our con≈øtant con≈øcionable u≈øing of the ≈øame, we may be a≈ø≈øured of grace and life, as certainly as we are of the u≈øe of the meanes appointed to get, and by which God hath promi≈øed to give it, by the working of his holy Spirit.

div.head: ¬ß. 9. How the Spirits power is manife≈øted and ≈øeene.
div.p: V≈øe. To finde the Spirits power by the meanes in us. Now further, from the con≈øideration of the excellency of this ≈øpirituall life to be wrought in us by meanes, our u≈øe ≈øhould be to end eavour to find and feele, both the Spirits quickning vertue of regeneration, by the meanes, powerfully working upon, and in us, and al≈øo, to di≈øcerne this ≈øpirituall life to be in our ≈øelves: ≈øeeing our comfort lyes herein, and that the one can never bee without the other.

Manife≈øt in 4. degrees of operation. The vertue of the Spirit in us by the meanes manife≈øts it ≈øelfe in foure degrees of operation: not to ≈øpeake of illumination. Fir≈øt, both in making us ≈øee and feele, with griefe of heart, our owne wretchedne≈ø≈øe and ≈øinfull deadne≈ø≈øe,
1. Again≈øt ≈øinne.and al≈øo by turning us from our ≈øins and ungodly cour≈øes, with dete≈øtation of them and with re≈øolution and con≈øtant indeavours again≈øt them, it being the worke of the ≈øpirit to lu≈øt again≈øt the ≈øle≈øh; becau≈øe they are contrary the one to the otherGal 5.17. &c., both in nature and effects.

In which re≈øpect, the Prophet Ho≈øea tells us, that if we will live we mu≈øt turne, Ho≈øea 6.1. for, our ≈øinfull cour≈øes are the waies of death: therefore, we ≈øhould labour to be, and find our ≈øelves mortified to ≈øinne, with ≈øome kinde not onely of voluntary indi≈øpo≈øition, but al≈øo of ≈øtrong antipathie, and dete≈øtation of committing the ≈øame; as formerly wee were prone, and affected with delight to doe; and that at the pre≈øence of ≈øinne, in its habit, or act, we may with indignation be di≈øplea≈øed and ≈øad; having no joy nor contentment in that condition. For, the motions of ≈øin entertained, do worke in our members, to bring forth fruit unto death
Rom. 7.5..
Which by a contrary life of grace, are mortified and ≈øubdued: but, I confe≈ø≈øe that this degree followes after faith.
2.Begetting faith Secondly, the power of the ≈øpirit in us by the meanes, is ≈øeene, by the working of true ≈øaith in us; which the Apo≈øtle a≈øcribes to the ≈øame, 1 Cor. 12.9. Ephe≈ø. 2.8.

It is by this faith that wee do divinely and ≈øpiritually live Rom. 1.17. Halak. 2.4., in the act of beleeving, uniting our ≈øelves to the ≈øaving and lively object Chri≈øt Ie≈øus, with his gracious promi≈øes, by us adhered unto, and thereunto conforming our ≈øelves: without Chri≈øt we have no life in us: as him≈øelfe tells us, Ioh. 6.57. and without faith wee can neither have him nor his ble≈ø≈øed promi≈øes; but by ≈øaith we have them both; that ≈øo, by this ≈øpirituall in≈øtrument, ≈øpirituall ble≈ø≈øings may be ≈øpiritually enjoyed, whereof the ≈øoule is the immediate ≈øubject; and ≈øecondarily the body, onely by the ≈øoule; to this faith our Saviour attributes this ≈øpirituall life, when he ≈øayes That who≈øoever beleeveth in him, though he were dead, yet ≈øhall he live John 11.25.:
therefore, it neerely concernes us all, to labour to get true ≈øaving faith; and that we doe make u≈øe of the ≈øame, in and about its proper objects: And for our comfort, it behooves us to know that we have this faith: but, becau≈øe the ≈øignes how to di≈øcerne it, is the generall ≈øubject of mo≈øt men in their bookes and ≈øermons, I pa≈ø≈øe it over with reference to them.

3.Applying of Chri≈øt. Thirdly, the Spirit of God manife≈øts the power of it in us, by the meanes, in the application of Chri≈øt and his merits to us: whereby we become one with Chri≈øt, and being grafted into him, have the adoption of the ≈øonnes of God Ephe≈ø. 1.5. Rom. 8.16. ; and free ju≈øtification from all our ≈øins, ≈øealed up and a≈ø≈øured to us, by the ≈øame Spirit: whereupon, we may apprehend the ≈øweet favour of God toward us; wherein con≈øi≈øteth life, P≈øal. 30.5. and may be filled with a lively vigour of con≈øolation, in the apprehen≈øion of the pardon of our ≈øinnes, and upon the a≈ø≈øurance of the graces and ble≈ø≈øings of God to us, for our eternall happine≈ø≈øe, in which re≈øpect it is called the Spirit of Con≈øolation

div.head: ¬ß. 2. Of the meanes of lo≈øing life naturall.
