Or el≈øe, the externall meanes of taking away a mans life; doe of them≈øelves, in their proper nature, and direct u≈øe, and in the inten≈øion of the agent, tend to the effecting thereof: which (about our life that is naturall,) is done either ju≈øtly; upon lawfull cau≈øes; in ju≈øt manner;Ju≈øtly. by tho≈øe tho≈øe that are ≈øufficiently authorized to doe the ≈øame: or el≈øe, it is done unju≈øtly; when the ≈øame is without ju≈øt cau≈øe;Unju≈øtly. not by the hands of per≈øons lawfully authorized to doe it; or is not performed in a ju≈øt and warrantable manner.

div.head: ¬ß. 3. Of the meanes of the de≈øtruction of ≈øpirituall life.
div.p: 2. Of the ≈øoule. Al≈øo, touching our ≈øpirituall life, the ≈øame is externally, or by meanes, without a mans ≈øelfe, de≈øtroyed; eyther by the ju≈øtice of God;1. By God. when he mo≈øt righteou≈øly, in his act of vindicative and di≈øtributive ju≈øtice puni≈øhes man with eternall de≈øtruction, for his ≈øinnes, Mat. 10.28. in which ca≈øe man, in re≈øpect of his owne merits and de≈øervings, is guilty of his owne peri≈øhing, and not God.

2. By men, two waies. Or el≈øe, our ≈øpirituall life may mi≈øcarry by meanes of men;1. who Fir≈øt, by their corrupt doctrine, and evill examples doe draw others with them to perdition: as did the Scribes and Phari≈øees; that did compa≈ø≈øe ≈øea and land to make one Pro≈øelyte, whom when they had wonne, they
made him two≈øold more the child of hell than them≈øelves, Mat. 23.15. or, by depriving them of the meanes of their ≈øalvation; they are ≈øubjected to de≈øtruction. 2. Secondly, when men, by compul≈øory meanes of unju≈øt lawes, and ≈øevere threatnings and puni≈øhments, are driven and forced from the waies of righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe into ≈øinnefull cour≈øes; as by Ieroboam, Mana≈ø≈øes, &c. ≈øoules are de≈øtroied with a twofold guilt, both of them that force others; and al≈øo of them that yeeld them≈øelves to evill, upon ≈øuch con≈øtraint.

Life is taken avvay: 1 By others. 2. By a mans ≈øelfe. Againe, the externall meanes of depriving a man of his life is inflicted, either by others; ≈øometime lawfully, ≈øometimes unlawfull; or el≈øe, by a mans owne hands and procurement; which is ever, in all ca≈øes, unlawfull for him to doe, mediately, or immediately, directly, or indirectly. But, it is to be noted, that no man lo≈øeth his ≈øpirituall life, but by his owne meanes, and merits procuring the ≈øame: for the ≈øpirituall life of man is ≈øubject to no mans power; who can kill onely the body and doe no more, Mat. 10.28.
And God, that is e≈ø≈øeatially and ab≈øolutely ju≈øt, subjects not man to ≈øuffer that, which actively he hath not fir≈øt ≈øome way procured, by his owne doings and de≈øervings.

Ob≈øerv. How ≈øubject man is to death. From hence, it is ob≈øervable, that the lives of no creatures are longer, and with more adoe hatchedup, and maintained, than the lives of men; and yet, the lives of no creatures are ≈øubject to ≈øo many dangers, inward, and outward of de≈øtruction; and ≈øooner overthrowne, than mans; we being like brittle gla≈ø≈øes, that containe precious bal≈øame; and as choi≈øe flowers, hardly cheri≈øhed up, and ≈øoone bla≈øted: which ≈øhewes, both our weakene≈ø≈øe, and want of ≈øelf-≈øufficiency, to uphold our ≈øelves; and al≈øo, how we are po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed and compa≈ø≈øed about, with things adver≈øe and dangerous to our lives; both of ≈øoule and body: of all creatures man onely being a ≈øtranger and
pilgrim on earth, hath, therefore, the lea≈øt kinde entertainment in this world, and the mo≈øt uncertaine po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of it; and is alwaies neere≈øt to be thru≈øt out of it; walking here but as a ≈øhadow.
V≈øe 1 Therefore, wee ≈øhould be more carefull to cleave the more clo≈øely to our God, who is the pre≈øerver of men; that by him we may be upheld and protected again≈øt all dangers.

2. And againe, we ≈øhould be the more watchfull again≈øt carnall ≈øecurity; that wee doe not pre≈øume upon our uncertaine lives; nor ≈øuffer our ≈øelves to be intangled with this world and the things of it; but that we be ever heavenly minded, and ready for our departure hence; labouring to get, and keepe that ≈øpirituall and eternall life.

div.head: ¬ß. 4. Of murder in ≈øelf-killing.
div.p: Killing of a mans ≈øelfe is murder. 1. In a mans taking away of his owne life, two things are to be con≈øidered. Fir≈øt, that it is murder, in regard of the nature of the act of it.

2. Secondly, that it is murder of ones ≈øelfe, in re≈øpect of the object thereof: and ≈øo ≈øelf-murder is a compounded ≈øinne of more degrees than one, and that in ≈øuch a kind, as is the mo≈øt hainous and mo≈øt to be abhorred in humane ≈øociety, in regard that this de≈øtroyes the ≈øub≈øtantiall being of that which ought to bee of all worldly things mo≈øt deare to us; whereas other ≈øinnes, ≈øpoile the welbeing of our ≈øelves, or others; which, ≈øo long as life la≈øteth, is recoverable.

Self-murder is horrible. And therefore, what≈øoever is to be thought of the vile quality, and of the damnable de≈øerts of murder in generall, is to be conceived to be due, and much wor≈øe, to ≈øelf-murder in ≈øpeciall. For, murder is but the genericall or generall matter, and not the ≈øpeciall and formall nature of Self-murder: and therefore, if it be horrible to murder another man, it is much more odious to kill ones
≈øelfe. For, by naturall rea≈øon, the more that any Genus, or generall matter, is re≈øtrained, and actuated, by its ≈øuperadded formes and ≈øpecificall differences, the more it is intended, active and powerfull; according to the motion of nature, ab imperfectioribus ad perfectiora, proceeding toward that perfection, wherein it intends to termine and end. Now, the perfection of a vice (if I may ≈øo ≈øpeake) con≈øi≈øts in the highe≈øt exorbitancie of it, beyond which none can pa≈ø≈øe, and in murder, it is certaine that none can goe beyond ≈øelf-murder, as afterward will fully appeare.
4. Things are ob≈øervable in murder. In taking away, ≈øpecially, a mans naturall life unju≈øtly and murderou≈øly, foure things are to be con≈øidered.
1. That death is unde≈øerved. Fir≈øt, that the effect done, or death of a man, in depriving him of his life, is without due de≈øert on his part, at their hands that put him to death.

2. Done without lavvfull authority. Secondly, that the act it ≈øelfe, whereby that effect is accompli≈øhed, is unlawfull, on his part that doth it, in regard of his want of authority, and ju≈øt calling to do that act: and if the ≈øufferer have de≈øerved death, and the executioner have a lawfull calling to kill him; yet, if his manner of doing of it bee contrary to the pre≈øcript and rules of his calling; and to the minde and di≈øpo≈øition requi≈øite for ≈øuch an agent in that act; then the ≈øame is murder.

3. Done wittingly. Thirdly, it is con≈øiderable in murder, that the agent therein both knowes, not onely that the nature of his action that he doth, tendeth to death; but al≈øo that morally it is an unlawfull act, or thing to be done: and al≈øo doth voluntarily and wittingly intend the doing of that action, without regard of the effect, or in≈øuing of death thereupon.

4. Death intended. Fourthly, touching murder, it is remarkeable that the agent doe not onely voluntarily and wittingly a lethiferous or mortall act; but that he doe al≈øo intend, and de≈øire to effect the death of a man thereby; whom ju≈øtly he cannot kill: otherwi≈øe, if a man ≈øhould ignorantly, or unwillingly,
in doing of his lawfull calling, be a meanes accidentally to take away the life of a man, he is not therefore guilty of murder. For, for ≈øuch God provided Cities of refuge, for their pre≈øervation, again≈øt the avenger of blood. Deut. 19.3, 4, 5. Io≈øbua 20.3. by the fir≈øt of the≈øe wee ≈øee, that an innocent ≈øuffers death; by the ≈øecond wee ≈øee, that the Agent or executioner is ≈øuch an one as ought not to kill him, although he were nocent: by the third and fourth it appeare, that the act is formaliter murderous, in regard of the knowledge, and intention of the doer thereof.

Self-murder is mo≈øt vile murder, in tran≈øcendent manner. So, in Self-murder, as it is murder, an Innocent, (never de≈øerving of him≈øelfe that him≈øelfe ≈øhould kill him≈øelfe,) is ≈ølaine: the Actor whereof hath no authority, nor calling over him≈øelfe ≈øo to doe: ≈øeeing, no man can be both ≈øuperiour and al≈øo inferiour to him≈øelfe: and for a man to doe an act upon him≈øelfe, which he knowes to be both mortall, and unlawfull; and yet will doe it, with purpo≈øe and intent to bereave him≈øelfe of his own life, it cannot be denyed to be murder in the highe≈øt degree, and he a murderer that doth it.

div.head: ¬ß. 5. How murder is vile.
div.p:
The vilene≈ø≈øe of murder in its effects. The vilene≈ø≈øe of murder is not onely ≈øeene, by its contrariety to Gods Law, and the heavie cen≈øures and puni≈øhments thereof, and its incompatibility with humane ≈øociety; but al≈øo, by the effects thereof upon the ≈øufferer. 1.It de≈øtroves naturall life. For, fir≈øt the act of murder utterly ≈øo de≈øtroyes the naturall life of man, upon the departure of his ≈øoule from the body; that the ≈øame is never againe recovered. For, naturall life depends, not onely upon the pre≈øence of the ≈øoule informing the body; but even upon our ≈øtate of being in this world; in≈øomuch that after the re≈øurrection, although ≈øoule and body ≈øhall be againe united; yet, as then our bodies ≈øhall be ≈øpirituall bodies1 Cor. 15 44.; ≈øo ≈øhall
our lives be. So then, a murderer takes that life away, which he can never give, nor re≈øtore; and de≈øtroyes that which he can never build up.

2. It de≈øtroyes mans per≈øen. Secondly, the act of murder de≈øtroyes the per≈øon of man; which depends upon mans life. For, neither is the ≈øoule alone, nor the body alone the per≈øon of man; but the whole man con≈øi≈øting of ≈øoule and body with their properties hypo≈øtatically united. So that, when the ≈øoule is in heaven, he cannot ≈øay, but Synechdochically, that the per≈øon is in heaven Nor, when the body is in the grave, can we properly ≈øay, that the per≈øon is in the grave. For, then, either a man mu≈øt be two per≈øons one in heaven, and another in the grave, which is ab≈øurd: or el≈øe one created per≈øon ≈øhould be in diver≈øe places at once; which is impo≈ø≈øible.

Ob≈øerve vvhere the per≈øon is after death. If you ≈øay, where then is the per≈øon after death? I an≈øwer, it is not in actuall being, but potentiall in its con≈øtitutive principles of ≈øoule and body; that are to be joyned together, at the day of judgment. And therefore it is, that the ≈øoules ≈øeparate from the bodies thinke not, nor worke in that manner as they did organically in the body: whereupon the P≈øalmi≈øt ≈øaies of Princes, that when they die their thoughts peri≈øh
P≈øal. 146.4.: and therefore, neither remember they, in that e≈øtate, things pa≈øt; nor are capable of pre≈øent, under tho≈øe ≈øpecies and notions, as they did here in the body. So then, he that murders a man, de≈øtroies a per≈øon; although his di≈øtinct natures doe remaine.

Thirdly, a murderer is injurious to God, not onely in breaking his Law, but al≈øo in de≈øtroying his Image; which is not properly in the body, or in the ≈øoule apart; but in the whole per≈øon of man, con≈øi≈øting of both ≈øoule and body, with their properties per≈øonally united: man was created in Gods Image: now, the ≈øoule alone, or body alone is not the man, but both united, as is ≈øaid: ≈øo it is apparent, that wrong is done to heaven and earth, by a murderer.

div.head: ¬ß. 6. Of the originall of murder.
div.p:
Murder whenee. 1. From our ≈øelves.We are to con≈øider, whence it comes that man doth mon≈øtrou≈øly, Fir≈øt, fall upon his owne kinde, to de≈øtroy it; and then upon him≈øelfe. Of murder in generall, mans wicked heart and the devill are the parents: for, the inward principle of motion to that vile ≈øinne; and al≈øo, the pa≈ø≈øive ≈øubject entertaining the ≈øame, is mans owne wicked di≈øpo≈øition inclining him, (by inbred hatred,) to that horrible mi≈øchiefe. For out of the heart proceeds murder
Mat. 15.19., ≈øaies our Saviour Chri≈øt: which is a ju≈øt recompence from God; that man, for his rebellion and di≈øobedience again≈øt God, ≈øhould be given over, in revenge of Gods quarrell, to de≈øtroy with his owne hands his owne kinde, and ≈øelfe. So that, he that will not agree with God and love him, cannot agree with, nor love him≈øelfe, nor his neighbour.

Satan is the principall and active parent of murder; who was a murderer from the beginning; and now is ≈øtill, in ≈øpite again≈øt God and man, a provoker and ≈øtirrer up of man to murder; affording him occa≈øions and opportunities to doe the deed; to the ≈øtaining of the honor of God, and defacing of mankinde; and therefore, murderers are mo≈øt e≈øpecially the children of the devill
Iob. 8.44.; and obedient to him, both in di≈øpo≈øition and practi≈øe: they that wilfully doe the greater ≈øin, do babitually and di≈øpo≈øitively not ≈øtick at the le≈ø≈øer; ≈øeeing that the le≈ø≈øer are ever, in ≈øome ≈øort, comprehended in the greater.

It was an act of impotency. This effect, in mans taking away the life of man, ≈øhewes that mans ability lyes ≈øpecially in ≈øpoyling and de≈øtroying of Gods handiworks; and argues rather impotency than power in him; where there is no ≈øtronger power of pre≈øervation, oppo≈øing of him. For, the proper effect of power is entity, or being; and non-entity or not being is the effect of weakene≈ø≈øe. We ≈øee that, although
a man can kill, yet he cannot re≈øtore againe to life; becau≈øe, it is God onely that hath power over the ≈øpirit, and that kills and makes alive againe.

V≈øe To bevvare of murder. And therefore, all men ≈øhould be carefull how they take away the life of any man. For, although by repentance they may make their owne peace with God, for their murder; yet they can never re≈øtore the lo≈ø≈øe, or damage: none can call back the ≈øpirit, but the Father of ≈øpirits, to aenimate a dead body: neither hath any man ab≈øolute power over the creatures, to do with them as he li≈øt, but as he is limited by Gods commi≈ø≈øion and will.

Ob≈øerv. To terrifie a man from killing him≈øelfe, he ought to con≈øider how he is limited and re≈øtrained, by his Soveraigne Lord God, from ra≈øhly attempting, or medling to hurt the lives of any men, Man is re≈øtrained from murder. whom he may not u≈øe, or di≈øpo≈øe of, according to his owne ≈øelf-will'd lu≈øt; but, according to the good will of God, who is the ≈øupreme and ab≈øolute Lord and ma≈øter of all mankinde, in ≈øpeciall manner. Al≈øo, he is to con≈øider the odion≈øne≈ø≈øe and puni≈øhment of ≈øimple murder, It is odious. in any man; and how loath he him≈øelfe would be to doe it, upon any other man: that ≈øo he may much more abhorre to doe it upon him≈øelfe: ≈øinnes are more di≈øcernable by us in others, than in our ≈øelves; as a vi≈øible object, clo≈øe upon the ≈øen≈øe of ≈øeeing, cannot bee ≈øeene ≈øo well, as at a greater fit di≈øtance: what wee doe ≈øee to be unlawfull and odious in others, others doe ≈øee to be no le≈ø≈øe, but rather more odious in us, if we excell them in place or per≈øonall parts; where there is no accident, or circum≈øtance that may extenuate the ≈øame.

A man cannot po≈ø≈øibly kill him≈øelfe, but that thereby he is, in the le≈ø≈øer degree of this ≈øinne, a murderer; in ≈øtate common with Barrabas and others, that murderou≈øly kill other men than them≈øelves: and thereby is lyable to the like dete≈øtation and puni≈øhment, but withall in a farre greater degree, for killing him≈øelfe.

Note. It is remarkeable, that no man can kill or murder
another, but withall he mu≈øt kill him≈øelfe, both ≈øoule and body.No man can murder another vvithout murdring of him≈øelfe. For, by his ≈øinne of murder he ≈øtabs his owne ≈øouls, and ≈øubjects it to the vengeance of God: And al≈øo thereby hee makes his per≈øon obnoxious to the ≈øtroke of ju≈øtice, by the hand either of God or man, to ≈øuffer death for that horrible ≈øinne: according to the threatnings and judgements of God; and the apprehen≈øion of the murderers owne con≈øcience; and the hatred wherewith all men doe pro≈øecute ≈øuch dete≈øtable per≈øons, as enemies of mankind, and of humane ≈øociety Gen. 9.5. Deut 19.12, 13. Gen. 4.14..

div.head: CHAP. 7. Of murder, as it is of ones ≈øelfe.
¬ß. 1. Of the ≈øpecificall difference of ≈øelf-murder.
div.p: BE≈øides the con≈øideration of murder, in a mans killing of him≈øelfe, the third point in the generall de≈øcription of ≈øelf-murder is the efficient cau≈øe, or meanes of it; and that is a mans owne ≈øelfe, by his owne precurement; who is al≈øo the immediate object of that vile fact; whereof now I am to ≈øpeake.

Self-murders ≈øpecificall difference. Here is now the ≈øpecificall difference of this ≈øort of murder, wherby it tran≈øcends, and is di≈øtingui≈øhed from all other murders; and con≈øi≈øts in re≈øtraint of the act of killing, in regard of its individual object, to a mans own life & ≈øelf; which is the greate≈øt and cruelle≈øt act of ho≈øtility in the world: when a man, who by nature is mo≈øt bound to pre≈øerve him≈øelf, reflects upon him≈øelfe, to de≈øtroy him≈øelfe; the horriblenes whereof is ≈øo mon≈øtrous, that we read no Law made again≈øt it, as if it were a thing not to bee ≈øuppo≈øed po≈ø≈øible. And this ≈øinne of all others is mo≈øt again≈øt the Law of nature, for that ≈øelf-pre≈øervation, armes a man to turne upon others, unlawfully invading him to

And al≈øo, it is again≈øt that ≈øelf-love, which is the rule of our love to others; and therefore what wee may not lawfully, in this ca≈øe, doe to others, we can le≈ø≈øe lawfully doe it to our ≈øelves, again≈øt this generall law of love; in breaking whereof, ≈øpecially towards our ≈øelves, we violate the whole law, the generall ≈øumme whereof is love.

div.head: ¬ß. 2. Of the evill and greatne≈ø≈øe of ≈øelf-murder.
div.p: Whence it proceeds. This is the malice of Satan, and our own wretchedne≈ø≈øe, to ≈øet us at divi≈øion and enmity again≈øt our ≈øelves; and in a mon≈øtrous manner to make a man both the active and pa≈ø≈øive ≈øubject of his owne action, and utter de≈øtruction of him≈øelfe; (the greate≈øt mi≈øchiefe that can betide him in this world) and ≈øo a mans ≈øelfe becomes his owne executioner, by his owne hands, or meanes; principall, or acce≈ø≈øary; by command, or otherwi≈øe.

Compari≈øon. If parricide be a grievous ≈øinne, as wilfully to kill our owne parents; children; wives; hu≈øbands, &c. who are di≈øtinct per≈øous from our ≈øelves; much more is ≈øelf-murder abhominable. For, by unitie, things are pre≈øerved; and individualls are principally one: and therefore, if individualls be divided again≈øt them≈øelves, the world cannot ≈øtand; when things ≈øhall cea≈øe to be true, and amically di≈øpo≈øed to them≈øelves.

div.head: ¬ß. 3. Of lawfull ≈øelf-killing.
div.p:
Lawfull ≈øelfekilling. Of our old man. There is a lawfull and commanded killing of our ≈øelves. For under≈øtanding whereof, it is to be ob≈øerved, that every one of us hath in him a ≈øelf-old-man of ≈øinfulne≈ø≈øe, lively and powerfull in manifold lu≈øts and wicked actions: of which the Apo≈øtle tells us, Rom. 7.5. That when we were in the fle≈øh, the motions of ≈øinnes, which were by the Law, did worke in our members, to bring forth
fruit unto death; when the Commandement came ≈øinne revived: the living whereof doth kill us.

In this ca≈øe, even for our owne pre≈øervation, it is nece≈ø≈øary, and lawfull for us to kill our ≈øelf-old-man, with the lu≈øts thereof: as the Apo≈øtle commands us to mortifie our memhers, that the body of ≈øinne might be de≈øtroyed: we ≈øhould put off the old man. Ephe≈ø. 4.22. Col. 3.9. ≈øo that we ≈øhould become dead to tre≈øpa≈ø≈øes and ≈øinnes, wherein formerly we were dead.

The kinds of it. This killing of our ≈øelves, is metaphoricall and morall; by which death we are made alive: For, if we doe not thus die, wee cannot live: as, the ≈øowne corne mu≈øt fir≈øt die, before it can live and grow.Compari≈øon.

Hovv done. 1. In Chri≈øt. This our ≈øelf-old-man is ≈ølaine by three ≈øeverall acts or blowes. Fir≈øt, the ≈øame, after a ≈øort, was crucified in Chri≈øt, Rom. 6.6. That the body of ≈øinne might be de≈øtroyed; although, not the individuall per≈øons; but the common nature of mankind a≈ølumed by Chri≈øt did ≈øuffer death in him.

2. By change of our e≈øtate in Ju≈øtification. Secondly, our ≈øelf-old-man is killed, by change of our ≈øtate, upon our grafting into Chri≈øt by faith: ≈øo that we are, in that re≈øpect, ≈øaid to be dead to the Law, by the body of Chri≈øt, Rom. 7.4.6. and that we are dead to the Law, that we might live unto God, Gal. 2.19. this is done at one entire act or blow; in the act of our ju≈øtification; ≈øo, by this death, freeing us from him, that hath the power of death, even the devill.

3. By the Spirit. Thirdly, our ≈øelf-old-man and the lu≈øts thereof are killed, as touching the dominion and corruption of them, by the Spirit of God, in the act of ≈øanctification: touching which the Apo≈øtle tells us, Rom. 8.13. That if we, through the Spirit doe mortifie the deeds of the body, (which is the worke of our whole life,) we ≈øhall live.
How we are actors in it. This killing of our ≈øelf-old-man ≈øhould be done by our ≈øelves, being the executioners of it; by a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of divine power from God, in three ≈øeverall acts.
1. Fir≈øt, by our act of ≈øavingly beleeving in Chri≈øt, whereby our ≈øtate is changed from death to life.
2. Secondly, by our con≈øtant indeavours to be conformed to Gods Image and will, by daily renovation.

3. div.head: ¬ß. 12. Of the meanes of de≈øtruction, by breaking the Law.
div.p:
By ≈øins of commi≈ø≈øion.The deadly meanes, whereby men kill their owne ≈øoules, and ≈øubject the ≈øame to eternall po≈øitive de≈øtruction,
are the ≈øins that they wilfully commit, and continue in; in ≈øuch kinds and degrees, and manner, as cannot con≈øi≈øt in them with grace and ≈øalvation: and are of two ≈øorts.

1. Again≈øt the Law of negative commands. Fir≈øt, ≈øuch as be again≈øt the prime law of Nature, by tran≈øgre≈ø≈øing the negative Commandements of God; whereby the tran≈øgre≈ø≈øours doe ≈øubject them≈øelves to that puni≈øhment, which is called poena ≈øen≈øus, or puni≈øhment of ≈ømart, or damnation in hell. For, by ≈øinne entred death, Rom 5.12. Rev. 21.8. Prov. 19 16.
The properties of ≈øoul-murdring ≈øinnes. The properties of the cour≈øe and ≈øinnes of Commi≈ø≈øion, whereby a man becomes guilty of ≈øelf-murder of his ≈øoule, are foure.

1. They are gro≈ø≈øe. Although the nature of all ≈øinnes be mortall, de≈øerves death, and di≈øpo≈øes a man for it, yet tho≈øe that be of the gro≈ø≈øe≈øt kinds, and in the highe≈øt degrees of exorbitancy, ≈øuch as Ho≈øea ≈øpeakes of, cap. 4.2. are ≈øpecially ≈øaid to be mortall, for their extreame contrariety that they have to God and his ju≈øtice; their incon≈øi≈øtency with grace; and for their apting and di≈øpo≈øing of tho≈øe to de≈øtruction, that live in them; ≈øo that, by committing ≈øuch ≈øinnes men doe ca≈øt their owne ≈øoules into the gulfe of perdition.

2. Wilfull. Secondly, when they that commit tho≈øe ≈øinnes, or any of them, doe willingly doe the ≈øame; and live in them, again≈øt the light and checks of their owne con≈øciences; as our Saviour charges the Phari≈øees, Iohn 9.41. then are they ≈øelf-condemned; and do wittingly de≈øtroy their owne ≈øoules without excu≈øe of ignorance, or of want of power to have avoyded the ≈øame: ≈øeeing, as there is, in ≈øome, naturall notions of the Law in the minde, ≈øuch as the Gentiles have, Rom. 2.14. So likewi≈øe, all men have ≈øome remainder of power to forbeare ≈øinnes, in their gro≈ø≈øe≈øt kinds and degrees; if they were not wanting to them≈øelves: and therefore, as all men, ≈øpecially the wicked within the Church, ≈øhall be judged by the Law; ≈øo they ≈øhall have nothing to plead, to excu≈øe why they ≈øhould
not be damned, for their gro≈ø≈øe tran≈øgre≈ø≈øing of it.

3. Ob≈øtinate. Thirdly, when men commit tho≈øe ≈øinnes, with eagerne≈ø≈øe and delight, from and upon advi≈øed judgment, and wilfull re≈øolution; with contentment in the acting of them, and defending, or excu≈øing them, when they are done; as did Saul, 1 Sam. 13.12. and do fall to oppo≈øing, cen≈øuring, and condemning the contrary cour≈øe of vertue and godline≈ø≈øe, in the per≈øons that doe practi≈øe the ≈øame; whom, therefore, they hate and per≈øecute1 The≈ø. 2.15.: ≈øuch per≈øons are in a cour≈øe of de≈øtroying their owne ≈øoules, by ≈øetting them≈øelves, with a high hand, again≈øt God; provoking him to his face, to fall upon them for revenge.

4. Pre≈øevered in. Fourthly, by this cour≈øe of ≈øinning, a man murders his own ≈øoule, when he goeth on, and incorrigibly per≈øeveres therein, pa≈ø≈øing from evill to wor≈øe; hardning his owne heart, again≈øt all reproofes, and amendment; ≈øtorming again≈øt, and abu≈øing all the meanes of his recovery, to his deeper plunging in wickedne≈ø≈øe, and de≈øtruction; for, although hee would willingly mi≈ø≈øe hell, and bee rid of the guilt of his ≈øinne, that troubles his con≈øcience ≈øometime; yet, the corruption, and practi≈øe thereof he loves and entertaines: which is ≈øweet in his mouth, and which hee hides under his tongue, as Zophar ≈øaies Iob. 20.12.: as upon per≈øevering in well doing attends eternall life; ≈øo unto them that are contentious, and doe not obey the truth, but obey, and continue in unrighteou≈øne≈ø≈øe, indignation and wrath is their portion; and tribulation and angui≈øh ≈øhall be upon every ≈øoule of man, that doth evill, Rom. 2.6, 7, 8, 9.10.

div.head: ¬ß. 13. Of the cau≈øes of mens adventure upon ≈øinfull cour≈øes.
div.p: Rea≈øons of mens ≈øo living. The rea≈øons, why men do ≈øo de≈øperatly venture upon ≈øuch deadly cour≈øes, and continue in them, to the de≈øtruction of their owne ≈øoules, are ≈øpecially two.

1. Seeming good. Fir≈øt, becau≈øe the ≈øame ≈øeemes good to them; in regard of the blindene≈ø≈øe of their minds2 Pet. 1.9., that cannot truly di≈øcerne things that differ; and in regard of their unregenerated affections, which do ≈øympathize and comply be≈øt with ≈øuch cour≈øes; and becau≈øe they are ≈øelf-deceived, by a ≈øeeming goodne≈ø≈øe of profit, or pre≈øent plea≈øure in them; which they preferre before true morall goodne≈ø≈øe; and therewithall do re≈øt and content them≈øelves, in the ignorance and want of better comforts: but a wi≈øe man will beware of ≈øelf-deceit; by tru≈øting to his owne opinion, or ≈øen≈øe; con≈øidering that there is a way that ≈øeemeth right to a man; but the end thereof are the waies of death, Prov. 14.12.

2. Want of faith. The ≈øecond cau≈øe of mans boldne≈ø≈øe, in adventuring to run an unlawfull cour≈øe with the perill of the damnation of his ≈øoule; is want of true faith to beleeve the threatnings of God in his word again≈øt the ≈øame; or, at the lea≈øt, they ≈øuppo≈øe that the judgments will not be ≈øo bad and intolerable, as is given out; or, they hope they ≈øhall e≈øcpe them; or, they comfort them≈øelves with conceit of their fellowes company; and doe imagine God to be all mercy, and no ju≈øtice: the rea≈øon hereof is, both their not di≈øcerning, nor regarding of the ≈øpirituall judgments of God upon them; which are the greate≈øt and wor≈øt, and ≈øuch as they ≈øee not ≈øen≈øibly; and al≈øo, becau≈øe ≈øentence again≈øt an evill worke is not executed ≈øpeedily; therefore, the heart of the ≈øonnes of men is fully ≈øet in them to doe evill, Eccle≈ø. 8.11. the flouri≈øhing of men in their owne ill condition hardens them, and ≈øtaggers the godly P≈øal. 73.12, 13..

div.head: ¬ß. 14. Of ≈øpirituall ≈øelf-murder, by ≈øinning again≈øt the Go≈øpell.
div.p:
The ≈øecond kind of ≈øinnes of commi≈ø≈øion are again≈øt the Go≈øpell. The ≈øecond kind of ≈øoul-killing cour≈øes, are ≈øinnes committed again≈øt the Go≈øpell; which is the only remedy
given for tran≈øgre≈ø≈øors of the Law, that when they are condemned for their di≈øobedience to the Law, they may be ≈øaved by their obedience to the Go≈øpell; without which they cannot but peri≈øh.
This Evangelicall obedience differs from legall obedience, in foure points.

1. Obedience of the Go≈øpell differs from obedience of the Law. Done by Chri≈øts power. Fir≈øt, whereas legall obedience is originally required to be done by a mans owne power and ≈øtrength; Evangelicall obedience is to be done by us, through the power of Chri≈øt and his Spirit working in us, and by us; inabling us above the power of nature.

2. Acceptable with infirmity. Secondly, no obedience of the Law is acceptable to God from tho≈øe doing it, as under the Law, for ju≈øtification by their workes; except the doers thereof be pure from inherent corruption, and doe their actions in their highe≈øt degree of morall perfection, without any defect therein: but, for the obedience of the Go≈øpell, it is accepted by God, from the hands of ≈øinfull men, as perfect, if it be in truth and ≈øincerity, although accompanied with many involuntary defects, in our beleeving and repenting.

3. It includes legall obedience. Thirdly, perfect legall obedience, yea any obedience of the Law, as legall, who≈øe performance re≈øpects ju≈øtification; excludes Evangelicall obedience; with which, in that ≈øen≈øe, it cannot con≈øi≈øt: ≈øeeing, ju≈øtification both by workes and faith, both by the Law and Go≈øpell, are incompatible, as the Apo≈øtle proves, Rom. 3.28. Gal. 2.16. But, Evangelicall obedience includes legall obedience, as inferiour and ≈øubordinate to it: for, there is an Evangelicall u≈øe of the Law under the Go≈øpell, both, for preparation to the beleeving of it; and al≈øo, for ≈øanctification of life ordered thereby, by a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of power from Chri≈øt; for manife≈øtation of the truth of Gods grace in us; to the workes whereof, although imperfect, a reward is due.

4. It re≈øpects ≈øalvation by another. Fourthly, the obedience of the Law, by it ≈øelfe con≈øidered, re≈øpects ≈øalvation by way of morall works in our
≈øelves, but the Go≈øpell re≈øpects the ≈øame, by way of application of merit from another, to witt, from Ie≈øus Chri≈øt: the Law cannot cure nor excu≈øe the tran≈øgre≈ø≈øions committed again≈øt the Go≈øpell; but the Go≈øpell can heale, and deliver us from the ≈øinnes and judgements of the Law, what≈øoever they have beene: and therefore it is, that the tran≈øgre≈ø≈øors again≈øt the Go≈øpell, are in farre more danger of de≈øtruction therby, than by their ≈øins again≈øt the Law.

div.head: ¬ß. 15. Of Infidelity.
div.p: Sins again≈øt the Go≈øpell. Of the≈øe ≈øoul-killing tran≈øgre≈ø≈øions again≈øt the Go≈øpell there are foure branches.

1. Infidelity. Fir≈øt, po≈øitive unbeliefe, or infidelity, when a man will not beeleve ≈øavingly in Chri≈øt, to have him to bee both his Saviour and Lord: neither beleeves truly the Go≈øpell, in its full latitude and contents, although litterally hee knowes the ≈øame, but holds and beleeves deceitfull errors, defending the ≈øame, and applauding him≈øelfe therein: and therefore, ≈øeeing that now there is no ≈øalvation but by true faith in Chri≈øt, tho≈øe that will not ≈øo beleeve, according to the Go≈øpell mu≈øt needs peri≈øh Iob. 3.18.
1.Cau≈øes of infidelity.The chiefe cau≈øes of this infidelity, are, Fir≈øt, an innated habit to beleeve error, before the truth.

2. Secondly, our carnall rea≈øon, deceitfull fancies, and humane pre≈øumptions, upon fal≈øe principles, over≈øwaying our faith, contrary to the word of God, whereby men turne a≈øide to their owne crooked wayes, and peri≈øh (as it were) in the gain≈øaying of Corah
P≈øal. 125.5. Cure.. For prevention of this infidelity, I conclude with the Apo≈øtle, take heed brethren le≈øt there bee in any of you an evill heart of unbeliefe, in departing from the living God

div.head: ¬ß. 16. Of Impenitency.
div.p:
2. Impenitency. The ≈øecond kind of ≈øinnes again≈øt the Go≈øpell, whereby
men kill their owne ≈øoules, is finall impenitency; when they neither care, nor indeavour to repent for their ≈øins pa≈øt; nor to reforme their lives, for time to come; but goe on in their ≈øinnes, out of love, or carele≈øne≈ø≈øe of them: remor≈øe for ≈øinnes, in re≈øpect of the puni≈øhment of them, is not true repentance, if it bee not ≈øpecially for the offence of God by them, and if a man bee ≈øorrowfull for ≈øome gro≈ø≈øe ≈øinnes, committed by him, and doe re≈øtraine his practi≈øe therefrom, it is not ≈øound repentance, ≈øo long as hee is not grieved for his ≈øinnes of omi≈ø≈øion; nor makes con≈øcience to doe his duty, in keeping the affirmative Commandements of God. Of the danger of this cour≈øe of impenitency the Apo≈øtle Paul gives his cen≈øure, in the≈øe words: But after thy hardne≈ø≈øe and impenitent heart, thou trea≈øure≈øt up unto thy ≈øelfe wrath, again≈øt the day of wrath, and revelation of the righteous judgements of God, Rom. 2.5.Cure. To prevent this impenitency, we mu≈øt beware of cu≈øtome in ≈øinne, and of ≈ølighting our ≈øpirituall e≈øtates.

div.head: ¬ß. 17. Of the ≈øinne again≈øt the Holy Gho≈øt.
div.p:
3. The ≈øinne again≈øt the Holy Gho≈øt. The third branch of the ≈øinnes again≈øt the Go≈øpell, whereby a man kills his owne ≈øoule, is the ≈øinne again≈øt the Holy Gho≈øt: which con≈øi≈øts in hating, and oppo≈øing the knowne ≈øaving truth of the Go≈øpell
Mat. 12.31., and is called a ≈øinne unto death, 1 Ioh. 5.16. from which there is no recovery; not onely becau≈øe it is ever accompanied with finall impenitency; but, ≈øpecially, for that the nature of that ≈øinne is ≈øo directly again≈øt the meanes of ≈øalvation, that thereby a man cuts him≈øelfe utterly off from it; and deprives him≈øelfe of the ≈øuffrages and prayers of the Church 1 Ioh. 5.16.: every ≈øinne di≈øpo≈øes a man le≈ø≈øe or more to this ≈øinne; which is the tran≈øcendency of all ≈øinnes; and therefore, that all men may feare, and not pre≈øume upon any ≈øinfull cour≈øe, God hath ≈øet bounds to his mercy, how
farre, in what ca≈øes, and to whom he will ≈øhew the ≈øame, and in what ca≈øes, and to whom not. It behooves all men, as they would e≈øcape damnation, to beware of this ≈øinne; which at la≈øt often cau≈øes men to lay violent hands upon them≈øelves, and to end their lives in de≈øperation. The ≈øinnes neere approaching to it, are tho≈øe that men doe wilfully, with a high hand, commit, and ≈øtand in; with hatred and per≈øecuting of the contrary vertuous cour≈øes in others.Cure. To avoid this ≈øinne again≈øt the Holy Gho≈øt, wee mu≈øt be carefull that wee ≈øinne not pre≈øumptuou≈øly; nor hate goodne≈ø≈øe, and good people.

Things ob≈øervable in it.It is (by way of enlargement) further to be ob≈øerved, that this ≈øinne again≈øt the Holy Gho≈øt is both incident onely to per≈øons inlightned, with certaine knowledge of Chri≈øt and the Go≈øpell,

Ob≈øerv. Many more doe now, in the time of the Go≈øpell, commit this ≈øinne again≈øt the Holy Gho≈øt, How many now do commit it. than could doe it in the time of the Law: and, many now doe come ≈øo neere unto it, that they fall into the de≈øperate e≈øtate of impenitencie, and of a reprobate ≈øen≈øe; in regard of the clearene≈ø≈øe, and abundance of the light of the Go≈øpell; contrary to which, and to their owne con≈øcience, they runne with greedine≈ø≈øe to all exce≈ø≈øe of wickedne≈ø≈øe and prophanene≈ø≈øe; with hatred and oppo≈øition of goodne≈ø≈øe;

None that are affraid they have committed the ≈øinne again≈øt the Holy Gho≈øt; or, are troubled about it; or, grieved for it, can (in that ca≈øe,) commit it; neither have committed it: becau≈øe, this ≈øinne is done with the whole con≈øent of will, and ≈øway of affections in a totall Apo≈øtacy, with impenitency, and unreconcileable hatred, and per≈øecution of the truth of the Go≈øpell, and of the profe≈ø≈øors thereof.

div.head: ¬ß. 18. Of Apo≈øtacy.
div.p:
Finall Apo≈øtacy. Fourthly, the ≈øoule murdering ≈øinnes, committed again≈øt the Go≈øpell, are, apo≈øtacy, from the profe≈ø≈øion, or power of it; occa≈øioned by an evill heart of unbeliefe, by the profits, honors, plea≈øures, or examples and temptations of the world; in tho≈øe that are hypocrites and un≈øound: as were Demas 2 Tim. 4 10., and Simon Magus

Where it is to be ob≈øerved, that Apo≈øtates (in Gods ju≈øt judgement) not onely runne into all exce≈ø≈øe of impiety and prophanene≈ø≈øe; but, doe al≈øo become mo≈øt bitter haters, and per≈øecuters of the profe≈ø≈øion and profe≈ø≈øors; which formerly they ≈øeemed to embrace; being not content to peri≈øh them≈øelves, but al≈øo are grieved that any ≈øhould bee ≈øaved, and ≈øtand fa≈øt in the truth. Apo≈øtates are hardly ever recovered, and their damnation is greater; becau≈øe, they fall from a higher pitch than other men; and again≈øt more meanes of knowledge, and reluctancy; whereby they are ≈øelf-condemned; and often, at la≈øt, end their dayes in de≈øpaire: graduall apo≈øtacy, or relecting in the power and wayes of godline≈ø≈øe, is incident to the godly, and recoverable, as wee ≈øee Revel. 2.5. and therefore, is not comprenended in this

The difference of ≈øinnes. Although, it is certaine that all ≈øinnes are damnable for nature, in regard of their contrariety to God and his Law; and are al≈øo of a condemning property, in re≈øpect of their merit of due puni≈øhment of damnation: For, the ≈øoule that ≈øins ≈øhall dye: Ezek. 18.4. yet, all ≈øinnes are not alike, (as the Stoicks affirme:) but, ≈øome are more mi≈øchievous, and more repugnant, than others, to God him≈øelfe, and to our ≈øalvation, and to the good of others; and are more incompatible with ju≈øtice, and charity, than others are: as Idolatry, perjury, &c.

div.head: ¬ß. 19. Of the malignity of the ≈øinnes again≈øt the Go≈øpell, above tho≈øe committed again≈øt the Law.
div.p: Sinues again≈øt the Go≈øpell wor≈øe than again≈øt the Law.The ≈øinnes that are done immediately again≈øt the Go≈øpell, are more dangerous and wor≈øe than tho≈øe that are committed immediatly again≈øt the Law, whereof I will give three rea≈øons.
Rea≈øons. 1. Fir≈øt, for their nature; they are of a higher ≈øtraine than the ≈øinnes of the Law, as the Go≈øpell is more eminent, than the Law, which is intimated, Heb. 10.28, 29.

2. Secondly, the≈øe ≈øinnes again≈øt the Go≈øpell are done, with more oppo≈øition again≈øt more abundant meanes and grace, by tho≈øe that now live in the Church, than the ≈øins of the Law: as Paul manife≈øts to us, 2 Cor. 3.8.

Thirdly, the ≈øinnes again≈øt the Go≈øpell are committed with farre more inevitable de≈øtruction, than the ≈øinnes again≈øt the Law: for, if a man doe ≈øinne again≈øt the Law he hath the Go≈øpell as a City of refuge to flee to, to ≈øave him from the killing and damnation of the Law: but if a man doe ≈øinne (as afore≈øaid) again≈øt the Go≈øpell, there remaines no further meanes, or hope of ≈øafety, but a

Ob≈øerve. From the con≈øideration of the afore≈øaid ≈øins of Commi≈ø≈øion, again≈øt the Law and the Go≈øpell; with their deadly effects, we may ob≈øerve,

2. To have our wills brings de≈øtruction. Secondly, we may ≈øee, that we cannot have our own wills in ≈øinfull cour≈øes, but with the de≈øtruction of our ≈øoules: our folly is ≈øeene in undoing our ≈øelves by our owne workes and wayes; ≈øo that a mans cour≈øe of ≈øinning, and following of his lu≈øts, is indeed but a cour≈øe of Gods heavy ≈øpirituall judgements upon him; wherein he is rather to be pittied, as mi≈øerable; than to be envyed as formidable: God will have his will in mans de≈øtruction; when man will not let God have his will in his Commandements.

div.head: ¬ß. 20. The improvement of the knowledge of ≈øpirituall ≈øelf-murder.
div.p: V≈øes.The V≈øes of the knowledge of the afore≈øaid ≈øpirituall ≈øelf-murder are ≈øpecially Foure.

div.head: ¬ß. 2. Of Mans body and its works.

div.head: ¬ß. 5. Of the degrees of ≈øinne, and how to e≈øcape the greate≈øt, and its end.
div.p: V≈øes.The u≈øes of this doctrine, of the di≈øtinction of ≈øelf-murder into direct and indirect; and of the differences betweene them; are ≈øpecially two.

1. Degrees of ≈øin. Fir≈øt, to teach us that, there are differences and degrees in the ≈øame kindes of ≈øinnes; ≈øome being more grievous, than other ≈øome. So that although we be not guilty of ≈øinne in the ≈øame degree; yet we may be in the ≈øame kinde; as appeares by the Iewes convicted in their con≈øciences, of uncleanne≈ø≈øe; although they were not taken in the act; as the Woman was, Iohn 8.9.

How to e≈øcape great ≈øins. And therefore, to e≈øcape falling into the highe≈øt degrees of ≈øinne, wee ≈øhould be carefull to avoide, and to be free of the ≈øame generall kindes of ≈øinne; both as they are unformed and confu≈øed, in originall corruption; as in their ≈øeminall Chaos; and al≈øo, as they are formed in their di≈øtinct habits; ≈øo improperly called, becau≈øe, after the manner of habits, they either are in the place of true habits, or unite them≈øelves in, and with them; that they may both brooke one common name: and ≈øo we ≈øhould labour to be cleare of ≈øinne; both habitually, and actually.

Ob≈øerve. Wee ≈øhould not bee conceited, and ble≈ø≈øe our ≈øelves ≈øo much, becau≈øe we are not fallen into the fowle≈øt degrees of ≈øinne; as we ≈øhould be humble, and penitently confe≈ø≈øe our guiltine≈ø≈øe in the kindes thereof; the difference herein being betweene us and others, but in magis and minus, in greater and le≈ø≈øer: where the lea≈øt degree makes way, and di≈øpo≈øes us for the greate≈øt; and makes us liable to the ≈øame kinde of puni≈øhment, although not to the ≈øame mea≈øure of it.

The ≈øame end ≈øeverall vvaies attained. The ≈øecond u≈øe ≈øerves to in≈øtruct us that men doe come to the ≈øame di≈ømall ends, as Saul and others did, by ≈øeverall cour≈øes, being guilty of their owne deaths in
diver≈øe manners; as men may come into the ≈øame pri≈øon, at and by ≈øeverall doores.Compari≈øon. For, although a man can draw a right, or ≈øtraight line betwixt the ≈øame points but one way; yet he may draw crooked lines many waies, and they all be terminated in the ≈øame points.

Therefore, as a man would beware of any evill end, ≈øo ≈øhould he ≈øhunne all the cour≈øes, that may lead, or bring him to it. For, it is no benefit to a man in mi≈øery to con≈øider, how, and by what ≈øinfull cour≈øe hee came thither; ≈øo long as he is in that woefull ≈øtate. Wee ≈øee many men come and end their daies together, upon the ≈øame Gallowes, but by ≈øeverall cour≈øes, and differing crimes; ≈øome for pettie trea≈øon; ≈øome for wilfull murder; ≈øome for burglary; ≈øome for pettie larceny; and yet, to him that is hanged for the le≈ø≈øer offence, it is ≈ømall ea≈øe and comfort, becau≈øe he ≈øuffers not for a greater; ≈øo long as it is for any that he dies.

div.head: CHAP. II. Of Indirect ≈øelf-murder of the body.
¬ß. 1. Why Indirect ≈øelf-murder is fir≈øt treated of.
div.p: Indirect ≈øelf-murder is handled fir≈øt:ALthough that by logicall method, I ≈øhould treat fir≈øt of Direct ≈øelf-murder; becau≈øe, that which is directly under a Genus, or generall head, ≈øhould bee handled before that, which is but indirectly under it, for the neerene≈ø≈øe thereof unto the ≈øame; and for the light that it may afford, for the better under≈øtanding of the other: yet, for all that, I will heere begin with indirect ≈øelf-murder for three cau≈øes.

Rea≈øons. 1. Imitation of nature. Fir≈øt, becau≈øe I will herein imitate nature, which proceeds froÃÑ things le≈ø≈øe perfect, tothings more perfect:
becau≈øe perfectioÃÑ is her ultimate end. Indirect ≈øelf-murder is le≈ø≈øe perfect ≈øelf-murder than direct ≈øelf-murder; becau≈øe, the Genus of ≈øelf-murder agrees more properly, and primarily to direct ≈øelf-murder, than to indirect.

2. Precedency in execution. Secondly, indirect ≈øelf-murder is ordinarily, both the way, and the cau≈øe of direct ≈øelf-murder: and therefore, may be fitly treated of fir≈øt; the rather becau≈øe, direct ≈øelf-murder never goeth before indirect; but, this goeth often before, and without that.

3. End intended. Thirdly, becau≈øe my intention is to in≈øi≈øt ≈øpecially upon direct ≈øelf-murder, and by meanes of it onely doe I ≈øpeake of indirect ≈øelf-murder, therefore, I purpo≈øe fir≈øt to di≈øpatch it, as an acce≈ø≈øary to the other; which I principally intend, as my la≈øt end in this treati≈øe, therewithall to conclude the ≈øame.

div.head: ¬ß. 2. Of Indirect ≈øelf-murder by omi≈øsion.
div.p: How indirect ≈øelf-murder is performed.Having ≈øhewed what indirect ≈øelf-murder is, and how it is differenced from direct ≈øelf-murder, I will now declare how men doe fall into the ≈øame; which is done two waies. Fir≈øt, by omi≈ø≈øion. Secondly, by commi≈ø≈øion.

1. By omi≈ø≈øion. By omi≈ø≈øion a man may indirectly murder him≈øelfe, being the deficient cau≈øe of the pre≈øervation of his life; two waies: either in a phy≈øicall naturall manner; or in a morall meritorious cour≈øe.

div.head: ¬ß. 3. Of indirect ≈øelf-murder, by omi≈øsion phy≈øically wrought.
div.p: Wayes how. 1. Phy≈øically, diver≈øe waies. Fir≈øt phy≈øically, and after a naturall manner, a man may indirectly murder him≈øelfe, divers waies: as

1. Neglect of food. Fir≈øt, a man may indirectly murder him≈øelfe, by way of omi≈ø≈øion; if out of ≈øullenne≈ø≈øe, griefe, or nigardize; or by undi≈øcreet puni≈øhment, of his body, he ≈øhall ≈øtubbornly and fooli≈øhly refu≈øe to eate, or drinke; in that mea≈øure,
or kinde that is requi≈øite for his pre≈øervation, by ab≈øtinency, and ≈øparing, either ≈øtarving him≈øelfe to death; or breeding in him≈øelfe and contracting that which kills him: ≈øomewhat like hereunto was the practi≈øe of Ahab, 1 King. 21.4. who becau≈øe Naboth would not let him have his vineyard, heavie and di≈øplea≈øed, layd him downe upon his bed; and turned away his face, and would eat no bread: 1 Tim. 5.23. the contrary whereof Paul commanded Timothy.

A Caveat. Yet, to avoid this danger, men may not Gormandize, or exce≈ø≈øively pamper them≈øelves, indulgendo Genio; but may, and ought at ≈øet times to fa≈øt; both for civill, and divine ends; with re≈øpect to the good both of ≈øoule and body.

2. Contempt of Phy≈øick. Secondly, in this kinde of omi≈ø≈øion, a man may indirectly murder him≈øelfe; by wilfull contempt of the lawfull u≈øe of Phy≈øick, or Chirurgery; either to cure, or prevent apparent mortall di≈øea≈øes or griefes; or, when he will not be ordered, by the whole≈øome direction of the skilfull in their calling; or, doth not depend upon God, for a ble≈ø≈øing upon the meanes; who, by his over-ruling providence, directs the cour≈øe, and ble≈ø≈øes the meanes.

A Caveat. Yet, men mu≈øt herein be carefull that they ≈ølavi≈øhly enthrall not them≈øelves to the meanes; nor anxiou≈øly perplexe them≈øelves, if they cannot have them; or, that the ≈øucce≈ø≈øe an≈øwers not their expectation: becau≈øe, the Lord di≈øpo≈øes things ≈øo, as he al≈øo may effect his worke and will, often by cro≈ø≈øing ours.

Neglect of prevention of dangers. Thirdly, a man may incurre indirect ≈øelf-murder, by regardle≈øne≈ø≈øe of pre≈øerving him≈øelf again≈øt mortall dangers; from without him≈øelf; as, in not ≈øeeking to God for reconciliation, by humiliation, and repentance; in ≈øome imminent judgements that threaten from God our de≈øtruction; that we may bee pre≈øerved either from them, or in them: Or as, when wee are in danger of inva≈øion by enemies, for a man then regardle≈øly to ≈øhut his eyes from fore≈øeeing the ≈øame, that it may ≈øuddenly ≈øurpri≈øe
him; or, that he ≈øhould not prepare him≈øelf, and do his utmo≈øt endeavours in his owne defence, to ≈øave his life; if by re≈øi≈øting it may be done; or otherwi≈øe to provide for him≈øelfe by flight; or other prudent diver≈øion, or preventing of the evill; that he may not carele≈øly ≈øuffer his life to be lo≈øt. So then, the cowardi≈øe of men in extremities by Sea or land, that will not doe their utmo≈øt endeavours, for their owne pre≈øervation; as likewi≈øe the griplene≈ø≈øe of tho≈øe that to ≈øpare their goods, indanger the lo≈ø≈øe of their lives, for want of military furniture and meanes to make oppo≈øition; are much to be blamed for this cour≈øe of indirect ≈øelf-murder.

A caveat. But yet, touching this point, men ≈øhould be wary that they neither be ≈øo carefull to pre≈øerve their lives, that they ≈øhould ≈øpare to venture them where they ought; and may comfortably ≈øpend and lay them downe: nor yet, have their eyes and confidence ≈øo upon earthly meanes, of humane ≈øtrength and provi≈øion; that they ≈øhould forget, or neglect to ≈øeeke to God, and to depend upon him, for ≈øafety and victorious ≈øucce≈ø≈øe.

4. Not avoiding dangerous per≈øons & places. Fourthly, of indirect ≈øelf-murder a man may be guilty, by not avoiding and fleeing from per≈øons and places de≈øtinated to de≈øtruction; which are under a cur≈øe; or, in a cour≈øe of mortall judgements; when we are not nece≈ø≈øarily tyed by duty, or calling, to commerce and bee with them: as is apparent by Lots for≈øaking of Sodome; and by the command of Mo≈øes to the I≈øraelites,
Gen. 19. Numb. 17.26. to depart from the tents of Corah, Dathan and Abiram; and by that divine commandement, charging all the godly to come out of Babylon; that they might not be partakers of her ≈øins; and that they might not receive of her plagues.
Rev. 18.4.

And therefore, ≈øuch as out of unwarrantable pre≈øumption, or carnall ≈øecurity, avoid not per≈øons, and places infected with the pe≈øtilence; or ≈øubjected to perdition; when their pre≈øence is unnece≈ø≈øary, & not to be ju≈øtified, and pernicious to them≈øelves; they mu≈øt be ca≈øt upon the

div.head: ¬ß. 4. Of indirect ≈øelf-murder by omi≈øsion morally wrought.
div.p: 2. Morally. By way of deficiency, or omi≈ø≈øion of indirect ≈øelf-murder, a man may be guilty by a morall meritorious default; two wayes:

1. By neglect of good life. Fir≈øt, by his wilfull neglect or contempt to live and walke in the wayes of godline≈ø≈øe, and obedience to gods affirmative commandements; whereunto the promi≈øes of life and protection are annexed Gal. 3.12., and which we may certainly expect; ≈øo long as we keepe our ≈øelves within compa≈ø≈øe of morall obedience to the Law and Go≈øpell; and within the limits and precincts of our ≈øpeciall callings; ≈øo that if therein, or therefore, we ≈øhould lo≈øe our lives, we ≈øhall be free of the imputation of ≈øelf-murder any way, in that re≈øpect.

2. Neglect of prayer, &c. Secondly, in meritorious morall manner, a man may mi≈øcary, and be indirectly guilty of his own death; by wilfull omi≈ø≈øion and neglect of commending him≈øelfe in con≈øtant and ordinary prayer to God; for divine pre≈øervation and ≈øafety of his life, again≈øt all evills and dangers, which may hurt him; and over which, and over him, God hath a ≈øoveraigne power and command. Unbeliefe. And al≈øo, by his unbeliefe, and not tru≈øting in God in all e≈øtates, for pre≈øervation; under who≈øe wings he may ≈øecurely re≈øt, a man may be ju≈øtly de≈øerted, and given over to peri≈øh and ≈øinke; as Peter when he doubted, was in danger of drowning.
Mat. 14.30, 31

Whence it proceeds. This neglect of thus depending upon God, ari≈øeth either from ≈øelf-confidence in mans owne power and meanes; whereupon he re≈øts as ≈øecure: or el≈øe, from Athei≈øticall conceits of the providence of God; as if he were regardle≈ø≈øe of humane affaires, and that all things did fall
out by chance and fortune; becau≈øe they doe ≈øee all things in this world fall out alike to all men: which being more exactly con≈øidered, manife≈øts rather the free and ≈øoveraigne powerfull providence of God over-ruling all things.

A caveat. Yet, this divine pre≈øervation, by faith and prayer to God, excludes not, but includes the con≈øcionable u≈øe of lawfull meanes, and walking in appointed cour≈øes; without which we can expect ≈øafety no more, than Paul and his company could, if they did let the mariners for≈øake the Ship:
Acts 27.31. if a man by the afore≈øaid neglect of prayer and dependance upon God, doe not peri≈øh; it is Gods ≈øpeciall worke, re≈øerving him either for repentance and amendment of his life; or for ≈øome wor≈øe end, and heavier judgement.

Ob≈øerve. Neglect of meanes is tempting of God. From this degree of indirect ≈øelf-murder, by omi≈ø≈øion of meanes, wee may ob≈øerve that when God gives meanes of life; if we u≈øe them not to that end, we tempt God, to follow our owne wills; while we will not follow his: and if we u≈øe the meanes, with tru≈øting in them, then we make gods of the meanes; and therefore, in that re≈øpect, it is ju≈øt with God to di≈øappoint us of our expectation, and to condemne us of indirect ≈øelf-murder, upon our mi≈øcarying, in not u≈øing the meanes.

For, all meanes, as they are meanes, have relation to the end; why, and whereunto they are appointed: and ≈øo, in their u≈øe to that end con≈øi≈øts their perfection; without which they were u≈øele≈ø≈øe and needle≈ø≈øe: and therefore, by the omi≈ø≈øion of the u≈øe of the meanes of life, which men would enjoy, they either tempt God to doe things otherwi≈øe than he hath ordained; or el≈øe, they doe ≈øhew them≈øelves regardle≈ø≈øe of God, preferring their owne wills above his, expecting to have their owne purpo≈øes without him; whereby many men deceive them≈øelves.

div.head: ¬ß. 5. A que≈øtion re≈øolved about ≈øtanders mute at tryall.
div.p: About mutes refu≈øing to undergoe the ordinary legall triall for their lives.To this branch of indirect ≈øelf-murder by omi≈ø≈øion belongs the ca≈øe about mutes, who are per≈øons ≈øtanding legally indited and arraigned for ≈øome capitall crimes, that doe wilfully and ob≈øtinately decline and refu≈øe either to confe≈ø≈øe them≈øelves guilty of the ≈øame, or to ≈øubmit them≈øelves to be tryed by God and the Country; notwith≈øtanding that they certainly know that for their ≈øtubborne mutene≈ø≈øe, they ≈øhall in fearefull manner bee pre≈ø≈øed to death; in which re≈øpect they are indirect ≈øelf-murderers; although that they are thereunto moved e≈øpecially by foure ≈øeeming rea≈øons.
Their rea≈øons. 1. Fir≈øt, becau≈øe that by that way they would ≈øave their e≈øtates, (if they have any) from being confi≈øcate to the King, that their heires may enjoy the ≈øame.

2. Secondly, that ≈øo they may e≈øcape the death that is mo≈øt ignominious in their eyes, and infamous in the world to their memories, friends, and po≈øterities, whereunto they fore≈øee they ≈øhould be ≈øubject, if ≈øo be they ≈øhould undergoe an ordinary tryall.
3. Thirdly, that it may not be ≈øaid that they ≈øuffered and dyed for ≈øo odious and ≈øhamefull crimes and facts as they are accu≈øed of, and indited for.

4. Fourthly, that they may not be ca≈øt, condemned, or ≈øuffer by the meanes, wills, and hands of ≈øuch pro≈øecutors, witne≈ø≈øes, Iury, or Indges as they take to be their capitall enemies; they choo≈øe to die by that cour≈øe of their owne election wherein their adver≈øaries can lea≈øt (as they thinke) have their will of them.

They ≈øhould die, and why.But whatever be their rea≈øons of ≈øtanding mute in that ca≈øe, it is mo≈øt ju≈øt that therefore they ≈øhould bee put to death in mo≈øt terrible and ignominious manner; for two rea≈øons.

1. Fir≈øt, becau≈øe of the intollerable wrong that thereby they doe to authority and ju≈øtice; tending to the overthrow of the ≈øame, by refu≈øing to ≈øubject their lives to the triall and judgement thereof; and by their deaths (as it may be truly interpreted) depriving their highe≈øt Soveraignes on earth both of the commendation of Iu≈øt, and al≈øo of opportunity of ≈øhewing mercy, and giving pardon to delinquents: and ≈øo not ≈øubmitting to the judicature, they actually declare them≈øelves to be rebellious outlawes, for which they are ju≈øtly to die.

2. Secondly, be cau≈øe ≈øuch per≈øons, by declining ≈øo ju≈øt a way of trial by God and their Peeres, doe (in iu≈øt con≈øtruction) declare them≈øelves to bee guilty of the facts and crimes whereof they are indited; and for which they ought to die, but ≈øeeke to cro≈ø≈øe the law in the proper kindes of puni≈øhment due for the ≈øame.
And that they are guilty of their owne deaths by a gro≈ø≈øe cour≈øe of indirect ≈øelf-murder, is evident by foure rea≈øons.Mutes are ≈øelf-murderers.

Rea≈øons. 1. Fir≈øt, becau≈øe ≈øuch an one wilfully and ob≈øtinately reiects that lawfull and ordinary cour≈øe of triall, whereby it is po≈ø≈øible that he might e≈øcape with his life; either by not being found guilty; or el≈øe by replevin, or pardon from the execution; and choo≈øes that illegall cour≈øe of ≈øtanding mute, whereby, and for which hee certainly knowes he ≈øhall die: and as certaine it is that ≈øo dying, he is an indirect ≈øelf-murderer; in regard that he ca≈øts away his life wilfully by that cour≈øe, which was in his owne power mo≈øt lawfully to have avoyded.

2. Secondly, by choi≈øe of that cour≈øe of ≈øtanding mute, when he is called to a lawfull tryall, he dies not only for that contumacy again≈øt authority and law; but al≈øo thereby he unnaturally witne≈ø≈øes, and gives verdict again≈øt him≈øelfe to be guilty of the originall fact or crime for which he is indited, and ought to die if it can bee proved and found again≈øt him; which thing hee (by his mutene≈ø≈øe),
doing, in that re≈øpect hee ju≈øtly peri≈øhes by his owne meanes, and is indirectly a ≈øelf murderer: for no innocent would decline ≈øo ju≈øt and lawfull a tryall, by God and his Peeres, when he knowes that by ≈øo refu≈øing hee ≈øhall ≈øurely die.

3. Thirdly, it is apparent that ≈øuch a body is indirectly a ≈øelf-murderer; becau≈øe of the morall nature of their cour≈øe of ≈øtanding mute; which is mo≈øt wicked and unlawfull, both by Gods law and mans: For, by the law of God and nature, every man is bound to plead and doe the be≈øt he can by all lawfull meanes to prolong, or pre≈øerve his life; but ≈øtanders mute in ca≈øe of triall upon their lives, doe not ≈øo, but utterly neglect the u≈øe of lawfull meanes to prolong, or ≈øave their lives; and therefore are of this kinde of ≈øelf-murderers.

By mans law, for a per≈øon arraigned to ≈øtand mute, is mo≈øt unlawfull, becau≈øe it cro≈ø≈øes the execution of Ju≈øtice, and is ju≈øtly puni≈øhed by a mo≈øt terrible kinde of death, by pre≈ø≈øing. Man hath not an allowed choi≈øe given him by law, either to ≈øubmit to triall, or to be mute, as he ≈øhall plea≈øe: for if the choi≈øe were lawfull, why then ≈øhould hee bee puni≈øhed for doing that which hee may lawfully choo≈øe, which could not be done by the magi≈øtrate without great inju≈øtice?

4. Fourthly, that ≈øuch mutes are indirect ≈øelf-murderers, is evident by the voluntary di≈øpo≈øition: of their wills in the free choi≈øe of that mortall cour≈øe, and by the proper nature of their death, and by the meritorious cau≈øe and rea≈øon of it; all proceeding from them≈øelves in active manner. Whereas, touching their deaths, and cour≈øe of inflicting thereof, they ≈øhould pa≈ø≈øively and obediently ≈øubmit to God and lawfull authority to live, or die as they plea≈øe, where no lawfull choi≈øe is given in mortall cour≈øes, there no man can choo≈øe that which is unlawfull without being an indirect ≈øelf-murderer, as it is in this ca≈øe.
An≈øwer to their motives.The motives whereupon any per≈øons doe ≈øtand mute, refu≈øing to be tryed in an ordinary lawfull manner, are altogether in≈øufficient to ju≈øtifie their practi≈øe.
For an≈øwer to the fir≈øt, it is certaine that we ≈øhould do nothing that is unlawfull to ≈øave our worldly e≈øtates for our heires: but this cour≈øe is unlawfull; Ergo.

To be more carefull to provide for the ≈øafety of their worldly goods, than of their ≈øoules, is wretchedne≈ø≈øe and de≈øperate folly; which all tho≈øe doe which by unlawfull meanes would pre≈øerve their e≈øtates. Such mutes are ≈øo farre from being worthy of having their e≈øtates pre≈øerved by this cour≈øe, that therefore they ≈øhould the rather lo≈øe them, and them≈øelves be the more cruelly and ignominiou≈øly entreated, for being guilty of two horrible crimes; fir≈øt, that whereof they are indited, and for which they refu≈øe to an≈øwer to be legally tryed; the ≈øecond is their contumacious rejecting of all ju≈øt and legall cour≈øes of tryall, and active obedient ≈øubjection to authority, requiring their ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion.

Touching their ≈øecond and third motives of ≈øtanding mute, with re≈øpect onely to the matter of their worldly credit, the ≈øame is meere folly; becau≈øe by this cour≈øe they doe farre more di≈øcredit and make them≈øelves infamous; in regard that ip≈øo facto they make them≈øelves guilty of a double crime; both of that whereof they are indited, and al≈øo of contumacy again≈øt authority and law; and the death of pre≈ø≈øing that they ≈øuffer, is the ju≈øt reward of their ob≈øtinate mutene≈ø≈øe, be≈øides all their other demerits: it is chiefly the morall manner of dying that is comfortable and honourable, wherein ≈øuch mutes are wanting.

Their fourth motive, which is from feare, proud impaciencie of ≈øuffering uniu≈øtly, or inimically by others, in the cour≈øe of ordinary legall triall, is mo≈øt vaine: for why ≈øhould we wrong our ≈øelves, that we may e≈øcape being wronged, or in≈øulted over by others? this was the practi≈øe
