Such mutes are not onely guilty of their owne deaths; but al≈øo, by that cour≈øe they ≈øubiect them≈øelves to everla≈øting damnation both in ≈øoule and body: both becau≈øe they die impenitently and wilfully in a ≈øinfull way of their owne ob≈øtinate procurement and choi≈øe: and al≈øo doe ca≈øt away their ≈øoules in departing this world in uncharitable manner, without either confe≈ø≈øion or clearing of them≈øelves in lawfull manner, of the crimes for which they are indited and arraigned: and ≈øo peri≈øh as outlaws again≈øt both God and humane authority; who≈øe fact is equivalent to direct ≈øelf-murder, by wittingly and willingly doing that unlawfull act, which they know will inevitably ≈øubiect them to death, without hope of e≈øcape.

div.head: ¬ß. 6. About malefactors arraigned for crimes; how they are to an≈øwer to the que≈øtion Guilty or not guilty.
div.p:
Que≈øtion 2. A ≈øecond que≈øtion con≈øiderable about the fore≈øaid ≈øubject is touching malefactors, indited and arraigned at the barre of Iu≈øtice, before a lawfull magi≈øtrate, to be tryed upon their lives for ≈øome capitall crimes that they have done; as petty trea≈øon, burglary, murder, or the like, touching their lives; whether, when they hold up their hands at the barre, and are in legall manner asked the que≈øtion whether they be guilty, or not guilty of ≈øuch a fact whereof they are indited; and which indeed they them≈øelves know they have done: whether (I ≈øay) are
they bound in con≈øcience, and may they an≈øwer affirmatively that they are guilty: without any danger of being indirectly guilty of ≈øelf-murder?

An≈øwer. They that confe≈ø≈øe them≈øelves to be guilty are indirect ≈øelf-murderers.For re≈øolution of this que≈øtion I an≈øwer, that when a man is accu≈øed of ≈øuch a capitall crime, and is therefore brought to a legall triall, whereunto he is ≈øubjected for finding, or not finding him to be guilty of that fact, upon the verdict of which enquiry, Law and Authority is ≈øatisfied, and determines their proceeding with the party; for him, upon that que≈øtion, whether he be guilty, or not guilty; before the triall, to confe≈ø≈øe him≈øelfe to be guilty; ≈øo, by his owne onely witne≈ø≈øe and verdict ca≈øting him≈øelfe upon the lo≈ø≈øe of his life, hee may in a ≈øtrict con≈øtruction, and in ≈øome ≈øort be accompted culpable of indirect ≈øelf-murder.

Exception.Except it be in ca≈øe to ≈øave innocents, from ≈øuffering wrongfully, for his fault, or that it be for greater good of the State, of the Church, or of his owne Soule; when the fact can no otherwi≈øe be knowne, or proved again≈øt him, but by his owne confe≈ø≈øion.

Touching a voluntary and full confe≈ø≈øion after conviction and condemnation I know none that is not of opinion, that it is nece≈ø≈øary for the ≈øalvation of the malefactors ≈øoule, although his body do peri≈øh as Achan did, Io≈øhua 7.20.

That ≈øuch an affirmative an≈øwer of guilty, to that que≈øtion, makes the an≈øwerer, I ≈øay in ≈øome ≈øort, indirectly guilty of ≈øelf-murder (although they are not the wor≈øt men, morally con≈øidered, that doe ≈øo;) I will make it plaine.

Rea≈øons. 1. Fir≈øt, a malefactor, by ≈øuch an affirmative an≈øwer, anticipates, and deprives him≈øelfe of that legall triall, whereby it were po≈ø≈øible for him to have e≈øcaped, and not to have beene found guilty of that capitall fact, for which he is indited; and therefore, by dying upon his owne onely confe≈ø≈øion, witne≈ø≈øe and verdict; which hee
needed not to have done, he is guilty of indirect ≈øelf-murder.

Now, for a man that hath, in danger of life, lawfull choi≈øe of two waies; the one mo≈øt certainely mortall, the other more doubtfully deadly; if hee choo≈øe, and peri≈øh by the former, he is indirectly a ≈øelf murderer; becau≈øe, he willingly rejected the latter and ≈øafer, whereby he might have lived: thus it is in this ca≈øe of an≈øwering guilty, before the triall.

2. Secondly, it is a naturall axiome, that no man is bound to betray him≈øelf: Nemo tenetur prodere ≈øeip≈øum; qui≈ø
que tenetur defendere ≈øeip≈øum. ∆≤nu≈øqui≈ø
que prae≈øupponitur e≈ø≈øe bonus, donec probetur e≈ø≈øe malus. and that every one is tied to defend him≈øelfe. A Traytour (≈øaies D. Kellet Mi≈øcel. li. 1. p. 164.) may without ≈øin plead not guilty; that is, not proved guilty at your barre; where, every one is pre≈øuppo≈øed to be good, untill he is proved to be bad. I am not guilty ≈øo farre, that I am bound to accu≈øe my ≈øelfe: and this is (≈øaies hee) the allowed generall acceptation of that u≈øance.

For further manife≈øtation hereof, it is to be con≈øidered, that the que≈øtion and an≈øwer is made in a humane civill Court, wherein hee is demanded, not whether in Con≈øcience, but whether in Law he be guilty; whereby he is bound to confe≈ø≈øe no more again≈øt his life, than can be legally proved again≈øt him; ≈øpecially ≈øeeing he an≈øwers not upon oath, or adjuration; which binds the examinate, or pri≈øoner at the barre, in con≈øcience, upon obligation of religion, to depo≈øe the truth concerning him≈øelfe, knowne onely to that deponent; and according to who≈øe owne te≈øtimony hee is to be acquited. or condemned;Of an≈øwering upon oath about crimes concerning a mans ≈øelfe. but, this being mo≈øt unrea≈øonable, to make a man witne≈ø≈øe, Jurie, and Judge in his owne cau≈øe; about and for things ≈øecret, to bring him to publick judicature and cen≈øure, it is not in u≈øe among us.

The ≈øeeming contrary practi≈øe in this Kingdome, is (as I take it) onely in Courts of Con≈øcience, having more ≈øpirituall power; to bee u≈øed ≈øpecially for the good of mens ≈øoules, without blood-≈øhedding, or danger of their
lives; who are not required upon oath to depo≈øe of criminall matters concerning them≈øelves; but where there are fir≈øt promoters and accu≈øers offering to prove the ≈øame: in which ca≈øe, for the better informing and re≈øolving of the Court, from the con≈øcience of the accu≈øed; in favour of whom, it is originally allowed, from the ≈øupreme governour and Judge of that Judicature, that hee may an≈øwer his knowledge upon his oath to the articles of his accu≈øation; not with legall intention, by that cour≈øe, to make him unnaturally to accu≈øe or condemne him≈øelfe, where none others can, or are about to doe the ≈øame; but for an≈øwere in his owne defence touching the things that he is accu≈øed of; thereby, either to make his innocency to appeare, if he be blamele≈ø≈øe; or otherwi≈øe, by his owne confe≈ø≈øion of his faults, for the good of the Church, and his ≈øoules health to di≈øcover the danger, and ≈øhew his ingenuity that hee may repent, amend, and find favour.

Objection 1. It may be objected, that ≈øuch a malefactor is bound, in this ca≈øe, to an≈øwere, according to his owne con≈øcience and knowledge, that he is guilty: becau≈øe, if he an≈øwer not guilty, when he is indeed guilty, he lies: which is unlawfull for him to doe.

An≈øwer 1. To this I reply; fir≈øt, that the malefactors an≈øwer is to be made according to the intention of the Law, and of the Iudge that moves the que≈øtion:
Cont. Ma ‚Ä¢ c. oÃÑ. lib. 4. Ju≈øta & digna prae≈øcriptio e≈øt in omni quae≈øtione, ad propo≈øitum interrogationis pertinere debere ≈øen≈øum re≈øpen≈øionis. aliud con≈øulenti, aliud re ≈øpondere, dementis e≈øt. Sen≈øus re≈øpoÃÑ≈øionis non e≈øt ad aliud dirigendus qu im ad propo≈øaum interrogationis. according as Tertullian ≈øaith: it is a ju≈øt and worthy rule, that in every que≈øtion the an≈øwer ≈øhould bee applied to the ≈øame ≈øen≈øe and purpo≈øe, to which the interrogation is made.

p.hi: To an≈øwer of one thing, when he is asked another, is the part of a mad man.
Agaeine, the ≈øen≈øe of the an≈øwer is not to be directed to any other thing, than that which was propounded in the interrogation.

div.p:
Now, the Iudge propounding, according to Law, this que≈øtion to the pri≈øoner at the barre, art thou guilty,
or not guilty of this felony, or the like; intends not that he ≈øhould an≈øwer, from his onely con≈øcience, guilty; which is unnaturall and ≈øu≈øpitious, for him to give witne≈ø≈øe and virdict again≈øt him≈øelfe, to the taking away of his owne life; but that he ≈øhould an≈øwer not guilty, in law, at the barre whereof hee ≈øtands arraigned, that ≈øo, for finding of him guilty of that whereof hee is indited, hee may legally bee put upon the triall of God and the Countrey.

For the que≈øtion being propounded in a disjunctive propo≈øition, art thou guilty, or art thou not guilty? both gives a free choi≈øe which of them to an≈øwer, and al≈øo puts in minde, and poynts rather to the latter, as more naturall and equall, than to in≈øi≈øt upon the former.

It is a free and lawfull election offered, in mercy and favour to the pri≈øoner, from the King by the Iudge, for the indicted per≈øon to choo≈øe which he will; whether voluntarily to confe≈ø≈øe the fact, or rather to put him≈øelfe upon the triall of God and the Countrey for the ≈øame.

His negative an≈øwer of not guilty, is but his choi≈øe and imbracing of the latter triall; which is mo≈øt agreeable to nature, to the Law, and the Kings favour and mercy, in this ca≈øe; which he can no otherwi≈øe have, but by fir≈øt pleading to the indictment, not guilty; And ≈øo, his an≈øwer and plea of not guilty is no lye, although hee have done the fact, whereof he pleads he is not guilty, and for triall thereof puts him≈øelfe upon God and the Country.

Objection 2. If it be againe objected that ≈øeeing the Law that makes this disjunctive que≈øtion, accepts of the pri≈øoners affirmative an≈øwer; and thereupon condemnes and executes him; (as David did with the Amalckite, upon his confe≈ø≈øion that he had ≈ølaine Saul, 2 Sam. 1.16.) it ≈øeemes to be lawfull and requi≈øite for all malefactors to an≈øwer to the que≈øtion affirmatively; touching the things that in con≈øcience they are guilty of.

An≈øwer.I an≈øwer, it is lawfull and fit for Magi≈øtrates to u≈øe
many meanes to winde out the truth of facts from delinquents, which malefactors are not bound, upon ≈øuch que≈øtions or inqui≈øition, to reveale again≈øt their owne lives: in regard, that every one ≈øeverally is to order their practi≈øe and cour≈øe, according to the rules proper and pertinent to their owne conditions and callings.

The Law indeed accepts of the malefactors an≈øwer of, Guilty; and accordingly proceeds to condemne and execute him; becau≈øe, by his confe≈ø≈øion, giving te≈øtimony and verdict again≈øt him≈øelfe, he cuts of, prevents and excludes him≈øelfe from triall by others, whereby he might be either cleared, or condemned; in regard, that it is ju≈øtly ≈øuppo≈øed that none other can know a man and his actions ≈øo well as him≈øelfe doth: and therefore, the Law for ea≈øe, certainty, & other politick re≈øpects, doth permit and accept of ≈øuch an affirmative an≈øwer, but neither commands, nor commends it: becau≈øe, the Law takes notice of things, and cen≈øures them politically, and not theologically con≈øidered.

Objection 3. Thirdly, it may perhaps be here replied, that when a man (be≈øides his owne knowledge of his capitall fact) hath, upon examination before a Iu≈øtice, confe≈ø≈øed the fact under his hand, which is produced again≈øt him at the Triall, how can he plead negatively to the inditement, Not guilty, without lying either in the former, or in the latter; ≈øeeing of coÃÑtradictioÃÑs of nece≈ø≈øity one mu≈øt be fal≈øe?

An≈øwer.I an≈øwer, that for ≈øuch an one to an≈øwer at the Barre, Not guilty, is not a lie, nor properly a contradiction to his former confe≈ø≈øion; or to his owne knowledge; neither is that negative plea any concealement of the truth, from being then and there knowne, by ≈øuch lawfull meanes, as by Law, and the Iudge, is intended for di≈øcovery of the ≈øame, which is by other evidence than a mans owne confe≈ø≈øion.

For clearing of the truth whereof, it is to be ob≈øerved that the que≈øtion made to him touching his fact, is propounded
to him, and hee charged with the fact, in his Inditement, in ≈øuch a nature and forme of Law termes, as it may be he properly under≈øtands not; as whether he be guilty of that trea≈øon, felony, burglary, or the like? in which re≈øpect, or Law notion, put upon his fact, his life is que≈øtioned, and in danger to bee taken away. And therefore when the que≈øtion requires an an≈øwer touching his fact, as it is ve≈øted in that forme, or Law terme and notion, he lies not, nor contradicts him≈øelfe in an≈øwering negatively, Not guilty.

For, although hee knowes, and hath el≈øewhere confe≈ø≈øed him≈øelfe to bee guilty of the fact, materially con≈øidered in the ≈øub≈øtance of it; yet he may be ignorant (as mo≈øt men are) whether that fact of his, formally con≈øidered, is, or may be found to be trea≈øon, felony, burglary, or the like, as by the inditement it is charged upon him; and in which re≈øpect he is to ≈øuffer death for it, if he do an≈øwer affirmatively. And although he ≈øhould certainly know that his fact were ≈øuch, in con≈øtruction and termes of Law, as, by his Inditement, the ≈øame is charged upon him; yet is he not to an≈øwer affirmatively: becau≈øe, not he, but the pre≈øent impannelled Iury, are the competent and lawfull Iudges to find, or not to find it to be ≈øuch, in that forme, and Law quality.

And therefore, hee is bound in con≈øcience to an≈øwer negatively, Not guilty of ≈øuch a fact under that forme, or terme and Law notion; whereby, and wherefore his life, in that re≈øpect, may be taken away.

And ≈øo, by pleading not guilty, hee lies not, nor contradicts him≈øelfe; but thereby takes the allowed benefit of putting it to a legall triall, whether his fact ≈øhall bee found again≈øt him in that ≈øen≈øe and forme, as, in tho≈øe Law termes, he is charged with the ≈øame in his inditement; and in which re≈øpect onely he can be put to death for it; which cour≈øe if hee ≈øhould not u≈øe of an≈øwering Not guilty; but that he ≈øhould ≈øtand mute, or an≈øwer
affirmatively Guilty, he ≈øhould be indirectly a ≈øelf-murderer: as hath beene ≈øhewed.

Repli.But then, it may be further replied, when ≈øuch a malefactor ≈øhall (after his pleading to the Inditement, not guilty,) bee publickly examined by the Iudge about his fact, con≈øidered in the ≈øub≈øtance of it, without the ve≈øture of ≈øuch termes, or Law notions put upon it; how can he an≈øwer negatively, again≈øt his con≈øcience, and former confe≈ø≈øion before a Ju≈øtice.

An≈øwer.I an≈øwer, fir≈øt, the Iudges que≈øtions to ≈øuch an one, at publick triall, (after his negative plea to the bill of Inditement,) are mini≈øtred in favour of the party arraigned; both that he may, upon better advi≈øement, traver≈øe his former confe≈ø≈øion, by his negative an≈øwer, contrary to the which confe≈ø≈øion hee is allowed at the barre to plead not guilty. And al≈øo, that hee may not bee ca≈øt, or condemned, upon any evidence, or verdit of others again≈øt him; before he bee heard an≈øwer for him≈øelfe, what hee can ≈øay for the negative in his owne defence, again≈øt the affirmative evidence, or ≈øentence produced again≈øt him: where it is to be con≈øidered that, the primary intention and expectation of the Iudge in his que≈øtions at triall is, that, by the pri≈øoners an≈øwers, hee may the better decerne the truth, or fal≈øhood of the evidence of others again≈øt him, and how him≈øelfe may proceed in accepting of the verdit, and in giving judgement according to ju≈øtice, and not thereby to wring affirmative an≈øwers from the arraigned, again≈øt their owne lives; when others cannot touch them; which is contrary to the Law of nature, and of God.

Secondly, it is alwaies to be ob≈øerved by every malefactor that in his an≈øwers hee doe not, to ≈øave his life make any lie, neither directly, nor yet by equivocation, or mentall re≈øervation: and al≈øo, that he doe not ≈øo confe≈ø≈øe the truth again≈øt his owne life, that he ≈øhould thereby make him≈øelfe guilty of indirect ≈øelf-murder.

Both which evils hee may avoid by the medium or middle cour≈øe, either of traver≈øe, and demurrer delaying and putting off the Iudge and Iury from him≈øelfe, to informe them≈øelves by other evidences than his owne: or el≈øe by ≈øilence (after his generall negative plea of not guilty,) replying nothing to ≈øuch que≈øtions, as the an≈øwers thereof may intangle him, either in a lie, or in indirect ≈øelf-murder, after which manner of an≈øwering nothing, our ble≈ø≈øed Saviour behaved him≈øelf before Pilate, Iohn 19.9.

Although that ≈øuch ≈øilence, or not an≈øwering directly may be con≈øtrued to be an acknowledgement of the fact, that he is indited for; yet thereby he ≈øhall not be active, but onely pa≈ø≈øive in being found guilty, and ≈øo condemned to die; whereby he ≈øhall be free of indirect ≈øelf-murder, in that re≈øpect.

The confe≈ø≈øion of a malefactor, upon examination before a Iu≈øtice, when the ≈øame is again≈øt his owne life, may bee con≈øtrued to have beene either ra≈øhly and unwarrantably done by the Examinate; again≈øt which therefore he is allowed at his Triall to plead not guilty: or el≈øe that hee did the ≈øame upon ≈øome motives and rea≈øons of con≈øcience, for the good and ≈øalvation of his ≈øoule: which are things properly belonging to another Court.

And therefore, in humane Courts of A≈ø≈øize, the que≈øtions and an≈øwers (in this ca≈øe) reach not ≈øo farre as to rack, or di≈øcover the con≈øcience of a man, to the taking away of his owne life, by his owne confe≈ø≈øion, which the Law of nature and of God binds a man to pre≈øerve.

Although a capitall malefactor is bound in con≈øcience not to lie in his an≈øwers, yet he is not bound to reveale all the truth he knowes again≈øt him≈øelfe; ≈øpecially where hee is not tied by ≈øome ≈øpeciall divine bond ≈øo to doe.

A negative an≈øwer at triall is as ≈øtrong to ≈øave a man, as his former affirmative in confe≈ø≈øion before a Iu≈øtice can be to condemne him; except either he publickly at
his triall acknowledge the ≈øame; or that there be ≈øome other proofe, or evidence again≈øt him.

And therefore I conclude, that it is not nece≈ø≈øary in con≈øcience that what≈øoever truth ≈øuch a man (in this ca≈øe) hath once confe≈ø≈øed, that he ≈øhould every where, and at all times, upon interrogatories to be an≈øwered at will, confe≈ø≈øe the ≈øame with perill of his life; but that hee may be ≈øilent, or forbeare to an≈øwer otherwi≈øe than he is bound by the lawes of the Court where he an≈øwers.

For, if another be bound to keepe clo≈øe a mans confe≈ø≈øion made to him of his ≈øecret faults, that man is not compellable to di≈øclo≈øe the ≈øame of him≈øelfe, ≈øpecially again≈øt his owne life; when he cannot doe the ≈øame without being guilty of indirect ≈øelf-murder; as in this ca≈øe I have ≈øhewed by the rules of divinity and right rea≈øon, for re≈øolving of weak con≈øciences in this point; not intermedling to argue and determine the ≈øame by the rules of the Common-law of this Kingdome, which is impertinent to my profe≈ø≈øion, and beyond my under≈øtanding; and therefore I leave that worke to the learned of that mo≈øt Honourable profe≈ø≈øion; to who≈øe cognizance this ≈øubject (legally con≈øidered) doth appertaine.

div.head: ¬ß. 7. Of indirect ≈øelf-murder by commi≈øsion.
div.p: The ≈øecond degree of indirect ≈øelf-murder is by commi≈ø≈øion, in divers branches. The ≈øecond meanes of indirect ≈øelf-murder is by a cour≈øe of commi≈ø≈øion, or of doing things, unlawfully tending to bring a man to his death; which is a degree gro≈ø≈øer than the former, and con≈øi≈øts in divers branches.

1.Abu≈øe of lawfull things. Fir≈øt, by abu≈øing lawfull things, in tran≈øgre≈ø≈øing due moderation in their u≈øe; for time, mea≈øure, and manner; falling into extreames, either of defect, or of exce≈ø≈øe, or of un≈øea≈øonablene≈ø≈øe: which is done two wayes. 1.As meate, drinke, &c. Fir≈øt, in things both re≈øpecting the body, and in the acts about them: as in eating to gluttony, and drinking to drunkenne≈ø≈øe; u≈øing labour and recreations to ≈øurfeiting: and al≈øo
in things re≈øpecting the minde; as in the over≈øtraining, and ≈øurcharging of the thoughts, fancy, and under≈øtanding; 2.Di≈øtemperature of the minde. in the immoderate di≈øtemperature of the affections, and pa≈ø≈øions of the minde, ≈øuffocating or wa≈øting the ≈øpirits by exce≈ø≈øe of choller, griefe, fretfulne≈ø≈øe, and the like; which being let loo≈øe, and extended beyond the bankes of their due moderation, doe often prove mortall, and meanes of indirect ≈øelf-murder, when they are willingly and indulgently entertained, and given way to: It is a hard thing for a man to u≈øe meanes, and not to abu≈øe them; which cau≈øes many a mans table to become a ≈ønare to him, and a trap
P≈øal. 69.22., and ≈øhortens his time upon earth.

2. Self-mutilation Secondly, indirectly, a man may be guilty of ≈øelf-murder, by needle≈ø≈øe mutilating of him≈øelfe, and cutting off any of his members, (as Origen did) to the hurt and danger of his life; which, by the pre≈øervation of ≈øuch a member, might have beene in more ≈øafety; for, lifes perfection is in the perfection of the whole body. Notwith≈øtanding, for the ≈øafety of the whole, a man may lawfully and nece≈ø≈øarily cut off a member; which cannot be pre≈øerved without manife≈øt danger of thereby lo≈øing his life; but, neither to puni≈øh a ≈øin pa≈øt, nor to prevent a ≈øin to come, may a man de≈øtroy or cut off any of his members, whereby he may be le≈ø≈øe able to doe the offices and duties for which God hath given him the ≈øame; ≈øeeing that both for cha≈øti≈øement, and prevention of ≈øin, God hath appointed other morall meanes, which wee are to u≈øe, and therein to depend upon God for the ≈øucce≈ø≈øe; for not in mans forced di≈øability to act ≈øin, but in the renovation of the heart con≈øi≈øts true ≈øanctification: Note. that of pulling out the right eye, and of cutting off the right hand, Mat. 5.29, 30. is meant of morall mortification, whereby tho≈øe members are made u≈øele≈ø≈øe, and as if they were not, to any unlawfull u≈øe.

4. Vnthriftine≈ø≈øe. Fourthly, this indirect ≈øelf-murder is committed by wilfull unthriftine≈ø≈øe and prodigality, whereby a man provides not, but mi≈øpends the meanes of his livelihood, and ≈øo ≈øubjects him≈øelfe and his to the perill of famine,

div.head: The fir≈øt Ca≈øe, of Braves and Gallants.
div.p: Ca≈øe 1. Concerning Braves. Fir≈øt, when any doe out of a bravery, and gallantry of ≈øpirit, goe needle≈øly with a charge of money, or of mens per≈øons, or errands; either in the night, through a place haunted and be≈øet with murderous robbers; or, at any time through knowne ambu≈øhments, and ≈øtrong troupes of enemies, above the pa≈ø≈øengers ≈øtrength to re≈øi≈øt, or e≈øcape; whereby, if they fall, they are guilty of this indirect ≈øelf-murder.

div.head: Concerning purcha≈øe and re≈øcue.
div.p:
Ca≈øe 2. Secondly, when any doe, out of over-great affection to worldly goods, make de≈øperate attempts, with the apparent perill of their lives, either to get goods; either by violent taking them from others, as theeves and ≈øpoilers doe; or, by labour in their callings aboveÃÑ that which with their health they are able to endure: or el≈øe, by their de≈øperate adventuring to ≈øave, or recover their goods out of fire, or water; or from, and out of the hands of their enemies; with the ca≈øting away of their owne lives; above all meanes and ≈øtrength that in this ca≈øe they have to ≈øave them; in ≈øuch undertakings beyond
all warrantable calling:Exception. within neither of the≈øe two ca≈øes are we to re≈øtraine, or bound the divine-heroicke enterpri≈øes of ≈øuch as by ≈øupernaturall in≈øtinct, or power, doe undertake tran≈øcendent enterpri≈øes, above the allowance of ordinary rules: as David to kil Goliah 1 Sam. 17.32., and Ionathan and his Armour-bearer to invade a whole Garri≈øon of the Phili≈øtims 1 Sam. 14.6.. Such men mu≈øt have both a calling, by divine inward in≈øtinct, motion, and qualification; and al≈øo, a ≈øtrong well grounded faith, in a≈ø≈øurance of Gods a≈ø≈øi≈øtance: as the Scripture tells us, how ≈øuch, through faith ≈øubdued Kingdomes, e≈øcaped the edge of the ≈øword, out of weakene≈ø≈øe were made ≈øtrong, waxed valiant in fight, turned to flight the armies of the Aliens: Heb, 11.33, 34.

div.head: Concerning ≈øome ≈øouldiers.
div.p:
Ca≈øe 3. Thirdly, when ≈øelf-conceited, wilfull, foole-hardy men will fight again≈øt their enemies, upon de≈øperate di≈øadvantages; and imminent perill of death; when they are neither forced to it by unavoidable nece≈ø≈øity; nor are warranted by command of ≈øuch ≈øuperiours as either have ab≈øolute power over them of life and death; or can a≈ø≈øure them, or give them the victory, Numb. 14.40. ∆≤≈ø
que ad finem. (as God often did to the I≈øraelites, fighting by his command, or approbation upon ≈øtrange di≈øadvantages) yea, when they cannot probably come off with the ≈øafety of their lives; then that is a cour≈øe of indirect ≈øelf-murder.

div.head: Concerning Mariners.
div.p:
Ca≈øe 4. The fourth Ca≈øe is of tho≈øe that trade by Sea, who often runne into mortall and de≈øperate adventures, out of eagerne≈ø≈øe to make their voyages; either putting to Sea in ≈øuch weather, and ≈øea≈øons as is like to endanger all; or putting for the Port, upon de≈øperate hazards of mi≈øcarying
by ≈øtormes, ≈øands, or rocks, or running pre≈øumptuou≈øly into the danger of Pyrates; or other mortall ingagement by Sea, either through wilfull negligence, or through ≈øelf-confidence of skill, or power more than they have, ≈øo tempting God.

Ob≈øerve.The true occa≈øion of which mi≈øcariages of men by Sea, is often given by Merchants upon the Land; who prai≈øe and re≈øpect men for fortunate and valiant according to the ≈øucce≈ø≈øe,‚Äîcareat ≈øucce≈ø≈øibus opto, Qui≈øquisab eventu facta probanda putat. and the event of their cour≈øes, without re≈øpect to the due rules of the managing the ≈øame; which makes many a man come ≈øhort home, by adventuring to plea≈øe their Merchants, contrary to the rules of art and wi≈ødome.

Note.In this ca≈øe I would advi≈øe men, rather to looke to do what they may warrantably ju≈øtifie; and may therein have peace in their con≈øciences, although the ≈øucce≈ø≈øe an≈øwer not their de≈øire; than to endeavour contrary to wi≈ødome and art, to plea≈øe their owners and Merchants by ≈øuch cour≈øes of de≈øperate and unwarrantable adventures: as (if they or their charge mi≈øcary therein,) will over-cloud them with ju≈øt blame & ignominie, and will bereave them of that comfort in their con≈øciences, which ≈øhould cheere and uphold them under their cro≈ø≈øes; a cour≈øe of accidentall good ≈øucce≈ø≈øe, and a cour≈øe of direct ill ≈øucce≈ø≈øe, are not ≈øo to be compared together; that for the former a man ≈øhould venture upon the latter; with the guilt of ≈øelf-murder to be imputed to him, if therein he doe peri≈øh.

div.head: Concerning Duells.
div.p:
Ca≈øe 5. The fifth Ca≈øe of de≈øperate adventure, is of tho≈øe that undertake Duells; or doe give, or accept challenges of ≈øingle combats, upon their owne private motion, for private revenge; or for ≈øuppo≈øed maintenance of impeached honour; who, if they peri≈øh in the attempt, or by
meanes of the con≈ølict, are guilty of more than indirect ≈øelf-murder: becau≈øe, that cour≈øe ≈øo unwarrantably, and needlefly undertaken, is commonly where the wronged may have better redre≈ø≈øe, with le≈ø≈øe adventure of life;Duellers what they b. and tho≈øe Duellers, or ≈øingle combattants doe, by ≈øuch challenges, ≈øhew them≈øelves to be lawle≈ø≈øe contemners of authority; who≈øe allowance they have not (as they ought) for ≈øuch a triall by battle to make the ≈øame ju≈øt; but by u≈øurpation they make them≈øelves Kings, (in contempt and prejudice of lawfull authority) in erecting a tribunall for Iu≈øtice, of their owne making, in their own ca≈øe; where them≈øelves alone are Parties, Iurie, Witne≈ø≈øe, Iudge and Sheriffe: whereas it is the prerogative of Kings to make warre and peace, and independently to execute ju≈øtice under God.

It al≈øo argueth in them, both great folly, and impotency of minde, ≈øo lightly to adventure or give away their lives; a price ≈øo far exceeding the worth of the purcha≈øe that they contend for, and which they may have decided farre better, without any ≈øuch de≈øperate danger; and al≈øo it proclaimes their pu≈øillanimity and weakne≈ø≈øe, in that they cannot beare cro≈ø≈øes and injuries. And finally, it makes their cau≈øe apparently unju≈øt; when they pa≈ø≈øe by, or neglect a peaceable triall by equall ju≈øtice and rea≈øon; and doe put it to be decided by bodily ≈øtrength, and chance of warre; in a cour≈øe more be≈øeeming bea≈øts than men. It ≈øeemes that ≈øuch men doe account them≈øelves and their lives little worth, and that they are weary of living; who ≈øo ra≈øhly expo≈øe the ≈øame by thra≈øonicall provocations and darings, to be taken away and de≈øtroyed in ≈øuch a manner; wherein, having abandoned the command of rea≈øon, they become bea≈øts; and becomming ≈ølaves to their vile≈øt pa≈ø≈øions of fury, madne≈ø≈øe, cruelty, and the like. (whereby they are overcome, who would in that cour≈øe overcome others) Duellers degenerate into incarnate devills: And while they thus contend to gain
or maintaine reputation of Honour and Valour by this mo≈øt di≈øhonourable and ba≈øe bruti≈øh cour≈øe of impetuous ≈øelf-revenge by Duells; they ju≈øtly lo≈øe that for which they contend, and otherwi≈øe might have had.

div.head: Concerning de≈øperate attempts upon daring and wagering.
div.p: Ca≈øe 6. The ≈øixt ca≈øe of de≈øperate hazzard and adventure, whereby men may indirectly be ≈øelf-murderers, 1. About daring. is in the point of provocation by others, for proofe of their courage and valour, challenging them to dare to attempt the effecting of ≈øome deadly enterpri≈øe beyond all warrantable calling, or lawfull meanes ≈øafely and lawfully to accompli≈øh the ≈øame: as, for a man needle≈øly to conflict with a Lyon, to run over rocks; to provoke, or a≈ø≈øault Adver≈øaries too potent for him to re≈øi≈øt, or offend, with ≈øafety of his life; or, upon ≈øuch daring to doe ≈øome capitall act or mi≈øchiefe, whereby he is mo≈øt like to peri≈øh; and not thereby without ju≈øt imputation to him≈øelfe of guiltine≈ø≈øe of his owne death, in regard of the unlawfulne≈ø≈øe of that his cour≈øe, wherein hee cannot warrantably looke for any ble≈ø≈øing, or protection from God: neither doe ≈øuch unju≈øtifiable daring-practi≈øes argue any true fortitude and valour, but onely bewraie temerarious audaciou≈øne≈ø≈øe; which is, in exce≈ø≈øe, contrary to fortitude: becau≈øe, true valour is ≈øeene in couragiou≈øly undertaking and accompli≈øhing dangerous performances upon advi≈øed rea≈øon, by lawfull cour≈øes, to ju≈øt and nece≈ø≈øary ends; but ra≈øh audaciou≈øne≈ø≈øe in daring to doe unwarrantable attempts is manife≈øt, by the unrea≈øonablene≈ø≈øe and unnece≈ø≈øarine≈ø≈øe thereof, undertaken upon unadvi≈øed pa≈ø≈øion, and foole-hardy pre≈øumption; with arrogancy in the manner of accompli≈øhing, and folly in the end of it.

A truly valorous man manife≈øts his fortitude by his
unconquerablene≈ø≈øe upon any provocation of darring, to doe any thing that is not fit and warrantable for him to undertake upon good grounds and rea≈øon; that if he bee cro≈ø≈øed, or peri≈øh in atchieving it, hee may have honour and peace, and no way be guilty of his owne death: So that, although daring audaciou≈øne≈ø≈øe exceeds true fortitude in unwarrantably adventuring beyond it; yet it comes ≈øhort of valorous fortitude in the grounds, and manner of enterpri≈øing, and of con≈øequent effects and honour of it.

A valorous man is his owne ma≈øter, in di≈øpo≈øing of him≈øelfe and his actions about dangerous enterpri≈øes, according to his owne minde, ≈øound rea≈øon, and advi≈øed re≈øolution. Whereas, an audacious man is but as a ≈øervant to others, by who≈øe will and daring provocations he orders him≈øelf and his actions, as they li≈øt, at their plea≈øure, and for their ≈øervice; that he mu≈øt needs doe what≈øoever de≈øperate attempts they will dare him to doe, even to the perill of the lo≈ø≈øe of his life, without any lawfull rea≈øon and calling.

2. Wagering.To this ca≈øe al≈øo belongs de≈øperate undertakings with danger of life upon wagers; as for a man, either upon a naked contract for a certaine ≈øumme, or upon a≈ø≈øump≈øit of ten for one, or the like, to be paid to him when he ≈øhall have performed ≈øome de≈øperate hazardous enterpri≈øe agreed upon, for him in that con≈øideration onely to undertake and attempt the ≈øame with the danger of the lo≈ø≈øe of his life: as to walke under the water; to cro≈ø≈øe the Ocean in a Wherry: in a few dayes to goe backward, or blindfold a long journey in a dangerous way, or ≈øome ≈øuch unrea≈øonable, needle≈ø≈øe, dangerous, mad, and idle vaine-glorious prancks, with adventure and lo≈ø≈øe of life; whereby ≈øuch are indirectly ≈øelf-murderers; and tho≈øe that lay ≈øuch wagers with them, are acce≈ø≈øary to their death, thereby hireing and provoking them to a mortall cour≈øe of ≈øelf-de≈øtruction. For, ≈øuch a cour≈øe is no warrantable
way and calling of Gods appointment, thereby to adventure, or get goods; and therefore, no ble≈ø≈øing can be therein, nor thereby expected; it is a needle≈ø≈øe tempting of God to commit them≈øelves to ≈øuch a mortall cour≈øe which they may well avoyd, and can looke for no protection in it, nor comfort of the action wherein they peri≈øh; being guilty of their owne death therein. Such de≈øperate enterpri≈øes, upon wagering; whereby a man may lo≈øe his life, proceede either from covetou≈øne≈ø≈øe, to be rich; or from nece≈ø≈øity, to live: but by unlawfull meanes never de≈øtinated of God to that end, neither of them can comfortably be expected nor endeavoured: it ≈øeemes that ≈øuch men either value their lives to be little worth, or apprehend their pre≈øent condition to be mo≈øt mi≈øerable; that they preferre the uncertaine attaining of a little lucre and worldly goods before them, and had rather die than live as they are; and therefore goe to ≈øeeke up death, where they can find him, to make an end of their dayes, by this de≈øperate and la≈øt ≈øhift that they doe u≈øe, when otherwi≈øe they cannot live. That man is neere driven, that cannot ≈øub≈øi≈øt but by cour≈øes of ≈øelferuine: and he is very de≈øtitute of good parts and of vertuous actions, that de≈øpaires of better fame and repute in the world; than he can procure by ≈øuch needle≈ø≈øe vaine undertakings and accompli≈øhments; which are but the pa≈øtime of fooles, and the ludibrie and ≈øcorne of the wi≈øe, and uncomfortable vanity and ≈øinne of the performers.

div.head: ¬ß. 11. Of indirect ≈øelf-murder committed by covenant and ≈øociety with per≈øons de≈øtinate to de≈øtruction.
div.p:
6 Branch of indirect ≈øelf-murder by commi≈ø≈øion. The ≈øixt branch of indirect ≈øelf-murder by commi≈ø≈øion, is, by wilfull contracting. and keeping ≈øociety with
tho≈øe, that are under a cur≈øe, and apparent danger of de≈øtruction; whereby all ≈øuch are mo≈øt probably like to ≈øhare with them, that have neere communion with them; which falls out ≈øpecially in three ca≈øes.

Ca≈øe 1. Of leagues. Fir≈øt, when a man unwarrantably enters a league, or bond of neere amity and ≈øociety with per≈øons, Princes, or States worthy of, and (as it were) marked out to de≈øtruction: as Iehoram did contract and keepe with Ahaziah 2 King. 9.27., whereby hee involved and inwrapped him≈øelfe into the ≈øame ruine with him. Which barres not conclu≈øions for commerce of trade; and al≈øo, for intercour≈øe of corre≈øpondency with them, at ≈øuch a di≈øtance and degree, whereby hurt from them may be avoyded, and u≈øe made of them for warrantable advantage; as the Scripture requires, that wee ≈øhould have peace with all men, if it be po≈ø≈øible Heb. 12.14..

Ca≈øe 2.Concerning warre. The ≈øecond ca≈øe of indirect ≈øelf-murdring ≈øociety is, when a man takes up armes, or puts him≈øelfe into military ≈øervice, or joynes with others in warre, offen≈øive, or defen≈øive; either to hinder, or oppre≈ø≈øe equity and truth; or, in oppo≈øition of Gods Church, to prejudice, or oppre≈ø≈øe the Go≈øpell and true religion; by this latter fighting again≈øt and provoking God; and by the former, irritating mankind ju≈øtly to de≈øtroy ≈øuch, as goe about to overthrow Gods Kingdome, and humane ju≈øtice, on earth; without which the world cannot ≈øub≈øi≈øt; in which cour≈øe of Combination, or ≈øociety, who≈øoever peri≈øhes is guilty of indirect ≈øelf-murder, by death of his owne unwarrantable procurement.

Although warre bee lawfull, yet it is a violent cour≈øe of ju≈øtice, the deci≈øion whereof is hereby ca≈øt upon the omnipotent Lord God, for him to determine the ≈øame, as he plea≈øes, by victory, or vanqui≈øhment. And therefore, none ≈øhould dare voluntarily to engage him≈øelfe, in that cour≈øe, upon his life, where hee knowes that ju≈øt and powerfull Iudge to bee party for the truth again≈øt him;
le≈øt he peri≈øh by this indirect ≈øelf-murder; whereas, to bee ≈øafe therefrom, wee ≈øhould ever bee party on Gods ≈øide.

Cro≈ø≈øe event of warre. That the event falls out contrary, ≈øo that the Abetters in a good cau≈øe do often fall, and the propugners of an evill do pro≈øper; it comes to pa≈ø≈øe by Gods ≈øpeciall wi≈øe providence, for three cau≈øes.
Rea≈øons. 1. Fir≈øt, to cha≈øti≈øe ≈øome ≈øinnes, or to exerci≈øe ≈øome vertues in the vanqui≈øhed.
2. Secondly, to make men more loath to fall to warre and blood-≈øhed, upon pre≈øumption of their ≈øtrength and cau≈øe, but rather, with ≈øome lo≈ø≈øe, to make peaceable compo≈øition.

3. Thirdly, that God may ≈øhew and exerci≈øe his ab≈øolute ≈øoveraignty over the world; di≈øpo≈øing humane things as he plea≈øes, in the demoli≈øhing and tran≈ølating of Empyres and dominion, by the ruines of one making way for the building of another; that it may be apparent, that by him Kings Raigne; and that as many Principalities and Empires are rai≈øed, and ≈øtand upon the foundation of inva≈øion, latrocinies, rapines, and blood; ≈øo ≈øhall they an≈øwer for the ≈øame, and bee ≈øhaken to peeces, by a divine hand of Iu≈øtice; as wee may ≈øee expre≈ø≈øed by the da≈øhing of the Image to peeces, by that ≈ømall ≈øtone out of the divine hand of God, Daniel 2.33.

Ca≈øe 3. Pre≈øuming into infectious places and company. The third ca≈øe of indirect ≈øelf-murdering ≈øociety is, when men do wilfully pre≈øume, without nece≈ø≈øity, or warrantable calling, into deadly infectious places and companies; wherein, or by which meanes if they mi≈øcarry or peri≈øh, they are guilty of their owne death, in a higher degree of indirect ≈øelf-murder; as al≈øo, are tho≈øe that doe, without a warrantable calling, put them≈øelves into ≈øuch places, or imployments, as doe procure or ha≈øten their deaths.

div.head: ¬ß. 12. Of indirect ≈øelf-murder by doing that, which naturally procures that which kills the doer.
div.p: 7. Branch. Seventhly, if a man doe, willingly and wittingly, any ≈øuch unlawfull act, as proves the cau≈øe, or occa≈øion of that, which by Gods providence in ju≈øt judgement, kills him, or takes away his life; he indirectly murders him≈øelfe: as a drunken man, that falls into a ditch or a pit, and is drowned; breakes his neck off his hor≈øe; dies by ≈øurfeits, or the like: he is in this degree, guilty of his owne death: for the cau≈øe of the cau≈øe is the cau≈øe of the effect: Cau≈øa cau≈øae e≈øt cau≈øa cau≈øati. ≈øuch a mans precedent unlawfull cour≈øe, or di≈øpo≈øition, is ≈øo farre from excu≈øing the con≈øequent effect; that in a ≈øort it doubles his ≈øin: a man that kills another, when he is drunk, is not excu≈øed; but hanged when he is ≈øober.

div.head: ¬ß. 13. Of indirect ≈øelf-murder by doing of capitall crimes again≈øt humane Lawes and authority.
div.p:
8. Branch. Capital crimes. Eightly, men doe commit indirect ≈øelf-murder, by their breaking out into capitall cour≈øes and crimes; in tran≈øgre≈ø≈øing and violating capitall good humane Lawes, the penalty whereof is death, whereby they bring them≈øelves under the ≈øword of Iu≈øtice, thereby to lo≈øe their lives; as do Traitors, and rebellious per≈øons again≈øt the King, State, or Kingdome: ≈øpoylers of other mens lives, or goods; as murderers, Pirates, Robbers, and the like: which is a thing both ju≈øt and expedient in rea≈øon, that for pre≈øerving & upholding of the whole body publick; or the more noble parts thereof, inferiour and rotten members ≈øhould ≈øuffer amputation; who, by their owne vile practi≈øes, have ≈øubjected them≈øelves to the penall cen≈øure of death: by their mi≈øde≈øerving cour≈øes, being indirectly ≈øelf-murderers; their blood being upon them≈øelves, and not upon the Magi≈øtrate, by who≈øe hands they ju≈øtly
fall, as is apparent; Levit. 20.9. where the blood of him that was put to death, for cur≈øing his Father, is ≈øaid to be upon him≈øelfe: and 2 Sam. 1.16. touching him that David killed, for ≈øaying that hee had ≈ølaine Saul, he ≈øaid that his blood was upon his head: as al≈øo, 1 King. 2.32, 37. touching Ioab, for his murder; and Sbimei, for his railing; it is ≈øaid that their blood was upon their owne heads; for that they were the wilfull meritorious cau≈øe, although not the immediate in≈øtruments of their owne deaths.

And ≈øo thus, all men that die by the merits of their owne actions, morally, or civilly con≈øidered, are murderers of their owne naturall lives and bodies, as man may truly be ≈øaid to be the overthrower of the ≈øalvation of his owne ≈øoule, by the merits of his owne ≈øins.

div.head: ¬ß. 14. Of indirect ≈øelf-murder by wilfull tran≈øgre≈øsion of Gods Lawes.
div.p: 9. Branch. Tran≈øgre≈ø≈øion again≈øt Gods Law. Ninthly, men indirectly murder their owne bodies, by wilfully and impenitently walking in a cour≈øe of tran≈øgre≈ø≈øion of Gods Law; in ≈øuch kinds and degrees, as are accompanied with fearefull threatnings of death and de≈øtruction, to bee inflicted, not onely upon the ≈øoules, but al≈øo upon the bodies of ≈øuch tran≈øgre≈ø≈øours, by fearefull judgments, even in this life, as we ≈øee it was done to Pharaoh: which is performed two waies.

1. Kills after a naturall manner. Fir≈øt, in a phy≈øicall, or naturall manner, by the very nature and act of ≈øome ≈øinnes them≈øelves immediatly wa≈øting; filling the body with di≈øea≈øes, and at la≈øt killing it: as, by drunkenne≈ø≈øe and gluttony, di≈øtempring and ≈øurfeiting the body; according as Solomon ≈øaies, that to tho≈øe that tarrie long at the Wine, and that do goe to ≈øeeke mixt Wine, is woe, ≈øorrow, contentious babling, wounds without cau≈øe, and redne≈ø≈øe of the eyes, Prov. 23.29.30.

Al≈øo, by whoredome, and bodily uncleanne≈ø≈øe, the
≈øtrength is wa≈øted, as the Apo≈øtle ≈øhewes how ≈øuch doe ≈øin again≈øt their owne bodies, 1 Cor. 6.18. and Solomon tells us that the hou≈øe of a ≈øtrange woman inclines to death, Prov. 2.18. and by her, a mans fle≈øh and body is con≈øumed, Prov. 5.11. and, the adultre≈ø≈øe hunteth after the pretious life.

2. A morall meritorious manner of ≈øelf-killing. Secondly, men by their ≈øelf-willed ≈øinfull cour≈øes, are indirect ≈øelf-murderers of their bodies efficiently; in a moral manner, and by way of merit, according to the ju≈øtice of God, threatning and puni≈øhing di≈øobedient prophanene≈ø≈øe and wickedne≈ø≈øe from heaven; not onely inwrapping tran≈øgre≈ø≈øors into publick generall judgements with others; but al≈øo, by inflicting particular per≈øonall de≈øtruction upon them; as God did upon Corah, Dathan, and Abiram
Numb. 16.38., and upon ≈øome, for their unworthy and prophane receiving of the Sacrament of the Lords Supper, did die1 Cor. 11.30., by their owne meritorious procurement: and, wee are taught in the Proverbs,
Prov. 1.8 31, 32. that ≈øinners do lay waite for their owne blood, and, eate the fruit of their owne
way: and that the turning away of the ≈øimple ≈øhall ≈ølay him. In the Prophet Ezekiel, Robbers, adulterers, and u≈øurers,

Ezek. 33.4, 5. Yea, all the damned in hell, who≈øe bodies with their ≈øoules ≈øhall be ≈øubject to the ≈øecond death by meanes of their owne ≈øins; are, and ≈øhall be guilty of their own deaths, both of ≈øoule and body; and ≈øo are ≈øelf-murderers al≈øo of their bodies, at lea≈øt indirectly.

In Adam, and by his fir≈øt ≈øin, all men naturally are ≈øelf-murderers. Moreover Adam, and all mankinde in him lap≈øed, are indirectly ≈øelf-murderers, by merit of that fir≈øt tran≈øgre≈ø≈øion; for, and through which, death entred into the world: according to the te≈øtimony of the Apo≈øtle; who ≈øaith, that by one man ≈øin entred into the world, and death by ≈øin: ≈øo death pa≈ø≈øed upon all men, for that all have ≈øinned. Rom. 5.12. So that no man can blame any for his death, in regard of originall merit and de≈øert, but him≈øelfe. Now, that this death of our ≈øelves, may not be imputed to our ≈øelves, that we ≈øhould ≈øtand guilty before God of this indirect ≈øelf-murder; we mu≈øt labour to get our pardon from God in Chri≈øt, for the comfort of our con≈øciences, and for our ≈øecurity from the avenger of blood, upon our reconciliation with our God; and bee carefull that we live not wilfully and impenitently in any knowne ≈øinne; without which care, all ≈øtand guilty before God of this ≈øinne of ≈øelf-murder, and ≈øhall ≈øuffer for it.

Ob≈øerve. The world is full of ≈øelf-murderers. From hence we may ob≈øerve, that there are many more ≈øelf-murderers than the world takes notice of, or that do thinke them≈øelves to be ≈øuch; yea, the world is full of them; who≈øe ≈øinnes are more haynous than they conceive, and ≈øpecially again≈øt them≈øelves mo≈øt pernicious: and therefore, it is no marvell that one man endeavours

Some difference there is in the affection and intention of betterne≈ø≈øe to him≈øelfe; but his reall performances are to him≈øelfe wor≈øt.

Thus having declared what indirect ≈øelf-murder is, and how it is diver≈øly procured and committed; now I will ≈øhew certaine exempt ca≈øes; which, although in the materiality of the facts they differ not from indirect ≈øelf-murder; yet, in the formality of their acting, are much di≈øcrepant.

div.head: ¬ß. 15. Of certaine exempt Ca≈øes.
div.p: Exempt ca≈øes. Three ca≈øes there are, wherein men are warrantably to expo≈øe their bodies to the apparent danger of death; without perill of ≈øelf-murder, or ju≈øt blame of guiltine≈ø≈øe of their owne deaths.

1. By calling. Fir≈øt, when a man hath a lawfull calling, generall, or particular; which, without danger of lo≈ø≈øe of his life, in di≈øcharging thereof, he cannot execute; then is he to adventure his life, that he may doe his duty, (which otherwi≈øe cannot be performed) committing him≈øelfe to Gods protection, and di≈øpo≈øall. Pacchtarius ad Januarium. In fine obitus ≈øui ≈øub Martyrii pa≈ø≈øione‚Äî David a Mauden in praeceptum 6. di≈øcur≈ø. decim. and is commended among the faithfull: Heb. 11.32. whom Bacchiarius, an ancient Author, calls a Martyr: of which David a Mauden gives the rea≈øon‚Äîquia illae quae ad Martyrium requiruntur conditiones in ip≈øo reperiuntur: the things requi≈øite for Martyrdome were found in him, being a per≈øon reconciled to God; and dying for Gods glory,
and in defence of the truth, and by a warrantable calling of divine in≈øtinct, and ≈øupernaturall ability. And we ≈øee, that when God did call Mo≈øes to come up into the mount, there to die; he obeyed, and went willingly and wittingly unto his owne death. Deut. 34.

By this rule, ≈øouldiers and ≈øervants taking wages, or otherwi≈øe bound to fight for their lives, or at the command of their ≈øuperiours, are bound (as Mauden ≈øayes) ex ju≈øtitia, by the law of ju≈øtice, to expo≈øe their lives to death, in di≈øcharge of their duty; to obey and protect their ≈øuperiours.

Rea≈øons of incouragement. The rea≈øons of incouragement to undertake ≈øuch mortall adventures, are ≈øpecially two. Fir≈øt, our knowledge and a≈ø≈øurance that God, whom herein wee are to re≈øpect and obey, originally, or ≈øecondarily commanding us, will either protect us in our wayes and undertakings; or will ≈øo di≈øpo≈øe of us, as ≈øhall be be≈øt for us; with comfort, and honour, in, and after our death:Knowledge. in which re≈øpect, both Plato pro Socrate; and al≈øo Ari≈øtotle affirme, that hone≈øt a mors turpi vitae e≈øt praeferenda: An honourable death is to be preferred before a ≈øhamefull life.

2. Benefit of death. Secondly, the feare of the lo≈ø≈øe of our lives ≈øhould bee no remora, or hinderance to our dutifull performances: becau≈øe our deaths in this manner, may be the medium, or meanes to the end, that is better than our lives: Wee ≈øee, that if a thing de≈øtinated to a certaine end, doe at any time cro≈ø≈øe or hinder the attaining of that end; in that re≈øpect it is to be deemed evill, and to be rejected: as our Saviour commands, that if our eye cau≈øe us to offend, then pull it out; and in like ca≈øe to cut off our hand, or foote. Mat. 5.30. which is done by mortification and grace, making them as u≈øele≈ø≈øe to any ≈øcandalous cour≈øes, as if they were cut off in ≈øemblable manner, as men throw away their armour to ≈øave their lives by ≈ølight in a hot pur≈øuit of their enemies, and as men at Sea throw their goods into the water to ≈øave them≈øelves.

div.head: ¬ß. 16. A particular que≈øtion about ≈øouldiers flying, re≈øolved.
div.p:
Ab ‚Ä¢ ut ≈øouldiers, a ca≈øe of con≈øcience. Que≈øtion.
A que≈øtion may be here moved, whether it be in con≈øcience lawfull for any ≈øouldier, out of feare of death, upon his owne apprehen≈øions, to flee and runne away to ≈øave his life, before a ≈øignall, command, or example bee given him by his Commander ≈øo to doe?

An≈øwer. Souldiers are to ≈øtand. I an≈øwer, for the fact it is true, nothing is more frequently done in warre, than ≈øo to runne away in di≈øorderly manner; becau≈øe feare bereaves men of their u≈øe and command of rea≈øon; and al≈øo ≈øelf-love makes every man more carefull of his owne particular, than of the publike; things that are neere≈øt doe mo≈øt affect; extremities of dangers convert all a mans thoughts, to thinke how then to pre≈øerve him≈øelfe. But, for the morall lawfulne≈ø≈øe of that cour≈øe it appeares not to me; yea rather, I conceive that although pre≈øent death ≈øtood ready before them to ≈øwallow them up; they are not to turne their backs, to leave their ≈øtations, and runne away without due crder, ≈øignall, or example of their Commanders. Becau≈øe ≈øuch de≈øertion of their Commanders and fellowes in di≈øtre≈ø≈øe, is a betraying of them into their enemies hands. Againe, the greate≈øt de≈øtruction and ruine of an Army, comes by di≈øorderly flight, wherein every man is objected to the enemies execution: Whereas, by re≈øolution and couragious re≈øi≈øting to death, many victories are gotten, with the pre≈øervation of the body of an Army. Finally, if the publike doe mi≈øcary, our particular cannot bee ≈øafe; but tho≈øe that e≈øcape may (in regard of their after-mi≈øeries) wi≈øh that they had fallen in the army, by the ≈øword of their enemies.

We are bound to attribute ≈øo much to the wi≈ødome, and valour of our Commanders; that they will not ca≈øt away the lives of their men, but upon apparent po≈ø≈øibilities
of victory or pre≈øervation, by oppo≈øition; although we ≈øee it not.Helps ≈øo to do. 1. Faith. The helps to enable us to this high courage of performing of duty, are two: Fir≈øt, Faith; both for the goodne≈ø≈øe of our e≈øtate in Chri≈øt to Godward; wherby we may be a≈ø≈øured of everla≈øting life and glory, when we die: and al≈øo, for the lawfulne≈ø≈øe of our calling and imployment in that ≈øervice, wherein death attaches us; that we may as comfortably there end our dayes, as if we dyed upon our beds; being per≈øwaded of our future happy condition; and that our death in that manner is more u≈øefull to men, and more acceptable to God, than our lives.

2. Re≈øolution. Secondly, undaunted re≈øolution to be obedient in doing our duties; con≈øidering that obedience is better than ≈øacrifice, although in doing thereof wee doe peri≈øh. For, for to enjoy vertue and union with God, (which confi≈øts in obedience to Gods will,) is better than life without them.

div.head: ¬ß. 17. The ≈øecond exempt ca≈øe about venturing of life, which is upon urgent nece≈øsity.
div.p:
The ≈øecond Ca≈øe, Nece≈ø≈øity: in three points. 1. Vncertaine death, for certaine good. The ≈øecond Ca≈øe wherein we may wittingly and willingly, without danger of ≈øelf-murder, adventure the lo≈ø≈øe of our lives, is a pre≈øent, urgent, and unavoidable nece≈ø≈øity, for a certaine greater more eligible good: which falls out in three points. Fir≈øt, not only when with an uncertaine danger of our owne lives, wee ≈øeeke to redeeme the certaine de≈øtruction of our neighbours; as to ca≈øt our ≈øelves into the water, being skilfull to ≈øwimme, to ≈øave him from a≈ø≈øured drowning, who hath no other meanes of ≈øafety: or, to ca≈øt our ≈øelves into de≈øperate dangers for re≈øcue of our wives, children, or friends, from out of the fire; or out of the hands of our enemies; as did Abraham for Lot
Gen. 14.14., and David for his wives 1 Sam. 30.; or to mini≈øter to the nece≈ø≈øities of our ≈øick hou≈øhold, that they

But further al≈øo, to ≈øave another from certainly peri≈øhing, ≈øometimes men may object them≈øelves to certaine death;Certaine death for Superiours. as if the per≈øon be a publicke Magi≈øtrate, or Prince, or evidently of more u≈øe and worth in Church or Common-wealth than our ≈øelves, we may exchange our ≈øelves to pa≈ø≈øe for him, as the Scripture intimates, with commendation; that peradventure for a good man ≈øome would even dare to die. Rom. 6.7. and the peoples e≈øteeme of David was, that he was worth ten thou≈øand of them; and therefore, would not let him adventure him≈øelfe; where, if halfe of them ≈øhould die, the enemies would not care for them. 2 Sam. 18.3. this re≈øpect and preferment of eminency and vertue is not only from love of them≈øelves, but al≈øo from love of that publike body, to which tho≈øe per≈øons by their lives may be beneficiall.

For a friend. Al≈øo, a man may, for pre≈øervation of his deare friend, put him≈øelfe upon a≈ø≈øured death; as our Saviour implies, by way of commending the ≈øame; when he ≈øayes, Greater love hath no man than this, Ambro≈ø. lib. 3. officiarum c. 12. de duobus Pythagoraeis. Virgil.‚Äîme me ad≈øum qui ≈øeei, in me converene ≈øerrwn. that a man lay downe his life for his friends. Therefore, this degree of love hee may have, and was practi≈øed by divers, as betweene Ni≈øus and Euryalus, Damon and Pythias, Pylades and Ore≈øtes.

Object. The thing that may ≈øeeme to with≈øtand the lawfulne≈ø≈øe of this practice, is that generall rule of loving our neighbours as our ≈øelves, and not otherwi≈øe.An≈øw. But this is ea≈øily an≈øwered; fir≈øt, by the right under≈øtanding of the rule; as our ≈øelves; which notes, not the degree or mea≈øure of our love;1. It is required that our love be ≈øincere. for then mu≈øt we love all men alike, if the rule of the mea≈øure be one: for, quae conveniunt in uno tertio, conveniunt inter ≈øe: they that agree in any one third thing, doe agree within them≈øelves: but, that we are to love all men alike, is ab≈øurd, and again≈øt the practice of our Saviour Chri≈øt, who loved Iohn above the re≈øt of the Apo≈øtles; then [as our ≈øelves] notes the ≈øincerity of our

So then, here is commanded fir≈øt, that we ≈øhould love our neighbours; ≈øecondly, that for the quality of this love, it ≈øhould be in truth; and as we would that others ≈øhould love us: which doth not exclude ≈øuch a ≈øuperlative degree of love, as may expre≈ø≈øe it ≈øelfe by a mans dying for his friend; as if it were an unlawfull exce≈ø≈øe.

2. To dye for a friend may bee ≈øelf-love, and lawfull. Secondly, this doubt may be re≈øolved, by the true interpretation of ≈øuch a mans act: becau≈øe, in that degree of love ≈øo expre≈ø≈øed for his friend, he loves him≈øelfe, both by the con≈øummation and earthly perfection of the vertue of friend≈øhip in him; which in ≈øome ≈øort beatifies the ≈øubject wherein it is; and al≈øo thereby he gaines to him≈øelfe the honour to be counted more worthy of a friend, than a friend was of him:Amicus e≈øt after ego. & lovers are ≈øaid to live rather in tho≈øe that they doe love, than in them≈øelves; ≈øo that without ≈øuch friends their lives would be but a langui≈øhing dying. With mee in this point, accords Cardinall Folet uponIdem ibid. Iohn 15.13. and David √† Mauden in his tenth di≈øcour≈øe upon the ≈øixt Commandement, is peremptory; and ≈øayes, thatId non facit ex amore vitae alterius‚Äî≈øed ex amore virtutis amicitiae, & ad ahorum exemplum: quod dum ≈øacit, ≈øe plus quaÃÑ amicum diligit. Certum e≈øt licitum e≈ø≈øe vitam ≈øuam certo periculo exponere, pro ≈øervanda amicivita temporali, ex motivo hone≈øtatis & amicitiae: quandoquidem hone≈øtas virtutis majus bonum ≈øit, qu√†m vita propria corporalis: It is certaine that it is lawfull for a man to expo≈øe his life to certaine danger, for to pre≈øerve the temporall life of his friend, upon the motive of hone≈øty and friend≈øhip; ≈øeeing the hone≈øty of vertue is a greater good, than his owne corporall life.

From hence he ≈øayes, Licitum e≈ø≈øe aiunt Doctores amico pe≈øte laboranti in≈øervire, cum aequi certo per culo mertis, & in communi naufragio takulam ≈øo ‚Ä¢ io cedere; unde ≈øi duo amici ≈øimul naufragium ≈øeci≈ø≈øent, u≈ø
que re≈øidua e≈øet tal ula, cu jus ≈øub≈øidio alteruter ex illis tantum po Yet ≈øalvari, po≈ø≈øet quidem alter e√¢ non uti, ut ≈øibi cam amicus a≈ø≈øumeret, cujus ≈øaluti con≈øultum crpit. in kee tamen eventu cavendum e≈øt, ne quis per po≈øitivam aliquam actionem direct√® neci ≈øuae ecoperetur; hoc enimillici ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ n e≈øt. Di≈øetu≈ø. 10. in praecept. 6. numer. 3.5. Ema: Sa: in vocabulo vita. that the Doctors affirme that it is lawfull to doe ≈øervice to a friend that is ≈øick of the pe≈øtilence,
with equally certaine danger of death; and in a common ≈øhipwrack to yeeld a board to a fellow companion: as if two friends have ≈øuffered ≈øhipwrack together, and that there were a board remaining to them; by the help whereof only one of them could be ≈øaved; the one of them may forbeare to make u≈øe of the ≈øame, that his friend, who≈øe ≈øafety he de≈øires, may take it to him≈øelfe. Notwith≈øtanding, in this ca≈øe heed mu≈øt be taken that no man doe directly, by any po≈øitive action cooperate to his owne death: for, that is unlawfull. div.head: ¬ß. 18. Of the ≈øecond point, which is concerning certaine death for certaine more publike good.
div.p: The ≈øecond point. The ≈øecond point concerning pre≈øent urgent nece≈ø≈øity, wherein a man may adventure the lo≈ø≈øe of his life for a greater good, without any danger of ≈øelf-murder, is when by the lo≈ø≈øe of one, or of a few lives, many more are pre≈øerved: Certaine death for greater pub. like good. for, bonum commune e≈øt praeferendum proprio: the publike good is to be preferred before our owne private; which argueth the greater charity for exten≈øion of it abroad: and as we are not made every one for him≈øelfe onely; but for the good one of another: So ≈øhould wee endeavour the ≈øame by life and death: as the Apo≈øtle commands that we ≈øhould not looke every man on his owne things, but every man al≈øo on the things of others. Phil. 2.4.

In the publike good, the good of every particular is comprehended; and therefore, the members, ≈øeverally con≈øidered, are to expo≈øe them≈øelves to ≈øuffer for the good and pre≈øervation of the Whole. Thomas of Aquine ≈øayes well, that Charitas communia propriis anteponit: Tho: 2.2. quae≈øt. 26. arlic. 4. ad 3.
Charity preferres the publike before the private: In this al≈øo David a Mauden is cleare, when he ≈øayes, in his
aforenamed di≈øcour≈øe: Laudabiliter facit, qui pro bono publico ≈øe periculo exponit: Sicut enim in naturalibus pars una corporis, rect√® periculo exponitur pro ≈øervando toto corpore; ita & in politicis, particulare Reipub. membrum pro ≈øervanda tota Republica: That man doth commendably, that expo≈øes him≈øelfe to danger for the publike good: as even in naturall things, one part of the body is rightly expo≈øed to ≈øave the whole body; ≈øo al≈øo in things politique, a particular member of the common wealth is to be expo≈øed for to ≈øave the whole. And therefore the Prophet David upon this ground, accompanied with a ≈øpeciall in≈øtinct and motion of the Spirit, for the generall good of his nation, undertooke with the perill of his life; a dangerous combate again≈øt the Gyant Goliah. 1 Sam. 17. Caiaphas did tell a truth, when he ≈øaid, that it was better that one man ≈øhould die for the people, than that the whole Nation ≈øhould peri≈øh.
John 11.50. Eleazar is commended, Qui ≈øe in mortem dedit, ut populum ≈øuum liberaret: Who gave him≈øelfe, that he might deliver his people, ≈øayes Mauden. Examples of this practice are frequent among the Heathen, and by them celebrated with greate prai≈øe: As Codrus the Athenian King, (if I be not mi≈øtaken) who thru≈øt him≈øelfe into death among his enemies, that hee might procure victory to his people, according to the Oracle. Al≈øo of Curtius the Romane it is ≈øaid; that Se pro Republica praecipitavit in hiatum terrae: for pre≈øervation of the common-wealth hee did throw him≈øelfe into a gulfe of the earth: But of this kinde many might be alleadged. Vpon this ground it is, that the keeping of a Pa≈ø≈øe; the defending of a Town, or Fort, or the making of a Stand to check the pur≈øuing enemy, may be committed to a few, again≈øt an unre≈øi≈øtable multitude of enemies: which charge and ≈øervice tho≈øe few are not to decline, nor di≈øert and quitt; although they doe fore≈øee that in that ≈øervice they mu≈øt all die upon the place; when it is apparent, that by the lo≈ø≈øe of the lives of tho≈øe few, after that brave manner, the lives of many others are
pre≈øerved, with a more generall publike good of that body and State whereof they are members: So Samp≈øonlike, doing more good by their thus dying, than they ever did, or could, by otherwi≈øe living.

div.head: ¬ß. 19. Of certaine que≈øtions re≈øolved.
div.p: Que≈øtions 1. About a manflayer, for who≈øe ≈øake his friends are pur≈øued to death. To this point belongs the deci≈øion of divers que≈øtions. As, fir≈øt, if a man have killed another, and e≈øcaped; for revenge whereof the kindred and friends of the ≈ølaine, in their pur≈øuit of the man≈ølayer for ju≈øtice, doe fall upon his kindred and friends that favour or entertaine him; whereby may follow the effu≈øion of much innocent blood, where there is not ≈øufficient power and authority to order and protect men again≈øt ≈øuch outrages; then is ≈øuch a man≈ølayer bound in con≈øcience to put him≈øelfe betweene his friends and ≈øuch harme, and to offer him≈øelfe a ≈øacrifice to appea≈øe wrath; and to prevent a more generall blood≈øhed, mortality, and deadly feud; Whereby, for his ≈øake, many of his deare≈øt friends might peri≈øh. It is better that one ≈øhould die for pre≈øerving of many, than that many ≈øhould die for pre≈øerving one of no more worth and u≈øe than any one of the other: which is apparent by Ioabs demand in his pur≈øuit of Sheba, at Abel of Bethmaachah, requiring him to bee delivered up to him, upon promi≈øe that he would depart from the City; which was done accordingly.2 Sam. 20.21.

div.head: ¬ß. 20. About a man under deadly di≈øplea≈øure of Superiours.
div.p:

2. In particular. An≈øwer. When they ought. I an≈øwer, if the bond for his appearance bee his owne promi≈øe, hee ought in con≈øcience to appeare; becau≈øe, Gods Word and Law bindes us to keepe our promi≈øes;

But, if hee bee at liberty, upon his friends bond, of body for body, for appearance, then ought hee in con≈øcience to appeare, although hee certainely fore≈øee that there hee ≈øhall die; that he may free his friend, by his mean√®s, and for his ≈øake, ≈øo ingaged; both, in re≈øpect of the Law of friend≈øhip; and in regard of the cau≈øe, that is not his friends, but his owne, that by his meanes, and for him, an innocent man do not peri≈øh: which were his grievous ≈øinne.

An≈øwer.The nocent ought to di≈øcover him≈øelfe. I an≈øwer, that hee is bound in con≈øcience ≈øo to doe: for, otherwi≈øe he is guilty, both by his fact, and ≈øilence, of the death of ≈øuch an innocent man ≈øo ≈øuffering, whom he might and ought to re≈øcue; now, it is certaine, that no man is to doe, or omit that which, by the doing, or omi≈ø≈øion thereof, either multiplies, or aggravates his ≈øin; to his owne wor≈øe, and eternall condemnation:And how. againe, he is bound not to ≈øuffer other men to ≈øinne, either by ra≈øhne≈ø≈øe, or malice, in the witne≈ø≈øes or jurie, when it is in his power to prevent it, by true information; as, in this ca≈øe he may: yet, I thinke he is to do it, with as great circum≈øpection, for ≈øafety of his owne life, as he can; being ≈øure that he leave not the truth undi≈øcovered; nor ≈øuffer the innocent to peri≈øh, through his feare or neglect.

The barre removed. V≈øe 2. Con≈øideration of our cour≈øes. Ob≈øerve 1. Ill cour≈øes are mo≈øt harmfull to the doers of them.
