div.head: CHAP. 12. Of direct bodily ≈øelf-murder.
¬ß. 1. What it is.
div.p: Now it followes that we treate of direct ≈øelf-murder; and fir≈øt, ≈øhew what it is: Direct bodily ≈øelf-murder is an advi≈øed, witting and willing intention, and effectuall endeavour of a man, by his owne hands, or meanes, to take away or de≈øtroy his owne life, whereby he doth indeed kill him≈øelfe.
In which de≈øcription wee are to ob≈øerve two things: Fir≈øt, the generall, and then the ≈øpecificall nature of direct ≈øelf-murder.

Generall nature of it. Touching the genericall, or generall nature of direct ≈øelf-murder, which is as the matter of it;1. A morall act. we are to con≈øider, fir≈øt, that it is a morall act proceeding from mans will; and therefore is good, or bad; and ≈øo wee are to bee the more carefull how we doe purpo≈øe, or performe it.

2. The object of it, Life. Secondly, we are to ob≈øerve touching that action, the object thereof, about which it is exerci≈øed: and that is the naturall life of man, who hath no ≈øuch other precious worldly thing: and therefore, we ≈øhould be very wary how we venture to deale therewith.

3. The ≈øubject of it, Mans ≈øelfe. Thirdly, the ≈øubject of this action is a mans ≈øelfe; by whom, and upon whom the ≈øame is done; and ≈øo is both the active and pa≈ø≈øive ≈øubject of the ≈øame act; and ≈øo it doth neerely concerne a man, that he may well con≈øider, both what he doth, and ≈øuffers in that ca≈øe; ≈øeeing he may bee guilty of a double blame, if he doth both doe, and ≈øuffer that which he ought not by his owne hands.

4. The end of it, To de≈øtroy. Fourthly, the end of this action is remarkable; that it is not to cheri≈øh and pre≈øerve, but to de≈øtroy and take away a mans owne life: It is the end that makes or marres even a good action, and increa≈øes the maliciou≈øne≈ø≈øe of an evill. And therefore it concernes us much, in all our actions, to con≈øider well their ends, whether the ≈øame be good or evill.

The ≈øpecificall nature of it.The ≈øpecificall nature of direct ≈øelf-murder, is that which is the true forme of it; whereby it is properly and directly ≈øelf-murder. This ≈øpecificall nature of it is remota & proxima, remote and next.
Remote.The remote nature of direct ≈øelf-murder con≈øi≈øts in two things.

1. Re≈øtraint of the act it ≈øelfe. Fir≈øt, in the re≈øtraint, or limitation of the act of killing, for agent and patient; for choi≈øe and application of the meanes to a mans owne ≈øelfe; who thereby reflects and returnes upon him≈øelfe, in an act of the greate≈øt ho≈øtility and cruelty that can be in the world, to de≈øtroy him≈øelfe and his owne life, by his owne meanes; ≈øo becomming his owne Burrio and executioner.

2. The Agent, under≈øtanding what he doth. Secondly, the remote nature of direct ≈øelf-murder con≈øi≈øts in the di≈øpo≈øition of the agent, both in his under≈øtanding, and will; in re≈øpect of his under≈øtanding, the actour of it doth the ≈øame advi≈øedly, and wittingly.

Advi≈øedly. Advi≈øedly he doth it; when after premeditation in his minde of killing of him≈øelfe, and after approbation of the fact in his judgement, he re≈øolves upon his unwarrantable motives to doe it; and devi≈øes and plots the meanes and manner how to doe it, after deliberation, and conflict with him≈øelfe betweene oppofite rea≈øons: and when withall the under≈øtanding works and prevailes upon the will, to draw the ≈øame to concurre in the re≈øolution to doe it, and to command and imploy the body in con≈øent with both the under≈øtanding and the will, to execute their plea≈øure to its owne de≈øtruction, as is manife≈øt in the practi≈øe of Ahitophel 2 Sam. 17.23. and Iudas.
Mat. 27.5. Then it is an advi≈øed
act, done by a man in ≈øuch advi≈øed manner, and ≈øo cannot be excu≈øed by ignorance, or incon≈øiderate ha≈øte; but is done with the fulle≈øt careere of morall motion, and with the greate≈øt ingagement of the whole man, in an action of the highe≈øt nature of ≈øelf-mi≈øchiefe.

Note.The vile≈øt actions are often done upon greate≈øt advi≈øement, and deliberation; which makes them the wor≈øe, and more odious. Mans wi≈ødome is madne≈ø≈øe when he is left to him≈øelfe; and a depraved judgement perverts the will, and leads a man into many vile practi≈øes; ≈øeeing the will followes the la≈øt determination of the practicall under≈øtanding. If the light of under≈øtanding that is in man be darkne≈ø≈øe, how great then is that darkne≈ø≈øe?

Wittingly. Wittingly, a man doth take away his owne life, when at the very time of doing the act, hee knowes both that he is doing ≈øuch an act, materially con≈øidered; and al≈øo, that the ≈øame act, for the nature and forme of it, tends directly to his own de≈øtruction, and is wicked and unlawfull to be done, and yet for all that doth not de≈øi≈øt; whereby man that is a rationall creature, able to judge of his owne actions, is ≈øelf-condemned in his own con≈øcience, while he is about, and in doing the act it ≈øelfe.

Willingly.The di≈øpo≈øition of the agent, or actour in direct ≈øelf-murder in re≈øpect of his will, is that he doth it willingly; as to bang, or ≈øtab, or poy≈øon him≈øelfe, or the like. For violence or inforcement cannot be done to the will, in its act of willing, which nece≈ø≈øarily mu≈øt be free; either ab≈øolutely, or conditionally.
Willingne≈ø≈øe.This willingne≈ø≈øe in a man to kill him≈øelfe, is twofold.

1. Antecedent. Ahitophel acce≈ø≈øit ≈øobrius ad perdendm ≈øcip≈ø ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , ut Cae≈øar ad perdendam Rempub: Fir≈øt, that which is antecedent before the fact; whereby he wills not only that he were dead; but al≈øo wills that ≈øuch a murderous act ≈øhould be done by him≈øelfe, upon him≈øelfe, to take away his owne life; which by a contrary act, and change of his will might be prevented; as it is ≈øaid of Ahitophel, that he came ≈øober to de≈øtroy him≈øelfe, as Cae≈øar came ≈øober to ruinate the common wealth.

Concomitant. Secondly, he hath a willingne≈ø≈øe concomitant at the act doing; ≈øo that when it is in his power to ≈øu≈øpend his act, and not to doe it, yet he wills and doth it indeed: which is ≈øo much the more grievous, by how much the more it hath of wilfulne≈ø≈øe; as will is both the originall fountaine of ≈øin, and is ≈øo e≈ø≈øentiall to it, that ab≈øolutely again≈øt, or without mans will he hath no actuall ≈øin, neither can have any.
The proximate or neere≈øt nature of direct ≈øelf-murder.The next, or neere≈øt ≈øpecificall nature of direct ≈øelf-murder con≈øi≈øts of two ≈øubordinate branches.

1. Mans intention. Fir≈øt, in the immediate intention of a men; which is to kill him≈øelfe, and doth conclude the joynt act therein both of his judgement and will; becau≈øe ≈øuch an intention is grounded upon, and proceeds from advi≈øement and deliberation, and doth al≈øo re≈øpect the fact that he minds to doe, ≈øub ratione finis; under con≈øideration of an end; and ≈øo, in his judgement, good: and therefore it includes his will, de≈øiring and endeavouring that it may be done; and ≈øo to him ≈øuch a fact falls not out by acdident, or unexpected, or not intended; but it is the thing he aymes at.

2. The bodies imployment. The ≈øecond branch of the neere≈øt ≈øpecificall nature of direct ≈øelf murder is, the actuall imployment of the body and the ≈øtrength thereof, upon direction of the under≈øtanding, and command of the will, fully to accompli≈øh his intention, and effect the killing of a mans ≈øelfe by his owne hands, or meanes, whereby it is perfected and con≈øummated, with ≈øelf-perdition, in a wicked con≈øpiracy of ≈øelf-de≈øtruction, by ≈øoul and body again≈øt them≈øelves. Ob≈øerve Abu≈øe of power, and of obedience. Wherein is to be ob≈øerved and condemned both the wretched abu≈øe of the authority and power of mans under≈øtanding and will, directing and commanding the inferiour faculties and body to doe that which tends directly to de≈øtruction both of their parts, and-whole: and al≈øo we may ≈øee herein a patterne of unwarrantable obedience; in the bodies yeelding to doe that which is unlawfull, and ruinates it ≈øelfe; the ≈øuperiority of the under≈øtanding
der≈øtanding and will frees not the body from blame; for then why ≈øhould it ≈øuffer with the ≈øoule for that act? But the ≈øin is the greater, by how much the further it extends to involve partizans, or acce≈ø≈øaries, and makes many guilty of the ≈øame crime; who are to be condemned, not only for the fact done by them, but al≈øo for violating the rights and duties of their places, in unlawfully commanding, and obeying in that which is evill, contrary to an higher rule.

div.head: ¬ß. 2. Of the imaginary good conceited to bee in ≈øelf-murder.
div.p: Object. Excl cannot be an end. It may be objected, that for a man advi≈øedly, wittingly, and willingly to propound to him≈øelfe, and to ayme at that for his end, that is his de≈øtruction, is again≈øt nature; becau≈øe the end is, or ought ever to be the perfection of the thing that de≈øires it, and endeavours to have it; and good only is de≈øirable, and to be ≈øought after; which may content us in the enjoying thereof: and therefore, the conclu≈øion may ≈øeeme to be good, that no man can advi≈øedly, wittingly, and willingly purpo≈øe and endeavour to kill him≈øelfe.

An≈øw. Death is not the ultimate cad. Whereunto may be an≈øwered; although death bee the immediate end intended, and ≈øought in direct ≈øelf-murder; yet it is not the ultimate, or la≈øt end; neither, is it ≈øought for at any time for it ≈øelfe, but accidentally, and for another thing, which is good; for obtaining whereof, a ≈øelf-murderer would u≈øe that as a meanes. Compari≈øon. As Phy≈øick is immediately de≈øired and taken, not for it ≈øelfe; but for health thereby, which is the patients ultimate end in taking of medicines: & therefore, one ≈øayes, Mors ut malum non e≈øtoptabilis, nec optatur per ≈øe, ≈øed grati√¢ alteriÍù∞: Death, as it is an evill thing, is not de≈øirable; neither is it of it ≈øelfe de≈øired, but in re≈øpect of ≈øome other thing; and ≈øo is de≈øired per con≈øequutionem, & non per ≈øe; by con≈øequution, and
not of it ≈øelfe; for, death is never de≈øired by a naturall appetite, as oppo≈øite to that appetite or de≈øire that followes rea≈øon, either right or depraved: becau≈øe nature is materiatum quid, ≈øome materiated thing belonging to the per≈øon, in re≈øpect both of matter and forme, ≈øoule and body, ≈øo long as they are united; and therefore ever de≈øired the good and pre≈øervation of the per≈øon, in that union.
The imaginary good of ≈øelf-murder.The good ultimately intended, and conceited to bee obtained by ≈øelf-murder, is twofold.

1. Freedome from evill. Fir≈øt, freedome from greater evill felt, or feared; reall, or but imaginary; which in a ≈øelf-murderers opinion is no other way avoidable: and they de≈øpaire to be able to beare it; (mea≈øuring them≈øelves by them≈øelves) ≈øo as if they cannot ≈øhake off the yoke, then will they violently di≈ø≈øolve them≈øelves.

Cau≈øes. 1. Conceited badne≈ø≈øe of e≈øtate. The true cau≈øes hereof, are fir≈øt, the ≈øelf-murderers conceit, that his pre≈øent, or feared condition is wor≈øe than any other that can betide him; or that he can ≈øhift into by death.

2. Want of meanes. Secondly, his want of having, or fore≈øeeing meanes of prevention, or deliverance from the evils that he de≈øpaires to be able to beare; cau≈øes him to fall upon this wicked damnable cour≈øe of ridding him≈øelfe from them.

3. Impatience. Thirdly, di≈øobedient impatiency, that will not let a man in all things ≈øubmit to bee ordered by God; and an evill heart of unbeliefe, that hinders him from tru≈øting and depending upon God, for ≈øupportation and deliverance.

Note. 1. By meanes of his rea≈øon man ≈øuffers. Man, by meanes of his under≈øtanding and rea≈øon, is ≈øubject to many more mi≈øeries and troubles, than any bruite bea≈øts; becau≈øe he fancies many imaginary calamities to him≈øelfe, from po≈ø≈øibilities in rea≈øon, that doe as much ≈øometimes affect and trouble the minde, as if they were reall, although they never be in≈øticted.

And pre≈øent troubles men doe aggravate in their
e≈øteeme and opinion, for mea≈øure and extent, beyond that which they are in truth and ≈øen≈øe, ≈øo making them needle≈øly the more importable.

2. By meanes of memory. And troubles, future and pa≈øt, man, by his imagination, makes pre≈øent, by helpe of his memory and feare, overcharging him≈øelf with the burden of more, than ever God did lay upon him at once.

Spirituall afflictions. And finally, in his minde he is capable, by meanes of rea≈øon, of manifold ≈øpirituall afflictions, farre exceeding tho≈øe that are upon the body, and where of no irrationall creature is capable.

Imagination. And yet, of all the≈øe troubles, the greate≈øt part is imaginary, of mans owne needle≈ø≈øe, and voluntary contracting, by meanes of his abu≈øed rea≈øon, and doe worke mo≈øt reall and de≈øperate effects, even to ≈øelf murder.

Although that ≈øelf-murder be no fit, or appropriated meanes to pre≈øerve, or deliver a man from mi≈øery, or troubles, yet, a ≈øelf-murderer doth u≈øe it; deeming, according to the Philo≈øophers, that a le≈ø≈øer evill, compared with a wor≈øe, obtaines the place of good; and is to be de≈øired for good, Ari≈øt, ad Nicom. lib. 5. c. 6. Picol grad. pol. Minus malum comparatu- cum detertore obtinet lotie boni, & pro bono optabile e≈øt. which is onely to be under≈øtood of the evill of puni≈øhment, and not of the evill of ≈øin: for, for to avoid all puni≈øhment we are to doe no ≈øin; which to doe, were a greater puni≈øhment, and would draw puni≈øhment more abundantly upon the doers of the ≈øame: in evils of ≈øinne there is no choi≈øe, or lawfull election, where all is forbidden.

2. Advancement to good. The ≈øecond imaginary good, conceited to be had by ≈øelf-murder, is the advancement of a mans ≈øelfe thereby to more good, or to a better e≈øtate than he hath at pre≈øent; either to an e≈øtate really better, as to ab≈øolute good in heavenly happine≈ø≈øe; or to fancied, or comparative good, in compari≈øon of greater evill, in the ≈øelf-murderers apprehen≈øion, that he may be in an e≈øtate le≈ø≈øe mi≈øerable, (as he thinks) than that is which he feeles or feares: which in that re≈øpect he e≈øteemes to be better than the pre≈øent.

In the≈øe regards ≈øelf-murderers are willing to exchange their lives by death; but of evill properly there comes no good. For, men gather not grapes of thornes, neither will any expect it, that is not ≈øpiritually mad.
Oh mi≈øerable ≈øtate of life that is more tedious to a man than death!

A ble≈ø≈øing may become a judgment. Thus the greate≈øt earthly ble≈ø≈øing may become, in mans ≈øen≈øe and opinion, a grievous judgement: For, God can make a man a terror to him≈øelf, and to all his friends; ≈øo that in that re≈øpect, he may brooke the name of Magor Mi≈ø≈øabib, as did Pa≈øhur, Ier. 20.3, 4. when a man leaves God, or is left of him, who is the ble≈ø≈øed object and fountaine of all true contentment and ≈øolid comfort.

Ob≈øerve. The mi≈øery of the damned in hell. Whereby, wee may ≈øee in part the mi≈øerable ≈øtate of the damned in hell, who≈øe living there is a ≈øecond death, farre exceeding the fir≈øt in mi≈øery; there is a death of di≈ø≈øolution, and a death of torment; the former brings the ≈øubject to an end, the latter brings the ≈øubject of it to all mi≈øeries: they that are in this latter ≈øhall wi≈øh for the former, and ≈øhall not finde it; whereby we may in ≈øome ≈øort ≈øee two things:

1. For mea≈øure. Fir≈øt, the mea≈øure of hells mi≈øery upon a man in it; being even as if a man, in his perfect ≈øtrength and ≈øen≈øes, were ≈øtruggling, and in the very pinch, and agonie of the la≈øt and fierce≈øt act of death, labouring under the un≈øpeakeable horror, and un≈øupportable, and untolerable paine of it, and in kinde and degree much more; as a man, in that death of hell, ≈øhall bee made more capable, and ≈øpiritually ≈øen≈øible of mi≈øery, than he is here; and whereas, here a man can die but by one mortall paine, there ≈øhall the damned be under all paines and mortall mi≈øeries in their extremities, to the utmo≈øt mea≈øure and degree, that tho≈øe damned wretches are capable of, with exact ≈øpirituall ≈øen≈øe and feeling of the ≈øame; be≈øides their woe, for want of that infinite happine≈ø≈øe in heaven, whereof they are deprived.

2. The durance of v. Secondly, wee may ≈øee here, the everla≈øtingne≈ø≈øe and endle≈ø≈øe continuance of that death in hell, which ≈øhall be as long as the damned ≈øhall have being, which ≈øhall be ever; that they may be capable of ≈øuffering, to the utmo≈øt of their capacity; ≈øo that, their being gives neither ea≈øe nor comfort; but they ≈øhall ever be in the ≈øame extremity of death, for evermore; without any relaxation, or abatement; which fills them with utter de≈øperation, and unexpre≈ø≈øible woe.Note. For, they have all that can make any creature mi≈øerable, viz. in hell, they have both life and death; by their living there, they are capable of, and doe ≈øuffer the puni≈øhment of ≈øen≈øible mi≈øery; and by that death, they have puni≈øhment of damage, in deprivation of all comfortable good; and ≈øo, what≈øoever wee can be, in the ab≈øence of good, and in pre≈øence of evill, they have the ≈øame.

div.head: ¬ß. 3. Concerning the wills object, and faultine≈ø≈øe.
div.p: Object of the will is good. That we may ≈øurther under≈øtand how a man can will his owne death, wee are to ob≈øerve that the will never choo≈øes to doe a thing ≈øub ratione mali, as it is evill; but wills a thing that is either in it≈øelfe good, or apparently ≈øuch in our apprehen≈øion; or el≈øe, it choo≈øes a thing that in it≈øelfe is evill, but is comparatively good, in re≈øpect of another evill, which in our judgement or ≈øen≈øe is greater or wor≈øer: and ≈øo no man choo≈øes death for it ≈øelfe, but in re≈øpect of ≈øome conceited good imagined to be had by it, and not otherwi≈øe: or, to have a le≈ø≈øer evill for a greater, by that exchange: as Saul, who, that hee might e≈øcape the mocking of the heathen, killed him≈øelf1 Sam. 31.4.: ≈øo that, no man is ab≈øolutely willing, in the act of ≈øelfmurder, but conditionally; becau≈øe, he u≈øes it not for it≈øelf, but as a meanes for a further end and good.

The kinds of good. Will hath ever good for the object of it: but of this good there is a double triplicity: Fir≈øt, bonum animi, corporis
& fortune: Good of the minde, of the body, and of wealth and preferment. Secondly, there is Bonum utile, jucundum & hone≈øtum: Good profitable, plea≈øant, and hone≈øt: Of the≈øe goods, the will doth not ever re≈øpect bonum hone≈øtum, or morale, vertuous or morall good, but often makes choi≈øe of profit, or plea≈øure, as the greater good, before the other: and ≈øtill bonum, or good, is the object of the will.

div.head: ¬ß. 4. Ob≈øervations from the knowledge of direct ≈øelf-murder.

V≈øe 2. How to behave our ≈øelves to our ≈øelves. div.head: ¬ß. 5. Of certaine exempt ca≈øes.Exempt ca≈øes.
div.p: 1. Men without rea≈øon, are not ≈øelf-murderers. The fir≈øt is, when a man, de≈øtitute of under≈øtanding, or of the u≈øe of rea≈øon, kills him≈øelfe, as a child without di≈øcretion, a naturall foole, a mad man in his mad fits, one in his ≈øleepe; or in ≈øuch ≈øits or ≈øickne≈ø≈øe as is accompanied with a delirium or phren≈øey, as, in a calenture; the ≈øame is not in them properly ≈øelf-murder: Rea≈øons why. becau≈øe, under≈øtanding in them is de≈øicient, or pa≈ø≈øively depraved, and not actively and wilfully done by them≈øelves: ≈øo that they cannot judge morally, nor ≈øometimes naturally, of their owne actions; neither are able rightly to direct them, in a ≈øtate of that impotency of under≈øtanding: neither is ≈øuch an act in ≈øuch per≈øons to be deemed willing, or an act of the will, ≈øo long as rea≈øon is wanting, without which it is not po≈ø≈øible for a mans will rationally to move.

Ca≈øe 2. div.head: ¬ß. 3. Self-murderers are apparent by hi≈øtory.
div.p:

div.head: ¬ß. 5. Of mi≈øcon≈øtrued decree and de≈øtiny, to the perverting of judgement.
div.p:
The third ground of a deceived judgement, Conceit of decree and de≈øtiny. The third ground of a deceived judgement, which occa≈øions ≈øelf-murder, is the ≈øelf murderers ≈øtrong apprehen≈øion that it is the unalterable deeree of God, and his owne unevitable fortune for him ≈øo to die, by his owne hands; as Tertullian ≈øpeakes of ≈øome: which conceit ari≈øes from two originals.

1. Impo≈øtures. Fir≈øt, from the oracles or impo≈øtures of Magitians and fortune tellers, that declare to tho≈øe who unwarrantably ≈øeeke to them for knowledge and re≈øolution of future contingent things, ≈øpecially touching their death, that ≈øo they ≈øhall die and peri≈øh. God never conceales any thing from us, but that, whereof the ignorance is better for us, than the knowledge.

It was curio≈øity after this kind of knowledge, that made Eve willing to learne of the devill, being her ≈øchoolema≈øter

We ≈øee, by the practi≈øe of Saul in killing him≈øelfe, how dangerous a thing it is to advi≈øe with witches 1 Sam. 28.7., ≈øooth≈øayers, magitians, A≈øtrologers, or any of that black rabble: upon affectation of curious and ≈øecret knowledge, from tho≈øe per≈øons, a man ≈øhall but play the Gnat about the candle, delighting in the light thereof, untill it be at la≈øt burnt up with the heat thereof:Ob≈øerv. as many a man may grieve that he hath ≈øo little knowledge of profitable things; ≈øo many may grieve that they have ≈øo much unprofitable, and needle≈ø≈øe knowledge. People are ignorant of nece≈ø≈øary things,Nece≈ø≈øaria n ‚Ä¢ ≈øcimus, quia non nece≈ø≈øeria di≈øcimus. becau≈øe they bend their minds ≈øo much to know unnece≈ø≈øary things: but was it ever knowne that the devill did give advice that was good, both for matter and end!

Rea≈øons. 1. Ab≈øurdity of it. For fir≈øt, by that argument, no man in the world ≈øhould be culpable of any ≈øin for any thing that hee doth, how flagitious ≈øoever it were; and ≈øo both God and man ≈øhould be blameable for unju≈øt dealing, in puni≈øhing any man for any thing that he doth; be it murder, trea≈øon, theft, or any like thing; and in vaine were all lawes, divine and humane, requiring the doing of that good, or forbidding that evill; if ju≈øtly a man may not be rewarded for the former, nor condemned for the latter.

Ob≈øerve. For, there is nothing that po≈ø≈øibly can fall out, or come to pa≈ø≈øe contrary to Gods eternall decree, in regard both of Gods pre≈øcience & fore-knowledge of all things; and al≈øo in re≈øpect of his power, and wi≈øe providence; from, and by which is the whole motion of all creatures, and their abilitie in all manner of actions. Which is further apparent by the te≈øtimony of the Apo≈øtles, in their confe≈ø≈øion to God, ≈øaying, Of a truth, again≈øt thy holy childe Ie≈øus, whom thou ha≈øt annointed, both Herod, and Pontius Pilate, with the Gentiles, and the people of I≈ørael were gathered together for to doe what≈øoever thy hand and thy Coun≈øell determined before to be done

If Gods decrees were ≈øufficient to warrant men to doe evill; then, either there could bee no ≈øinne in the world, what≈øoever men doe; or el≈øe, God mu≈øt be the author of ≈øinne, and the onely ≈øinner; which is a thing mo≈øt bla≈øphemous to thinke.

2. Ignorance. The ≈øecond rea≈øon that manife≈øts the error of tho≈øe who thinke them≈øelves warranted to doe what≈øoever God hath decreed, is both their ignorance of what God hath decreed; (which for the mo≈øt part he keepes ≈øo ≈øeeret, that it is not certainly known, but by the event and effect what it is; and in this ca≈øe the Scripture ≈øayes, that the
≈øecret things belong unto the Lord our God,

And al≈øo, it is their ignorance of the u≈øe of Gods decree, which is properly his owne will whereby, and according to which, he in wi≈øe and in ≈øoveraigne manner orders all things according to his owne good plea≈øure. But it is not that which he would have alwayes to bee our will, and according to which we ≈øhould order our wills and practi≈øe; for which he hath given us his revealed word and law; which is to be, in all practicall things, the mea≈øure of our wills and wayes.Gods revealed will is the rule of our actions. And therefore, ≈øo long as Gods word forbids ≈øelf-murder, we are not to dare, upon pretence of de≈øtiny, or Gods decree, to entertaine thoughts to attempt it. Gods ≈øecret decrees containe no formall commandements to us what we ≈øhould doe; nor put any reall influxe to incline us to ≈øin, nor ≈øubject us to compul≈øory nece≈ø≈øity of ≈øinning, contrary to our owne wills, or to the meanes, and Commandements that we have again≈øt the ≈øame.

Ob≈øerve. So then, it is certaine that our fulfilling of the ≈øecret will and decree of God by our wretched cour≈øes, and the accidentall good that may come to others thereby, cannot excu≈øe us from damnation, for running a cour≈øe contrary to the revealed wil of Gods Commandements, and to the meanes whereby we are to order our practi≈øe in obedience to God.

No man is ≈øaved for fulfilling the will of Gods decree, which no man can overthrow.It is not in the power of the mo≈øt wretched and malicious men in the world to cro≈ø≈øe, but mu≈øt fulfill the ≈øecret decree of God, neither is any man commended or ≈øaved for fulfilling that decree which no man can di≈øappoint: But all men are commended, or condemned for tho≈øe cour≈øes and meanes which they u≈øe, according as the ≈øame is commanded or forbidden in the Word; whereby the ≈øeverall decrees of God for mans ≈øalvation, or de≈øtruction, are voluntarily accompli≈øhed by men them≈øelves.

Note. Mans care ≈øhould be to live well. Mans only care in all e≈øtates, ≈øhould be to live well, in conformity to Gods revealed will and word; not being ≈øolicitous ≈øo much for our deaths, which after a good life can never be ill. 2. Di≈øobedients to God, are forward to obey the devill. div.head: ¬ß. 6. Of conceited good by ≈øelf-murder, perverting the judgement.

Good conceived. Cap. 12 ¬ß. 2. Of the goodne≈ø≈øe that a ≈øelf-murderer conceives to be in killing of him≈øelfe, I have ≈øpoken already in the explication of the definition of ≈øelf-murder.

How apparent good affects the under≈øtanding. Touching which, I will onely now ob≈øerve how bonum, or good, that properly is the object of the will, or of the ≈øoule, in its elections and actions, can affect the under≈øtanding; when it is but apparent good, and contrary to truth.

2. Goodne≈ø≈øe and truth are equally the object of the under≈øtanding. Secondly, whereas bonum and verum, good and truth, in a metaphy ≈øicall notion, are the ≈øame, and convertible, confineable to no one Category; (as neither are any of the properties or attributes of the Godbead) they are likewi≈øe equally the object of the under≈øtanding, as of the will: which in the ≈øoule, doe not differ e≈ø≈øentially; but are only the divers powers, offices, and workes of the ≈øame ≈øoule, about its-≈øeverall objects; which doe give the occa≈øion of the di≈øtinction of tho≈øe things which in them≈øelves are one: and ≈øo where ever bonum, good, is pre≈øented to the minde; there al≈øo it offers it ≈øelfe to the ≈øame, as verum, true. Con≈øequent of ≈øinne.There is a ≈øub≈øequent blindne≈ø≈øe that followes upon ≈øinning, whereby the oftner that ≈øin is committed, the le≈ø≈øe evill it ≈øeemes to be to the doers thereof; in re≈øpect both of the ≈øinfulne≈ø≈øe and puni≈øhment thereof; in which

Ob≈øerve. Wee are here to ob≈øerve two things for our in≈øtruction in this point.

div.head: ¬ß. 7. Concerning afflictions upon the body, occa≈øioning ≈øelf-murder.
div.p: Second generall motive of ≈øelf-murder. Calamities. The ≈øecond generall motive occa≈øioning ≈øelf-murder, is immoderate affectation of freedome from evill of puni≈øhment that ≈øinfull man is liable unto; for bearing of which, he hath neither comfort, nor ≈øtrength, as he apprehends.

The ≈øorts of them. The≈øe evills are, either reall and true, or but fancied and conceited; and are either pre≈øent, or feared; and are ≈øuch as a ≈øelf-murderer de≈øpaires, either to be able of him≈øelfe to beare, or that God will uphold him in them, or will deliver him from them: and therefore hee re≈øolves not to endure them; but out of ob≈øtinacy of minde and will, purpo≈øes to remove him≈øelfe by ≈øelf-murder, from that which hee cannot remove from him≈øelfe. 1. Vpon the body Fir≈øt, they are tho≈øe that are upon their bodies; which doe al≈øo much affect their ≈øoules; becau≈øe of their neere union together; whereby they doe make one per≈øon, and doe ≈øo ≈øympathi≈øe together, that what is proper to the one nature in matter of action, or pa≈ø≈øion, is deemed to bee common to the other, in regard of the unity of the per≈øon con≈øi≈øting of them both: Whereupon it is, that the ≈øufferings of the body doe drive the ≈øoule into ≈øtrange pa≈ø≈øions and undertakings, on the bodies behalfe.

About the ≈øecond branch, the in≈øufficiency of the motive from a better life kill ones ≈øelfe.For the ≈øecond branch of the afore≈øaid motive: viz. about a better life, the in≈øufficiency thereof to make a man undertake to kill him≈øelfe, thereby the ≈øooner to come to eternity, is evident by foure particulars.

Wee are to wait Gods apponted time for heaven. Secondly, we are to waite our appointed time of God, and not to ≈øtint, or cut it ≈øhort, as we li≈øt; as we ≈øee was the practi≈øe of Iob, who ≈øaid, All the daies of my appointed time will I waite, till my change come

div.head: ¬ß. 21. Of the motions of the Devill, to ≈øelf-murder.
div.p: The ≈øixt generall motive to ≈øelf-murder. Impul≈øus diaboli. The in≈øtigation of the devill. The ≈øixt generall motive, whereupon ≈øelf-murderers do kill them≈øelves, is the ≈øtrong impul≈øe, powerfull motions, and command of the Devill, who is him≈øelfe a murderer, and al≈øo moves man to practi≈øe it; both upon others, and upon him≈øelfe; thereby to di≈øhonour God, in the de≈øtruction of his Image, and in the contempt and breach of his Law: and that by the ≈øame he may de≈øtroy mankind, overthrow the works of God, and fill the world with confu≈øion: hee attempted it again≈øt Chri≈øt him≈øelfeMat. 4. ; he cau≈øed the Swine to drowne them≈øelvesMat. 8. ; he endeavoured to have made the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed child to have killed it ≈øelf. Mar. 9.22.

Whence the devill hath his power. That the devill hath ≈øuch power ≈øometime over man, proceeds from the leave and permi≈ø≈øion of God, without which hee can do nothing: and al≈øo it is from his ≈øpirituall nature, whereby hee is naturally ≈øuperiour to man, and can ≈øtrangely affect him; that hee ≈øo farre prevailes over him ≈øometimes, that hee can make him kill him≈øelfe.
How thereby ≈øelf-murder is effected.This infernall command, or powerfull inclination of ≈øelf-murder is given, or wrought by Satan two wayes.

1. In vi≈øible apparition. Fir≈øt, in ≈øome vi≈øible apparition of the devill, ≈øpeaking to, and per≈øwading a man to kill him≈øelfe.2. Outwardly. Which hee doth either outwardly in ≈øome bodily ≈øhape, as he ≈øpake to Eve, and to our Saviour Chri≈øt:1. Inwardly. or el≈øe inwardly to the fancie, whereby a man thinks that he heares, or ≈øees the devill, or ≈øome other, that can be none el≈øe but hee, bidding, or per≈øwading him to ≈øtab him≈øelfe, or to fling him≈øelfe

Per≈øons haunted. 1. Wicked. The per≈øons thus haunted by Satan, are either notorious wretches, mancipated to the devils ≈øervice, and guilty of horrible crying crimes;2. Melancholick. or el≈øe they are per≈øons extreamly melancholick, fearefull, or di≈øcontented, who≈øe tempers, and imaginations give the devill advantage this way to worke upon them.

2. Satans powerful motions in the minde. Secondly, the devill doth powerfully move a man to kill him≈øelfe, in manner equivalent to a commandement, by internall ≈øugge≈øtions, and rai≈øing of ≈øuch inward powerfull motions of ≈øelf-killing in the minde, as can hardly be put out, or with≈øtood: in regard of the deepe and firme impre≈ø≈øion of them in man, and of the intimate entertainement and commanding po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion that they have in him, by meanes of his corruption con≈øpiring with Satan, to mans owne de≈øtruction.
Satans grounds of working to prevaile. The grounds that Satan works upon, after this manner, to prevaile with man to kill him≈øelfe, are three.

1. The advantage of all other motives. Fir≈øt, he takes advantage of all other motives to ≈øelf-murder, both furthering and powerfully intending all occa≈øions to that effect; perverting the judgement, and kindling pride, or impatiencie, as is apparent by his dealing with Iob, who≈øe afflictions he both procured, and poy≈øoned, with the leaven of his intermingled malitiou≈øne≈ø≈øe.

He injects re≈øolutions of ≈øelf-killing. And al≈øo, hee workes and injects into the minds of men, upon tho≈øe cro≈ø≈øe occa≈øions, ≈øuch ≈øelf-killing re≈øolutions, as puts them upon that vile act; in a mans ≈øufferings and di≈øtractions the devill is mo≈øt bu≈øie to worke his owne ends thereby, who ≈øubtilly intermingles him≈øelfe in all ≈øtormes of troubles, again≈øt man.

2. Prophanene≈ø≈øe and idlene≈ø≈øe. The ≈øecond ground, whereby Satan prevailes with man to kill him≈øelfe, is mans wretched prophanene≈ø≈øe and idlene≈ø≈øe: for, a heart emptie of goodne≈ø≈øe, and filled with wickedne≈ø≈øe, is a fit receptacle for Satan, e≈øpecially when
≈øuch an one is not taken up with holy thoughts, and with good and warrantable imployment, in ≈øome calling, then is there roome, and fit time, for the devill to ca≈øt in his firie temptations, to take po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of ≈øuch a man, and forcibly to incline him to what horrible evils he li≈øt, even to ≈øelf-de≈øtruction.

2. Morall. Or el≈øe, the temper mo≈øt capable to receive the impre≈ø≈øions of ≈øelf-murder from Satan, is morall: as in people ≈øurcharged with the bondage and horror of their ≈øinnes; and with the feare of the puni≈øhment due for them: which the devill aggravates to ≈øuch a man, to drive him to de≈øperation; and ob≈øcures, or over≈øhadowes the grace and mercy of God from him; and ≈øo perplexes a di≈øtre≈ø≈øed con≈øcience with conceit of unpardonablene≈ø≈øe of his ≈øins, from apprehen≈øion of the exce≈ø≈øive greatne≈ø≈øe of the ≈øame; of the kind of them, as if they were again≈øt the holy Gho≈øt, and from conceit that either the time of grace to him is pa≈øt; or that God will never pardon him, although he ≈øhould ≈øeeke to him for forgivene≈ø≈øe: then ≈øuch an one re≈øolves, by the devils per≈øwa≈øion, to kill him≈øelfe, that he may prevent the making of his e≈øtate wor≈øe, than pre≈øently it is, and to ea≈øe him≈øelfe of the pre≈øent di≈øtre≈ø≈øe of con≈øcience that he is in.
How the≈øe motioÃÑs be knovvn to be froÃÑ Satan. That we may know whether this ≈øelf-murderous impul≈øion, and ≈øtrong motion be from the devill, we are to ob≈øerve three things.

Secondly, if the forciblene≈ø≈øe of the motion to ≈øelf-murder, for effecting the act, be not ≈øo much, from the apparent occa≈øious, as from ≈øecret impelling power, then, the ≈øame is from Satan; becau≈øe, the thing whereunto a man is moved is evill, and therefore, cannot be from God, or any good principle.

In≈øufficiency of this motive from Satan to kill ones ≈øelfe.The in≈øufficiency of this motive from Satan, to warrant a man to kill him≈øelfe, is apparent by two things.

1. Beleeve him not. Fir≈øt, we ought neither to beleeve the devill who is a lyar, nor to obey him; but to re≈øi≈øt him, and give him no place Jam. 4.7. Ephe≈ø. 4 27.. 2. Contrarie to rea≈øon and religion. Secondly, ≈øuch a vile motion is contrary to right rea≈øon, and Gods will; both, becau≈øe it flowes originally from Satan; and al≈øo is grounded, neither upon rea≈øon nor religion, but upon fond conceits and ≈øelf-will: a rea≈øonable man, and Chri≈øtian, ≈øhould do nothing advi≈øedly, neither warrantably can doe any thing, but according to ≈øound rea≈øon and religion.

div.head: ¬ß. 22. Of Phren≈øie occa≈øioning ≈øelf-killing.
div.p: Kinds of it. 1. Naturall. This involuntary phrentick di≈øtemperature is either naturall, or ≈øpirituall.

1. Fooles. Naturall, is fir≈øt in per≈øons from their birth, wanting the u≈øe of rea≈øon, and di≈øpo≈øed to mad prancks, by a depraved di≈øpo≈øition, or deficiency; as fooles, having in≈øtead of rea≈øon a ≈øpice of phren≈øie, when pa≈ø≈øion is provoked in them, not ≈øticking to do them≈øelves mi≈øchiefe.

div.head: ¬ß. 23. Of examples of ≈øelf-murder.
div.p: The la≈øt generall motive to ≈øelf-murder. Examples. div.p:

div.head: ¬ß. 6. Self-murderers want true repentance.

But, if it be neither way in them, then it cannot be in them at all, but it is neither way in them, ergo.

1. Habituall repentance. Fir≈øt, habituall repentance they cannot have; becau≈øe, it is a penitent di≈øpo≈øition, that mu≈øt be either infu≈øed by the holy Spirit; or acquired and purcha≈øed, by frequent acts and practi≈øe of repentance: but, neither doth the holy Gho≈øt indow ≈øuch with the habituall di≈øpo≈øition of true repentante; becau≈øe, it is an Evangelicall grace whereof ≈øinners of that tran≈øcendencie beyond the Law are not capable; and where it is, it is accompanied with the body of other ≈øaving graces, which all ≈øuch per≈øons do want: nor yet have they got habituall repentance, by their long and con≈øtant practi≈øe thereof; ≈øeeing ≈øuch do alwaies live impenitent wretches in their ≈øins, without godly remor≈øe and new life.

2. Actuall repentance. Secondly, for ≈øuch per≈øons actually and indeed to repent ≈øoundly, and to life, at, or in their act of this tran≈øcendent ≈øelf-murder, they cannot; in regard that either they want time to doe it, if it were po≈ø≈øible for them to repent; or, they want rather a heart ≈øavingly to repent; which requires both a divine principle within them,
whereby they may be able to do it, and al≈øo ≈øome ble≈ø≈øed meanes of Gods ordination, to exu≈øcitate and ≈øtirre up that power into act: the former a ≈øelf-murderer hath not; for the latter, God never ordained vile ≈øelf-murder to be a meanes of a ≈øelf-murderers repentance; neither attends ≈øuch mens lei≈øure, to give them repentance, when they li≈øt; who would not repent at his call.

By the tran≈øcendency of their ≈øin, the≈øe ≈øelf-murderers over-≈øet them≈øelves, beyond the pitch of recovery. And if any ≈øuch ≈øhould happen to have time, betweene his vile act and his expiration, his ≈øorrow for ≈øuch an extraordinary and odious fact cannot be true ≈øaving repentance: becau≈øe, repentance in ≈øuch extremities, and al≈øo late, where there is no time to trie, and give proofe of the ≈øoundne≈ø≈øe of it, is forced, and rarely true, and al≈øo repentance for one gro≈ø≈øe fact, or for a few, is not ≈øound, nor ≈øufficient for ≈øalvation; where a man ≈øtands guilty and impenitent for abundance of other finnes and corruptions, whereof he ought to repent, as well as of the other. And when and where was it ever knowne certainly, that any ≈øuch tran≈øcendent ≈øelf-murderer did ≈øavingly repent, although he had time betweene the blow and his departure?
And therefore, as no proper and tran≈øcendent ≈øelf-murderer doth, or can truly repent, ≈øo can he not be ≈øaved, but is damned, by and upon accompli≈øhment of that enormious and odious fact.

div.head: ¬ß. 7. The Churches Iudgement of ≈øelf-murderers.
div.p:
5. Rea≈øon. That all ≈øelf-murderers are damned. By the Iudgment of the Church. The fifth and la≈øt argument, that makes it apparent that no proper ≈øelf-murderer is ≈øaved, is the ancient and con≈øtantly continued Iudgement of the Church touching the finall e≈øtate of ≈øuch per≈øons, which is expre≈ø≈øed by her order and practi≈øe, in excluding them from the priviledges
of Chri≈øtian buriall, as hath beene formerly ≈øaid Chap. 17. ¬ß. 7. Argument 9.; that ≈øhe will neither permit, nor allow that their bodies ≈øhall be brought to the grave with Chri≈øtian ≈øolemnity; as, with ringing of Bells, or ≈øinging of P≈øalmes, or the like: nor that they ≈øhall be interred or buried in con≈øecrate ground or Chri≈øtian buriall, Pecreti ≈øecunda pars. cau≈øa. 23. quae≈øt. 5. c. 12. Vlacuit. in common with the bodies of tho≈øe, all who≈øe ≈øoules the Church hopes, in charity, are ≈øaved in Heaven: neither at their buriall, (where ever it be el≈øe) will the Church ≈øuffer any prayers, or reading of Scriptures to be u≈øed,Qui≈øe laqueo pertmunt, aut en≈øe recant, wanife≈øtum ≈øi ≈øeclus borum ≈øit, nobi≈øcum non tumulentur. Rarmundus. as may intimate to others any comfort, or hope of their ≈øalvation.

Their wills ≈øhe makes void, as of per≈øons that, having ca≈øt away their ≈øoules, have nothing left, nor power to di≈øpo≈øe of any thing, ≈øhe deemes it unrea≈øonable for ≈øuch to have their wills ≈øtand, who do, in ≈øo high a degree, with≈øtand and counterveen the will of God.

Barring them from Chri≈øtian buriall. Neither, at any time after their buriall, will the Church allow, or permit that any commemoration ≈øhall be made of the names of any ≈øuch, in the ≈øuffrages or ≈øolemnities of her divine ≈øervice, (as anciently the manner was to deale with tho≈øe, of who≈øe ≈øalvation ≈øhee did not de≈øpaire.)

That by this omi≈ø≈øion it might be manife≈øt, how ≈øhee abhorred ≈øelf-murderers, and their vile practi≈øe, and that their names might bee extinct, and rot, who≈øe ≈øoules ≈øhee conceived were damned: ≈øhe would not have them remembred, or regi≈øtred by her to their honor, that were ≈øo dead; or to the comfort of the living, either in regard of the fact, or in re≈øpect of the finall e≈øtate of the per≈øons, who≈øe names ≈øhe conceives are razed out of the booke of life.

For, if ≈øo bee that the Church did, in charity, conceive that the ≈øoules of any proper ≈øelf-murderers had communion after death, in place, ≈øtate and ble≈ø≈øedne≈ø≈øe, with the ≈øoules of tho≈øe that are ≈øaved; why then ≈øhould ≈øhee, or could ≈øhee ju≈øtly exciude the bodies of tho≈øe
≈øelf-murderers from communion, in Chri≈øtian buriall, with the bodies of the godly, and heires of ≈øalvation?

And, if the Church had any hope of the ≈øalvation of ≈øelf-murderers, why ≈øhould ≈øhe deny the u≈øe of tho≈øe meanes of ≈øolemnities, of reading of Scripture, of ≈øaying godly prayers, and of making honourable commemorations of their names in publick divine a≈ø≈øemblies and ≈øervice, whereby the Church her ≈øelf might be comforted, and al≈øo the di≈øcon≈øolate friends of ≈øuch parties might be cheered, touching the goodne≈ø≈øe of the finall e≈øtate of ≈øuch ≈øelf murderers?

Why ≈øhould the Church deny any of her common priviledges to any that ≈øhe conceives to inherit the priviledge of enjoying the kingdome of Heaven? it cannot be done, only for terror to the living, that they may not dare to do the like; becau≈øe, the Church, the pillar and ground of truth 1 Tim. 3.15., will not do ≈øo much wrong and inju≈øtice to the dead, to effect any good; for doing whereof ≈øhe hath other, and tho≈øe warrantable meanes ≈øufficient; yea, even the Roman Church leaves no place of hope for ≈øelf-murderers, ≈øo much as in purgatory; but abandons them all to hell without redemption, by all which the Church makes it manife≈øt, that it is her Judgement that none ≈øuch are ≈øaved; but are all damned: who≈øe very externall goods are judged, by the Church and Commonwealth, to be execrable; and, in that re≈øpect, are made a deodand.
And therefore, upon all the fore≈øaid rea≈øons, and arguments, I conclude that no proper ≈øelf-murderer, in manner afore≈øaid, can be ≈øaved, but are all damned.

div.head: ¬ß. 8. Of certaine u≈øes.
div.p:
Ob≈øerve. From what hath beene ≈øaid, touching the finall e≈øtate of proper ≈øelf-murderers, we may ob≈øerve, for our u≈øe;1. fir≈øt, that none but reprobates and damned per≈øons do
breake out into this tran≈øcendent, direct and proper ≈øelf-murder: ≈øo that, it is proper only for reprobates and damned per≈øons to do it, in the perfit height, and greate≈øt enormity of it; and is not incident to any good body that ≈øhall be ≈øaved, to do it, in that manner.

2. Secondly, the con≈øideration of the finall damnable e≈øtate of tho≈øe ≈øelf-murderers, in re≈øpect of that fact, may make ≈øelf-murder odious and formidable to all people; le≈øt by their venturing and approaching neere to the brinks of that de≈øperate gulph, they ≈øhould fall in; to the everla≈øting de≈øtruction both of ≈øoule and body: which ≈øhewes the de≈øperate madne≈ø≈øe of tho≈øe, that wilfully ruinate them≈øelves for ever, in this manner, by ≈øelf-murder.

div.head: ¬ß. 9. Certaine objections an≈øwered; and fir≈øt touching the nature of ≈øelf-murder.
div.p: Objections.There remaines now certaine objections to be an≈øwered, which may be made in favour of proper ≈øelf-murderers, for their ≈øalvation, which are e≈øpecially three.
The fir≈øt of them may be pretended to be taken from the nature of ≈øelf-murder, alledging that the ≈øame is not ≈øo hainous a ≈øinne, but that the doers thereof may bee ≈øaved.

1. From the nature of ≈øelf-murder. Fir≈øt, becau≈øe, if we con≈øider ≈øinnes as they are committed again≈øt the Go≈øpell, onely the ≈øinne again≈øt the holy Gho≈øt is called a ≈øinne unto death 1 Joh. 5.16., which never ≈øhall be pardoned Mat. 12.31.. Self-murder is not that ≈øinne, and therefore may ≈øeeme to bee pardonable, and the doers thereof ≈øaved.

2. Againe, if wee do con≈øider the ≈øinnes committed directly agai≈øt the Law, there is none of them de≈øperately unpardonable; becau≈øe they all, and every of them may, upon repentance, be cured by the Go≈øpell, which is of
equall extent to the Law, to be able to repleave and ≈øave all that the Law condemnes.

And of the ≈øinnes committed again≈øt the Law, ≈øome (as ≈øpitefull bla≈øphemy again≈øt the Maje≈øty of God, and the like;) may in the true nature of them ≈øeeme to be more hainous than ≈øelf-murder; both, in regard of their more direct and malignant oppo≈øition again≈øt God: and al≈øo for their greater di≈øtance in nature from pardon.

An≈øw. 1. The ≈øin again≈øt the holy Gho≈øt. To this objection, that caries with it a countenance of probability: I an≈øwer, fir≈øt, touching the argument taken from the ≈øin again≈øt the holy Gho≈øt, it is to be con≈øidered that, that ≈øin is unpardonable, and they damned that do it, onely in re≈øpect of that de≈øperate oppo≈øition, whereby the committers of it do ≈øpitefully oppo≈øe and reject Chri≈øt and his Go≈øpell, the very only meanes whereby they can be ≈øaved; ≈øo that there remaines no further, or other way, or help for ≈øalvation; and al≈øo becau≈øe, that ≈øinne is ever infallibly accompanied with finall impenitency; which alwaies makes a man uncapable of grace and ≈øalvation, which none can have but true penitents.

How ≈øelf-murder is equivaleÃÑt to the ≈øinne again≈øt the holy Gho≈øt. Self-murder hath that in it, which is in the ≈øin again≈øt the holy Gho≈øt, in re≈øpect whereof it damnes, and is unpardonable; which is both finall impenitency, in regard that a ≈øelf-murderer, by that ≈øinne in the perfection of the anomie of it, doth ≈øo indi≈øpo≈øe him≈øelfe, and ≈øhuts up and ends his life by, and in ≈øuch a horrible tran≈øgre≈ø≈øion, that hee cannot po≈ø≈øibly repent, nor con≈øequently bee ≈øaved. And al≈øo, equivalent and an≈øwerable to that ≈øpitefull rejection of Chri≈øt, his grace, and Go≈øpell, in the ≈øin again≈øt the holy Gho≈øt, by the living; there is in ≈øelf-murder the cutting off of one ≈øelfe (by his owne hands in this death,) from grace and ≈øalvation, to be gotten only in, and by life.

So that, in the≈øe re≈øpects, ≈øelf-murder is as certainly damnable, and the doers thereof reprobated, as is the ≈øin again≈øt the holy Gho≈øt, and the committers thereof. For,
although of the ≈øin again≈øt the holy Gho≈øt it be preci≈øely ≈øaid, that it ≈øhall never be forgiven, and that the committers thereof are certainely damned; yet, it is neither ≈øaid, nor is true that none, but ≈øinners again≈øt the holy Gho≈øt, have their ≈øinnes not forgiven to them, and are damned, ≈øeeing the contrary is abundantly certaine; and the wicked quality, and impenitent di≈øpo≈øition of ≈øome per≈øons, ≈øo depraved and vitiated by their ≈øins, makes the ≈øame to be in them unpardonable; which brings them to the ≈øame finall ≈øtate with ≈øinners again≈øt the holy Gho≈øt; it matters little for a mans comfort, that is to be put to death, whether he be hanged for felonie, or for burglarie, ≈øeeing for either of them his death is the ≈øame.

2. Self-murder a tran≈øcendent great ≈øin. Secondly, I an≈øwer touching the compari≈øon made betweene ≈øelf-murder and other ≈øinnes, committed again≈øt the Law, that ≈øelf-murder is a greater ≈øin, than any that can be directly and properly committed again≈øt and within any precept of the Law, for which the committers of the ≈øame may have grounded hope of forgivene≈ø≈øe; becau≈øe, ≈øelf-murder is a tran≈øcendent ≈øinne, as hath beene ≈øhewed in the third rea≈øon; tran≈øcedents are ever larger and greater than ≈øubordinates; and it is a ≈øinne condemnable by more, and ≈øtronger rea≈øons and arguments, than any other ≈øinne committed again≈øt and within the compa≈ø≈øe of the Law: as the ≈øame is more grievou≈øly injurious to more objects, and tran≈øgre≈ø≈øes more Lawes, naturall, divine, and humane; and therefore, it mu≈øt needs be the greater ≈øinne.

Al≈øo the e≈øtimate of the greatne≈ø≈øe and unpardonablene≈ø≈øe of ≈øinnes as they are in offenders, is not wholly to be made by con≈øideration of their ab≈øtract nature; but ≈øpecially the ≈øame is to bee made by the quality and di≈øpo≈øition of the committers of them, who≈øe per≈øonall and actionall circum≈øtances in doing of theÃÑ, much aggravats, or extenuats the ≈øame. For, pardon, or not pardon of ≈øins depends more upon the penitencie, or impenitency of
the offenders, than upon the nature of their ≈øins; ab≈øolutly and ab≈øtractly con≈øidered, the fact of ≈øelf murder is ≈øuch a ≈øinne, as no man penitently di≈øpo≈øed can commit, and it cuts him (that doth it) off finally from all repentance, and con≈øequently from ≈øalvation.

Self-murder mo≈øt dangerous for a mans ≈øoule. Of all ≈øinnes again≈øt the Law, ≈øelf-murder is mo≈øt dangerous and pernicious for a mans ≈øoule, to bring it to damnation: both becau≈øe, it excludes all care, and meanes of a mans ≈øalvation, which if a ≈øelf-murderer did regard, he would not venture in the la≈øt period of his life, upon a cour≈øe ≈øo contrary to it; and al≈øo, it puts the ≈øelf-murderer into ≈øuch an e≈øtate and di≈øpo≈øition of ≈øinfulne≈ø≈øe and aver≈øene≈ø≈øe from God and his will, in pur≈øuing of his owne wicked lu≈øt, that he is not, nor can be capable of grace, nor is in the way of ≈øalvation, whereunto ≈øelf-murder is mo≈øt contrary, by his la≈øt act of horrible ≈øin, in the clo≈øure of his life.

And therefore, it is apparent that, for any thing in this objection alledged, there is nothing from the nature of the ≈øin of ≈øelf-murder, properly ≈øo called, that can give any comfort of ≈øalvation to ≈øelf-murderers, or can warrant us to hold probably, and in the judgement of charity, that they are not all (generally con≈øidered) utterly damned.

div.head: ¬ß. 10. Touching Examples of ≈øelf-killers.
div.p: 2. Object. Is from examples. The ≈øecond objection, that may be made, in favour of the ≈øalvation of ≈øelf-murderers, is taken from examples of Samp≈øon, Pelagia, and many others that in the Primitive Church killed them≈øelves, and are acknowledged to be ≈øaved. Therefore, it may ≈øeeme probable that ≈øome ≈øelf-murderers may be ≈øaved.

An≈øwers. 1. That Samp≈øon is no ≈øelf-murderer. To this objection I an≈øwer, fir≈øt, touching Samp≈øon, that he was no ≈øelf-murderer directly; nor, in that point of ≈øo dying, indirectly; the rea≈øons whereof are evident.

Rea≈øons. 1. Fir≈øt, becau≈øe his intention, will and endeavours were not directly, or primarily, but only accidentally to kill him≈øelfe; but, in all the afore≈øaid re≈øpects, he was wholly bent to de≈øtroy his enemies the Phili≈øtims; which he could not doe, but with, and by the death of him≈øelfe: which is apparent by the ≈øtory, Iudg. 16.28.

2. Secondly, he was a Iudge of the people of I≈ørael, to free and avenge them of their enemies the Phili≈øtims; and therefore, by vertue of his office, was warranted to de≈øtroy them, as he ≈øhould be able; in which execution, although he peri≈øhed through his owne voluntary act, according to his owne certaine foreknowledge; he could not be a ≈øelf-murderer; from which ≈øinne his office and calling of God to that work freed him.

3. Thirdly, for that act, and la≈øt worke of Samp≈øon, whereby him≈øelfe died; God called him to it, that then and there he might ≈øo do it, both by his providence, giving him ≈øuch an opportunitie again≈øt his enemies ≈øo a≈ø≈øembled, as he could never have the like againe; and al≈øo, by the extraordinary ≈øupernaturall a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of the Spirit of God that came upon him,Spiritus latenter hoc ju≈ø≈øerat. Decreti ≈øecunda pars, cau≈øa. 23. c. 9. ≈øi non licet. and ≈øtrengthned him to do the deed: which it never doth for any wicked act; which is rather the work of the devill. Whereby it is manife≈øt that Samp≈øons act was not ≈øelf-murder.

4. That Samp≈øons act was warrantable, and no fact of ≈øelf-murder, is evident, by his intending, and going about it in ≈øubordination to God, and his will, manife≈øted by his Spirits a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, and obtained by lawfull and pious prayer, which no ≈øelf-murderer doth; who preferre their owne wills above Gods; in ≈øatisfying whereof, they cannot comfortably pray for Gods a≈ø≈øi≈øtance to doe the deed, which in their owne con≈øciences they know is unlawfull and wicked; and therefore, were horrible to entreat him to be an actor of the ≈øame with them.

5. Fiftly, this la≈øt act of Samp≈øon is ≈øpoken of in the hi≈øtory of it, Iudg. 16.30. with commendation; when it
is ≈øaid that the dead which he ≈ølew at his death, were more than they which he ≈ølew in his life: and Heb. 11.32. him≈øelfe is honoured among the faithfull, as being one of them: whereas the facts of ≈øelf-murder, and the per≈øons of ≈øelf-murderers are never ≈øpoken of, but with a≈øper≈øion of blame and di≈øgrace; and therefore, Samp≈øon is no ≈øelf-murderer.

6. Sixtly, things may be done lawfully in a type of figure upon divine in≈øtinct, or ordination; which otherwi≈øe were unlawfull to be done: as, a Certaine man of the ≈øonnes of the Prophets, ≈øaid unto his neighbour, in the word of the Lord, ≈ømite me, I pray thee: and the man refu≈øed to ≈ømite him: then ≈øaid he unto him, becau≈øe thou ha≈øt not obeyed the voice of the Lord, behold, a≈ø≈øoone as thou art departed from me, a Lyon ≈øhall ≈ølay thee: and a≈ø≈øoone as he was departed from him, a Lyon found him, and ≈ølew him. Then he found another man, and ≈øaid, ≈ømite me, I pray thee; and the man ≈ømote him, ≈øo that in ≈ømiting he wounded him, 1 King. 20.35, 36, 37. Which act otherwi≈øe had beene unlawfull; that here, done upon divine command, and for a type, or figure, was good.
Samp≈øons manner of ≈øo dying was a type or figure of Chri≈øt; who by his death ≈ølew more, than in his life: and therefore, in this re≈øpect, it was lawfull, and he no ≈øelf-murderer.

2. About Pelagia and others, not ≈øelf-murderers. Secondly, I an≈øwer, touching Pelagia, and others in the Primitive Church, who killed them≈øelves to avoid, either doing of ≈øin them≈øelves, or ≈øuffering ≈øin to be done upon them, that they were charitably thought of, and favourably cen≈øured; becau≈øe of their precedent pious godly life, and of their good intention, although the act were wicked; and are excu≈øed, 1. By allegation of their ignorance of the morall nature, and of the danger of the fact to their ≈øoules: 2. And by the ≈øuddaine inva≈øion and ≈øurpri≈øall of them, by violence of their unadvi≈øed pa≈ø≈øions: which can be no pre≈øident for ordinary practi≈øe,
either to warrant the fact to be lawfull, or to comfort the per≈øons doing it with expectation of the like event, and ≈øafety. But of this ≈øee more cap. 12 ¬ß 5. and cap. 15. ¬ß. 23. and cap. 17. ¬ß. 7. argument 17. & ≈øupra ¬ß 4.

Whereby it appeares evidently that tho≈øe, and ≈øuch per≈øons were not proper ≈øelf-murderers, and ≈øo not of that number, and ranck of ≈øelf-killers, that are, certainely, and finally, excluded from ≈øalvation. And ≈øo, this objection is of no force again≈øt the former conclu≈øion of the damnation of all proper and tran≈øcendent ≈øelf-murderers; becau≈øe, the in≈øtances given are in≈øufficient, and impertinent to make proofe, or to give any comfort and hope of ≈øalvation to any proper ≈øelf-murderer, in regard that the ≈øame are of another kinde; for, although, by falling by their owne hands, or meanes, they were ≈øelf-killers; yet they were not proper and direct ≈øelf-murderers; ≈øeeing the≈øe two are not alwaies convertible, and of equall extent, as hath beene ≈øhewed.

div.head: ¬ß. 11. About antecedent Prayer and repentance for pardon of ≈øinnes to come.
div.p:
3. Object. From mens preparation to God-ward, before they murder them≈øelves. The third objection, that may be alledged in favour of the ≈øalvation of ≈øelf-murderers, is that a ≈øelf-murderer purpo≈øing, and re≈øolved to murder him≈øelfe; may, before the fact make his peace with God, by humiliation and repentance for all his ≈øinnes pa≈øt, and in particular for his hainous ≈øin of ≈øelf murder to come; praying in≈øtantly to God to forgive him both the guiltine≈ø≈øe and puni≈øhment of that vile fact, that he is bent ≈øuddainely to do; and be≈øeeching him, through Chri≈øt and his merits, to receive him into mercy, and to ≈øave his ≈øoule; for the ≈øame, ca≈øting him≈øelfe upon, and beleeving in Chri≈øt. And ≈øo, thereupon di≈øpatches and murders him≈øelfe, by his owne meanes, or hands; hoping and expecting to be ≈øaved: whereby, and in which ca≈øe, ≈øuch an one ≈øeemes
to die in a good minde, in peace with God, and in charity with all the world; and in an e≈øtare ≈øure enough of heaven for his ≈øoule, and of perfection of ≈øalvation for both, at the re≈øurrection, and great day of Judgement.

An≈øwer. A ≈øelf-murderer cannot make peace with God.To this objection, I an≈øwer, that no man can make, or be at peace with God; when and ≈øo long as he wilfully intends and per≈øi≈øts in ≈øuch a ≈øinfull cour≈øe, or practi≈øe, as offends, enrages, and makes God his implacable enemie, in that ca≈øe: ≈øuch is the ≈øtate of an indivertibly-re≈øolved ≈øelf-murderer; and therefore, it is impo≈ø≈øible that, ≈øo long as he is in that minde to murder him≈øelfe, he can make, or be at peace with God; whom, by his vile ≈øin, he inrages again≈øt him, ≈øo that he cannot die that way, but in vengeance from God; both thereby puni≈øhing his former ≈øinnes, and al≈øo thus di≈øpatching him away to hell.

Antecedent prayer and repentance for ≈øelf-murder is uneffectuall. Neither can any man truly repent before hand, for that gro≈ø≈øe ≈øinne, which he is purpo≈øed, and fully bent to do afterward; notwith≈øtanding that he knowes the ≈øame to be directly contrary to Gods will, and to his own ≈øalvation. Neither can any mans precedent prayer be effectuall with God, for to obtaine pardon of a vile enormious ≈øin, that he de≈øperatly and unre≈øi≈øtably intends to perpetrate again≈øt the will of God; which I will manife≈øt by three ≈øtrong rea≈øons.

Rea≈øons. 1. Such prayer condemnes the ≈øelf-murderer. Fir≈øt, Repentance, and Prayer to God for pardon of the vile ≈øin of ≈øelf-murder, that a man purpo≈øes to do; doth manife≈øt, it is in him, not a ≈øinne of infirmity, but a mo≈øt pre≈øumptuous ≈øin, which he doth ≈øo advi≈øedly, deliberatly, wittingly, and willingly go about: and therefore, in that ca≈øe, is farre from true repentance, and hath no ground for him to dare to come before God, to pray for ≈øuch a thing, neither can he hope to be heard in ≈øuch a prayer, which helps onely to condemne him, if he do the ≈øinne: becau≈øe, thereby he witne≈ø≈øes and te≈øtifies again≈øt him≈øelf, that ≈øuch an act of ≈øelf-murder is wicked and ≈øinfull, and
that he doth advi≈øedly and pre≈øumptuou≈øly intend, and do it; and therefore, for his doing of it, may mo≈øt ju≈øtly and certainely looke to be damned.

And againe, by ≈øuch an antecedent prayer, repentance and pretended reconciliation to God, ≈øuch a ≈øelf-murderer doth but beg of God leave, that he may ≈øecurely ≈øinne, in that horrible manner, and fact, without feare, or check of con≈øcience, or touch of puni≈øhment: which is to de≈øire, that God would be unju≈øt; by ≈øhewing mercy, contrary to his nature and truth, to pre≈øumptuous ≈øinners, in their act of ≈øo ≈øinning: and ≈øo by that kinde of humiliation, and prayer to God, for favour in their purpo≈øe and act of ≈øelf-murder, they make God a partie acce≈ø≈øary to their ≈øinne, and to be ≈øinfull, by his a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of them in their vile practi≈øe.
Such per≈øons abhorre not the ≈øinne, but the puni≈øhment; and would have heaven by their owne way, contrary to Gods; which cannot be.

2. Such prayer is not of faith. The ≈øecond rea≈øon, proving the unlawfulne≈ø≈øe, and uneffectualne≈ø≈øe of the antecedent repentance, and prayer of ≈øelf-murderers, for pardon for the ≈øin, that they purpo≈øe to commit, is; becau≈øe, ≈øuch a prayer cannot be of faith, whereby they ≈øue to God for a pardon ante factum before the deed be done; which is nothing el≈øe but the grant of a di≈øpen≈øation for them to ≈øin, in mo≈øt vile manner, which is mo≈øt unlawfull to be de≈øired; for which there is no warrant, and it is mo≈øt impo≈ø≈øible for God to grant; becau≈øe, thereby hee mu≈øt not onely di≈øpen≈øe with the puni≈øhment of the fact, contrary to his ju≈øtice: but al≈øo he mu≈øt approve of the deed to be done, as lawfull; contrary to his nature, and will. For, both the allowance of the fact, and al≈øo exemption from puni≈øhment are comprehended in a di≈øpen≈øation.

But, God can neither lye, by ≈øhewing mercy contrary to his truth, nor yet can approve any ≈øin, ≈øo as it ≈øhould be no ≈øin in the doer, and act of it: which is a contradiction.
True repentance lyes ≈øpecially in abhorring, for≈øaking and reforming of ≈øin; both for the habit, and for the act of it; which, in this ca≈øe, a ≈øelf-murderer doth not; and therefore, doth not repent, neither of his other former ≈øins, nor of this; for the ≈øame rea≈øon of repenting for the one, is for the other.

3. It is unwarrantable. The third rea≈øon of the vaine≈ø≈øe of ≈øuch repentance and prayer, made by ≈øelf-murderers, is; becau≈øe, the ≈øame wants all warrant: For, repentance can be onely of ≈øins committed and pa≈øt, or pre≈øent, and not of ≈øins to come; whereof a man (in that re≈øpect) cannot be guilty; becau≈øe, a thing to come is yet a non ens, or nothing; it is not certaine it ≈øhall be: and all ≈øins for time to come ≈øhould be utterly re≈øolved again≈øt, and with≈øtood, with prayer to God for grace, that wee may never bee able to doe them.

Pardon of ≈øins is craved by prayer, and granted by God, onely for ≈øinnes commited; and not before they be done: for, pardon followes upon repentance; which is properly of ≈øins done, and not of ≈øinnes purpo≈øed to be done. True repentance changes, both a mans ill purpo≈øes and practi≈øe; contrary to the cour≈øe and di≈øpo≈øition of ≈øuch a ≈øelf-murderer, who≈øe repentance and prayer tends to incourage him more boldly to ≈øinne; by a mo≈øt vile fact of ≈øelf-murder: he cleaves to the ≈øinne, and practi≈øes it; the puni≈øhment whereof he would avoid, which are individuall companions.

It is a ≈øtrange madne≈ø≈øe for a ≈øelf-murderer to conceit, or pre≈øume, that God, upon his prayer proceeding out of a wicked minde, and from an ill intent, will grant him his reque≈øt and will, for the ≈øalvation of his ≈øoule, when as he will not yeild to the will of God, who forbids the horrible ≈øin of ≈øelf-murder.

Note.Touching ≈øuch ≈øelf-murderers beleeving, hoping, and ca≈øting them≈øelves upon Chri≈øt for ≈øalvation; I grant, they may have de≈øires of ≈øalvation; but it is onely to be
had in Gods way, and therefore, they cannot have it in their own. True faith and hope they cannot have; becau≈øe, the ≈øame cannot con≈øi≈øt with ≈øuch raigning and advi≈øed pre≈øumptuous ≈øins; neither have they any ground to beleeve, or hope that any, in that ca≈øe, can be ≈øaved.

To ca≈øt them≈øelves upon Chri≈øt for ≈øalvation I deny not; as the fooli≈øh Virgins that knocked to be let in; but Chri≈øt will be Saviour to none, that will not ≈øubmit to him for to be their King; to be ordered by him, in all things.

Although multitudes come and ca≈øt them≈øelves upon Chri≈øt for ≈øalvation by him, yet hee receives, and ≈øaves none but ≈øuch as come fir≈øt to him, in all humilitie and obedience, to be cured of their ≈øinnes, and to be ruled by his Lawes.

Pre≈øumption.The hope and expectation of the ≈øalvation of ≈øuch ≈øelf-murdering per≈øons when they die; is but groundle≈ø≈øe pre≈øumption, in regard that their abu≈øe of religious practi≈øes of prayer and the like, and wretched dallying with God, in ≈øo wicked a minde, and to ≈øo vile an end, doth aggravate their ≈øin, and makes them much more culpable and ≈øubject to eternall damnation, than if they had forborne the ≈øame: the expectation and de≈øire of the wicked, and hope of the hypocrites ≈øhall peri≈øh Prov. 10.28. Job. 8.13. P≈øal 112.10..
They that do to them≈øelves an act of the greate≈øt hatred and ho≈øtility in the world, in murdering them≈øelves, cannot properly be in charity with others; God, or men.

And to die in peace, and in a good minde they cannot, who≈øe mindes at their la≈øt ga≈øpe, are perturbed, troubled, and ≈øet upon a mo≈øt horrible vile act of ≈øelf-murder; attended upon with all horror from Heaven and hell, to their everla≈øting confu≈øion.

So then it is apparent, for ought that can be ≈øaid in favour, or hope of the ≈øalvation of any proper ≈øelf-murderer; that there is no probability of the ≈øalvation of any
of them, but that they are all damned; according to the former conclu≈øion.
And therefore, we are to beware that, upon no pretence, we approach neere to that ≈øin, which brings to ≈øo certaine and eternall de≈øtruction.

2. Stiffne≈ø≈øe of re≈øolution to kill ones ≈øelfe. The ≈øecond let to be removed is, ≈øtiffne≈ø≈øe of purpo≈øe, and re≈øolution of committing ≈øelf-murder. div.head: ¬ß. 3. Of the meanes to be u≈øed with others again≈øt temptations to ≈øelf-murder.
div.p:
The ≈øecond kinde of Antidotes are with others. The ≈øecond ≈øort of Antidotes and meanes to be u≈øed for prevention of ≈øelf-murder, is the cour≈øe that they, that
labour under ≈øuch temptations, are to take jointly with others: which is either privatly with a few, or publickly with the Church.

1. With a few. To advi≈øe, and pray. Fir≈øt, with a few, (to whom by confe≈ø≈øion ≈øuch a partie ≈øo afflicted hath di≈øcovered his e≈øtate, as hath been ≈øaid,) he is both to advi≈øe by conference, for ≈øetling his judgement, re≈øolving and comforting his con≈øcience; and for right ordering of his practi≈øe: and al≈øo, to u≈øe fa≈øting and prayer together with ≈øuch friends in private; whereby he may get power from God to overcome the temptation, and to be freed from danger of the fact.

For, we have a promi≈øe, that where there are two or three a≈ø≈øembled together in Chri≈øts name, there he will be in the mid≈øt of them, and will grant them what≈øoever they ≈øhall aske in his name

Note. The care of friends to the tempted. The care of private friends, ≈øo farre intere≈ø≈øed by confe≈ø≈øion in this ca≈øe, ≈øhould be, not only to advi≈øe, and pray for tho≈øe that are under the≈øe temptations, in company with them: but al≈øo to pray for them by them≈øelves: and towards ≈øuch they ≈øhould ≈øhew them≈øelves pitifull, and compa≈ø≈øionate, about their e≈øtate; ≈øuch per≈øons di≈øtemper is better allayed palpando quam pul≈øando, by gentlene≈ø≈øe, than by rigour: they ≈øhould often deale with them, and que≈øtion them about their ≈øucce≈ø≈øe again≈øt their temptations: for, what cannot be effected at once, repetition may worke; and the victory be got, and the cure be accompli≈øhed; ≈øuddaine cures are commonly un≈øound: and to leave them over-≈øoone argues too much neglect of them; and al≈øo the di≈øea≈øe is not fully di≈øcovered, when they ≈øuppo≈øe the ≈øame is healed.Note.

How ≈øelf-murder is be≈øt prevented by removall of the motives to it. Self-murder is prevented, not ≈øo much by arguments again≈øt the fact; which di≈ø≈øwades from the conclu≈øion; as by the di≈øcovery and removall of the motives and cau≈øes, whereupon they are tempted to do the ≈øame:Compari≈øon. as di≈øea≈øes are cured by removing of the cau≈øes, rather than of their ≈øymptomes: and practicall conclu≈øions are overthrowne by
≈øolid confutation of the premi≈øes and arguments, upon which they do depend; in logicall di≈øcour≈øe, conclu≈øions are neither properly the matter of denyall, nor of confutation, ≈øo long as the premi≈øes, and rea≈øons, whereupon the ≈øame ≈øtands, are pa≈ø≈øed by, as allowed, or granted.

2. With the Church. Secondly, when as the temptations of ≈øelf-murder ≈øtill prevaile again≈øt all the former meanes; then it remaines for the tempted to flee unto, and to make u≈øe of the more publick helps and a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of the Church: which (as a tender Mother) both compa≈ø≈øionatly pities her di≈øtre≈ø≈øed Children; and al≈øo by her coun≈øell and comfort to them, and by her interce≈ø≈øion and prayers to God with, and for them; is ever readie, as well in her publick a≈ø≈øemblies, as in private to relieve and ≈øuccour all tho≈øe that re≈øort to her for the ≈øame: which from, and by her meanes is more certainly and comfortably to bee expected, and to be had, than by any other cour≈øe; as the publick Church is more prevalent with God, than private Chri≈øtians; and the promi≈øes of God more ample to her for regard and audience, than to her particular members.

div.head: ¬ß. 4. Of the cour≈øe that others without the tempted are to take to ≈øave him.
div.p: 3. By others powerfull re≈øtraint. The third ≈øort of Antidotes, or pre≈øervatives again≈øt ≈øelf-murder is, when after the u≈øe of all the fore≈øaid meanes, the temptation of ≈øelf-murder ≈øtill continues and prevailes in a party re≈øolved to kill him≈øelfe; and ≈øeeking and attempting all the meanes that he can to do it: then all others are to be carefull;

1. Required of God by Prayer. Fir≈øt, not to cea≈øe to pray to God in≈øtantly for him, that he would keepe him and deliver him by his over-ruling providence, hindering the execution, and turning his will.

2. Be ob≈øervant of the tempted. Secondly, men ≈øhould bee ob≈øervant of ≈øuch per≈øons;
1. To ≈øpie out the cau≈øes. both to fi≈øh and ≈øpie out the outmo≈øt hidden lurking undi≈øcovered cau≈øes thereof, that the ≈øame may be removed, that hinders the cure;2. To watch him that he do it not. and al≈øo, to watch him, again≈øt all oppertunities and meanes, whereby hee may accompli≈øh his act of ≈øelf-murder.

3. Humane forcible re≈øtraint. Thirdly, they are to u≈øe outward forcible re≈øtraint to ≈øuch an one, as to a mad man; ≈øhutting him up, and keeping meanes of ≈øelf-de≈øtruction from him; as much as may be. The putting by of the violent attempts and pa≈ø≈øions of ≈øelf-murder, which comes by fits, ague-like, not only re≈øtraines the act for the time beeing, but may al≈øo counter-check and abate the rage of it, that by degrees it may be prevailed again≈øt, and a≈ø≈øwaged;Compari≈øon. as agues, many times, are cured accidentally, by very impertinent modicines, putting by the fits.

Ob≈øerve. None are ≈øelf-murdered but by their owne fault. From that which hath beene ≈øaid, touching the Antidotes for ≈øelf-murder, we may ob≈øerve that it is a mans owne fault if he peri≈øh by ≈øelf-murder, in neglect of u≈øing the meanes again≈øt it.Compari≈øon. V≈øe of it. And al≈øo, for this deliverance, ≈øuch a one is bound to be ever exceeding thankefull to God.
Vpon the cure, dangers.Upon pre≈øervation and freedome out of the≈øe temptations of ≈øelf-murder, a man is to take heed of two great dangers.

1. Security, &c. Fir≈øt, ≈øecurity, ≈øelf-confidence and pre≈øumption, whereby tho≈øe corruptions and ≈øinnes may clo≈øely grow upon
him, that may bring him into as dangerous a condition for his ≈øalvation; as we ≈øee how Hezechia after his recovery out of his mortall ≈øickne≈ø≈øe, fell into other ≈øins, (as he manife≈øted, by his oftentation to the me≈ø≈øengers of Babylon, in boa≈øtingly-≈øhewing them his trea≈øure and ≈øtrength) all which co≈øt him deare.2 King 20.13.

2. Vnprofitable life to goodne≈ø≈øe. The ≈øecond danger to be avoided, after ≈øuch a recovery, is unprofitable living; when ≈øuch a man ≈øpends not the life that God hath given him, in ≈øpeciall manner, to Gods glory, to the good of others, and to his owne ≈øalvation; which is the maine end why God gives us our lives; and for the attainement thereof, if we ≈øpend them not, it were better for us not to live.

Ob≈øerve. The various ≈øtates, and great dangers that God carieth man through are very remarkable: and Gods worke therein is gracious and wonderfull; for which we ≈øhould ever prai≈øe his glorious and ble≈ø≈øed name, with con≈øtant dependance upon, and dutifull ob≈øequiou≈øne≈ø≈øe to him, in all our life, and wayes: which God grant we may do.
